reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is very unique. No 2 kills are the same. I'm still finding new ways to ragdoll opponents. This game is extremely hard to learn at first. I spent 10+ hours practicing the combat before I had the basics down well enough to win a few fights.  The flip side is that this game is extremely rewarding and has a lot of replayability. I've owned this game since the fall of last year and Bare Mettle has updated the game with new content 3 times already. Thats an amazing pace.

I've had so much fun crawling through the dungeons. Exanima's main game has a survival horror feel to it. you have to scrounge for clothes, then armor, weapons. (I really like that the clothes and armor can be layered for max effect) It's never easy. The violent collisions in combat are the highlight of Exanima. The control scheme in this game allows for very precise movement and maneuvers. It also allows you to throw all of your bodyweight into an attack.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima has by far the most engaging and dynamic combat system I've ever tried. At first I found the controls sluggish and they seemed severely unpolished, but that was only because I wasn't used to the simulated weight of my character. Now, after a couple of hours of practice I'm capable of sweeping my enemies off their feet with a powerful blow of my two-handed mace and bash their skulls against the floor.

Procedural animations and movements bound by the laws of physics makes every battle unique. The combat is not flashy but that makes it so much fun, like a proper brawl. You and your enemies will stumble around and trip over objects lying on the floor while trying to kill each other, and suddenly one of you might strike a blow to the head, which often determines the victor. Fatality...

One of the funniest moments I had was when I was cornered by two guys. One had a giant axe and the other some whimpy stick. When Mr. Axe swings, I trip over a chair and the axe misses my head by a straw, instead the axe hits Mr. Stick right in the kisser and sends him flying into a wall. Mr. Stick sags down on the floor next to me, and when Mr. Axe tries to hit me a second time he trips over the same chair I did. The three of us flop around on the floor, trying to get up, but the physics of the game won't let us, we're so entangled <3

Ah, I will remember Mr. Axe and Mr. Stick with great fondness.

If you want to try something fresh, this is it. Don't be frightened by the controls when you start out, once you master it, it can be the greatest thing ever.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is an isometric physics-based dungeon crawling RPG. This combination of genres probably doesn’t make a lot of sense at the first glance, as we usually see physics being one of the main gameplay elements in different puzzle and adventure games alike, but very rarely in something more action-oriented.

The main feature of the game, which differentiates it from any other top-down RPG, while also defining the gameplay itself, is that almost all the objects in the game world are subjects to physics, including the player character and all the NPCs. Not only does it enable player (or his enemies) to trip over some environmental detail, like a pile of rubble or a carelessly dropped chair, but also completely changes the way fighting works in general.

Usually, in a top-down game, pressing an “attack” button would initiate an animation, at the end of which the target enemy would receive some pre-determined (or calculated via rolling of some invisible dice, DnD-style) amount of damage. In Exanima, it only really does the first of these actions or, to be precise, starts the animation. What happens next is completely dependent on player’s actions: the damage is only dealt if the weapon makes physical contact with the opponent, and its amount is based on three different parameters: type of damage (is determined by the weapon) and the target’s resistance to this particular type, the weapon’s weight, and, most importantly, the momentum that the player has been able to give to it. One single blow can knock your enemy down to the ground or even completely crush him if executed properly, while simply holding the attack button would result in a flurry of weak and easily blockable strikes, which would probably just get you killed.

The animations, although they are constantly being tweaked and improved, still look kind of sluggish and wonky, leading a lot of people to the conclusion that Exanima is just a “drunken fighter simulator”. When you first start playing, it really does seem that the player has nearly no control over his character’s actions and movement, but after you get accustomed to the controls, the combat system starts working just fine. As the developers say, this game really IS different from the others, so you shouldn’t expect to be able to be good at it from the very start.

As for the actual gameplay, there are currently 3 modes: “Practice” – fighting against some progressively stronger NPCs, “Arena” – practice with global progression (is kind of slow and boring for now) and the main “Story” mode.
In the story mode you find yourself alone in a dungeon, crawling with zombie-like creatures, and start trying to find your way out. The dungeon is NOT procedurally generated, and consists of 4 manually created levels, with a save available at the beginning of each one. If you die, you’ll have to start from the checkpoint, leading to a lot of frustration early on. During this noble quest to save… eeh… your life, you will find new weapons and armor pieces (and yes, this game has an incredible equipment system with a few layers of armor), as well of pieces of information about what has actually happened in this dire place. Also, note that most of the damage you take is permanent, and there are only 2 or 3 healing items in the entire game. Regarding the length of the game, I can only say that it took me nearly 13 hours to thoroughly explore the first 2 layers, and only gods know how much I’ve spent on the third.

Exanima is currently in Early Access state, and has recently started to develop rapidly; the devs are introducing new mechanics into the game, such as thrusting attacks and skill systems, and it is clear that they are not going to stop the development until it’s finished.
I would personally recomend this game to anyone who is looking for a new gaming experience and is persistent enough to make it through the early stages.

P.S. As you could have already noticed, English is not my native language, so if you find any mistakes, feel free to point them out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game where every time you encounter an enemy, you step aside and let him pass; hoping upon hope that he does not take notice of you and just continues his or her eternal routine of endlessly roaming around a sinister dungeon. If you antagonize them for whatever reason, however, then they will descend upon you with the wild swinging of an undead barbarian backed with the power of this game's fantastic, all-encompassing physics engine.

Every single fight in this game could be your last. Against every enemy. This is a game where you are constantly on edge, never able to relax and torn between searching every single room in hope of finding a better piece of gear to protect yourself or avoiding them out of fear of a wild prisoner slamming a lumber axe into your face.

Throughout the environment there are signs of a story. A note here, or a room where a man has attempted to barricade himself in before eventually falling to a horrific onslaught. In another, a man is slumped against a desk, presumably murdered by inmates or servants. The graphics are gloomy and the sound design sinister; it's a dungeon crawler that has  the potential to scare you witless.

As mentioned before, physics are a huge part of the game. It boasts that it simulates everything and I would be inclined to agree that they're not too wrong. The player is able to drag objects around the world to create obstacles or block doors, even throw wooden planks and crates at enemies to hinder their progress. Combat consists of force, momentum and locational damage. Swing a hammer hard enough and at the correct distance and you can bash your enemy to the ground; but misjudge the distance and your forearm or weapon handle will bounce harmlessly off them. Weapons swung at the same time into each other will collide and blocking is done automatically depending on the availability of your character to adequately protect himself and where you choose to face. You can even swing your character around while holding the attack button to perform larger, more powerful attacks with momentum and force behind them - but the enemy can see these coming and either avoid the attack completely or attack you while you're open.

Enemy AI is fantastic. At first, you may find yourself at every disadvantage. You might find the controls awkward and unfriendly and your character slow or clumsy. But then you realize that your enemy has all those disadvantages too; bound also by the power of the game's physics engine and subject to all the same laws as you. To compensate, each enemy plays almost like you would expect a player too; right down to simulating reaction times and attempting to read your movement to best figure out how to defeat you. It has, by far, the most realistic and engaging melee combat I have ever seen in a video game.

You need to re-learn how to fight if you plan to play this game - and you should. You need to treat it as though it's as real as any fight you've been in personally. This is not just a game where you have to learn the controls, but a game where you have to truly master your chosen weapon and stay one step ahead of your opponent at all times, because once you die? That's it. You have to start all over again.

If real men play Dark Souls, then only the baddest of the badasses play Exanima.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is an unforgiving isometric RPG currently available through Steam Early Access. In Exanima you explore, fight and survive while grappling with the game's tricky combat system. Exanima is set in a dark 'low-fantasy' underworld and from what I understand from the Store page it's a prelude for a bigger, open world RPG, developed by the same studio.

Exanima's main selling point is its unique, physics-based, combat system which tries to be as realistic as possible with a focus on momentum, forces and collisions between characters as well as weapons. In making their combat system so realistic Bare Mettle have inadvertently created one of the most difficult combat systems I've ever come across, even after just over 5 hours of gameplay I'm still really struggling to make heads or tails of it and the explanation of it in the in-game literature isn't helpful either, this is something you have to learn by yourself. However the game's physics doesn't just impact the combat, it also impacts movement and interaction with in-game items so if you run into something on the floor, chances are you're gonna fall over rather than kick it out of the way.

Currently Exanima is split into two game-modes, Arena and Campaign. Most of the time I've spent with Exanima has been in the Arena trying to grasp the game's combat but I will briefly explain both modes.

In Arena mode you start out with basic clothes and a basic weapon and you begin in a small room facing off against one enemy who has a one handed weapon and basic clothes. After you kill your first enemy you progress to a new room where you fight a slightly more powerful enemy and that continues until you die. When you do die, which you will, you will have access to any weapons or armour you picked up from your foes during your time in the Arena but these are only saved for your current session, quit the game and you will no longer have access to them.

In Campaign mode you start with some clothes and a torch and you must make your way through the dungeon which you find yourself in, defending yourself against enemies and then taking what you can from them to make yourself stronger. I've never managed to get very far in Campaign, which is part of the reason why I've stuck to Arena, so I'm not sure if there's any sort of end-game to it or if you just continue exploring forever.

+Very good graphics
+As mentioned, very realistic physics
+Hitting/killing enemies is oh so satisfying thanks to the combat system
+Quite a lot of weapons, items, clothing and armour
+Excellent character creator which manages to give you a fair amount of power while remaining easy to use
+Brutally unforgiving
+Requires some skill to play, it's not just button mashing which is a nice change for isometric RPGs
+Not all enemies attack on sight which gives you some time to prepare
+Very unpredictible enemies
+Good sound effects

+/-Permadeath in Arena and Campaign

-As mentioned the combat is very difficult to wrap your head around and the explanation of how it works in-game isn't very helpful so you need to figure it out for yourself
-One handed weapons feel underpowered compared to polearms
-Movement is based entirely on your cursor, for example W makes you walk towards your cursor rather than walk up relative to the camera which I don't really like especially as you have to move the mouse around a lot in combat which leads to a lot of unwanted movement
-Walking and running animations are a bit odd

Here's a short gameplay video I recorded of the Arena mode:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SQmzv7VCbwM

Verdict:
8

Despite some flaws Exanima presents a unique idea in a good way with very good graphics, interesting combat mechanics and good item variety. Even if you don't want to buy it this is certainly one to watch.

***This review was written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***

El K.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I believe early access reviews should focus on two parts:

-Is the game worth buying at this time?
and
-How does the games potential look?

At this time, January 9th 2015, both of these questions hold up pretty well with exanima. I won't bother to explain what the description already says, but I will elaborate on how it plays out.

The games physics engine has a huge amount of effort poured into it, even at this early stage. The strikes you do can land with a crushing thump, or maybe just a light scrape, depending on how you angle your hits and how hard your strike hits. It turns into a very challenging fighting mechanic that rewards careful tactics and good swordsmanship.

However, it should be mentioned that at the current time, everyone is drunk. Yes, even the skeletons. Essentially theres two types of stances. Normal movement stance, and fighting stance. Movement stance is fine for the most part. Feels a little funky due to the nature of physics and such, but overall very responsive.

And then theres fighting stance. The character readies his weapons, widens his stance, and slowly crab-walks towards his foes with determination. To say the least, it feels a little funny switching between these two modes, and the crabwalk feels a bit unresponsive at times (once again, due to physics. It makes sense when you analyze the movement). However, it does the job well enough.

Once you get the hang of these, it works. Most of the time, quite well. But even though its mechanically smooth, it feels a bit clunky just due to the very nature of the beast. Expect to die a few times while your getting used to it.

The combat is very very satisfying. As mentioned before, depending on how you strike a target, or a target strikes you, changes the amount of damage done. Since parrying happens quite often, landing those satisfying blows is just too much fun. Its the delicious crunchy reward after being hammered blow after blow and barely fending them off every time.

The story at this stage has a little bit of love too poured into it. Its told in dark-souls style, where little fragments of parchment lore are scattered throughout the level, and by reading parchment after parchment you begin to piece together a rough idea of whats happening. So far, it needs quite a bit of work and a little more substance: I've read most of the accessible parchments and I still have no idea whats going on. But, its intriguing, and leaves me searching around for more.

On whats apparently considered a good run, I completed the current storymode at around 8-10 hours. If you were to speedrun it, I'd probably say it could be completed in less than 2. Exanima has the mindset where levels could be completed very fast if you know where everything is, but most of the fun comes from exploring the various rooms, finding new story fragments, gear, and areas.

With all that in mind, exanima is a unique experience. Many games say they have physics, but nothing implements the idea so thoroughly as exanima. It permeates its every fiber and decision it makes.

For that, I'd say its well worth the asking price at the moment for 15 dollars, and its potential is astounding. I'll be watching this game closely as it comes out with updates, and I'd recommend for anyone else who wants to try a truly unique RPG experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First Fight: Holy hell, is this guy drunk? Am I drunk? What is this?

One hour in: Ok, ok. So moving forward and swinging is pretty good. But what if I use my drunken shove and combo it?

One hour, thirty minutes in: OH SWEET BABY JESUS THERE'S AN ALTERNATIVE ATTACK?! Stab, stab, swing, lounge push, swing... ... ...

Three hours in: Judging by the trajectory of this guy's movements and his previous attempts at coming at me from the side, he's going to move to the left to flank, and that gives me an opportunity to feint after a solid parry to put him on the defensive and back him into a corner. Then... ... ..


Look, this game is great.
It brings a fresh new formula to combat in top-down action RPGs. At first it feels rather choppy as you flail about to get ahold of the controls, but it turns out to be a system that flows well and keeps you on your toes, regardless of who your enemy is (the AI is very good so far, and beating enemies on equal-footing is always a rewarding feeling).

Exanima is very difficult, has a fun learning curve (crazy thought, I know), and overall has pretty great gameplay. The atmosphere is relatively similar to the Dark Souls series in that the dark, gritty setting is coupled with a complete lack of hand-holding and the story is entirely dependant on how much you want to look into it.

The development of this game appears to be coming along very well, and the devs appear to be quite responsive to their community. I'm quite happy with the progress, which shows no signs of slowing, and I think it's worth every penny of $15- especially if you're already a fan of the genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Attention to detail:
1: The maps are designed in such a way that all objects and rooms have purpose. I can tell the purpose of each room by the arrangement of objects in it that room. Rooms seem practical. The dungeon really feels like a credible and livable environment.
2: The fantasy elements are used sparingly, which makes them more important when they appear. This is why I enjoy low fantasy settings. High fantasy has the tendency to overdo the fantastic and throw out logic, which forces the developers to continually ramp up the scale until things get ridiculous and unbelievable. Fantasy based on spectacle is superficial and boring, whereas low fantasy builds and builds in an exciting progression, where all of the times feel important, even the simple ones.
3: Weapons and armor are clearly created using real world influences, but with a healthy touch of artistic license where it's needed. Never once did I think that something looks too overdesigned to be appealing, or too impractical to ever be used.  Even the expert boss' armor, despite clearly being fantasy, doesn't appear too implausible to break my suspension of disbelief. In Sui Generis, my bet is that it'll take some serious treasure hunting to ever find something like that.
4: Item randomization is really cool. I love how you can find all sorts of clothes with different colors, fabric, stitching patterns, etc. Even when two objects are of precisely the same kind, they'll still have slight variations to make them appear different. I've always found it bothersome in RPGs where two objects are precisely the same, and this game does away with that. Item randomization also adds another layer of replayability.
5: Looting is actual looting. I despise when you can find the +10 polearm of irascibility" somehow inside the entrails of a rabbit

Ok, so at first I thought the combat system was silly...Then I went in the Arena, and practiced for an hour. This may very well be the best combat system for an RPG I have ever played. I am absolutly in love with this engine. The fact that I can charge an enemy after he swings and is off balance and knock him over....Brilliant. The Physics are fantastic. After a few hours getting use to the combat, I tried my hand at the Dungeon....All I can say, this is a very SPECIAL title, and one I will be watching very closely. I havent had this much fun in a dungeon crawl in a long time.

The controls are odd, but that is merely because it is a system never done before. Once you learn it, FANTASTIC!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is going to be an in-depth review, so grab a drink and some food, ladies and gentlemen. You'll be here for a while.

STORY

You start out as a character who, I assume, has either fallen into a dungeon and been rendered unconscious, or chosen to do so willing. Let's assume the first option is correct. Regaining consciousness, you wake up, grab your torch, and set off deeper into the dungeon, as returning to the surface doesn't look possible.

You can piece the story together slowly, collecting scrolls here and there, but not many. This game is somewhat like Dark Souls, where the story isn't fed to you. You have to discover it on your own, though I'm not sure enough information is given to even do so. However, I haven't gotten far in the game, as I have a kill-on-sight mentality, which is not helpful in a game like Exanima. Therefore, I cannot give an accurate review of the story.

GAMEPLAY

Regarding the main game, from the start, you are given a torch. There are other items to find if you are clever enough to find them. The game is based on a system where you slowly improve your weapons and armor over time by killing those around you and taking their loot or raiding chests and rooms. That being said, the game is  very  hard. Don't expect to begin playing and immediately start dominating your enemies. In the beginning, you  will be killed, again and again and again. This should be expected, as combat and movement takes some getting used to. This will be covered in a later section.

The enemies you encounter are smart, and will not go down without a fight. They must be handled carefully, as damage in this game is something you do  not  want to take. Regarding damage, there are two types: lethal, and non-lethal. Lethal damage is represented by the color red, while non-lethal is represented by a darker yellow than the rest of your health bar. Lethal damage does not regenerate, though some of it can be regained through healing items, which are  very rare. Non-lethal damage does regenerate, however, but slowly.

The game features a mostly realistic physics system, where being careless can cause you to trip or be knocked down, sometimes dealing damage upon hitting the ground (theoretically). This also allows your enemy to get multiple hits on you, which can get you killed quickly. You can manipulate many objects in the game; though it is typically not necessary, you may need to do so to reach an item or a door.

The game is level-based, though your character is not saved between levels unless you enable early checkpoints in the options menu. This is recommended if you are looking for a more rewarding system of gameplay, as nothing you do will matter if you die without reaching a checkpoint (the next level).

Armor and weapons go up significately in tear as you progress. Eventually your armor, with its unique layering system, will negate all non-lethal damage, and your weapons will do much more damage. Weapons will do more damage based on how much armor the other person is wearing. Damage is dealt based on what part of the body the weapon strikes, and with what part of the weapon the body is struck.

There is an arena mode with two difficulties to go alongside with the main game, where you simply engage in one-on-one combat against many stages of enemies, each one pitting you against an increasingly more difficult and well-armored enemy. There are two arena types: novice and expert. I recommend you complete both to get a feel for the combat before entering the main game.

GRAPHICS

This game does look quite nice, and does not require a very good computer to run. The lighting is realistic, adding to the overall sense of immersion. There isn't much else to say about this category, really.

CONTROLS

The controls for this game will definitely take some getting used to. The game features a unique muscle-system, where turning with your swing will do much more damage than a normal swing. Movement can be controlled with WASD, or with the mouse.

In combat mode, you always face the direction of your pointer, and movement is relative to it as well. This will take some getting used to for a new player, but eventually it will seem natural. Ducking allows for you to dodge the enemy's attack (most of the time). You can parry the weapon by moving the pointer in the direction the attack is coming from.

POLISHING

This game feels very polished, and was programmed very well. Good job, developers!

RATING AND FINAL REVIEW

I would like to give this game a rating of 9/10. It is an amazing experience, though I would like to express my thoughts on the need of a better saving-system. I feel as if the current one is too challenging, but very rewarding. However, people may still turn away from the game because of its challenge. Great work on this game, Bare Mettle Entertainment! It is a great experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You're not your sword.

You're not the armor you wear.

You're not the contents of your inventory.

This is your own unique fight, and there's not gonna be a same one, even if you wanted. You create it. With each painful grunt, with each measured strike, with each desperate sidestep. This is a game that puts YOU above everything else when the swords start swinging. ''A fool with a stick can beat a halberdier in plate armor, if the fool is the right one.'' Your skill is the only thing that counts here.  If you are smart, if you have patience, if you 'd like a game with practically limitless strategy and possibilities, then, and only then, buy this.

It is slowly turning into a very interesting arena fighting game, with its unique combat system. There is a dungeon-crawling campaign also, but everyone loves the arena, very fun and addicting. I personally never give a flying rat's ♥♥♥ about multiplayer in games, but in this case i am very curious to see how multiplayer is gonna work out. The developers are cool dudes and listen to the community, taking smart decisions so far and working hard on the updates. They are few, but they are juicy. The updates, not the devs. And yes, this game exists just to make funds for Sui Generis, the next big title from Bare Mettle Entertainement. And you know what? I'm fine with that! I wish all cash grab games were of this quality! Keep it up, can't wait to see what's next!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima's biggest virtue is the physics based combat system, but besides that there's a huge amount of detail went into pretty much everything and the overall quality of the game is top notch, especially for a $15 indie game.

+Challenging roguelike gameplay
+Everything is physics based
+Unique combat system; once you get the hang of it it's really satisfying
+Detailed armour system: Not the usual helmet / chest piece / gloves / boots system, my character currently wears 11 pieces of armour from top to bottom (don't know what's the max number you can wear), and a piece of armour only protects the part of your body that it actually covers
+Large dungeons to explore, find secrets and hidden loot
+Dark, creepy atmosphere
+Pretty graphics and lighting, the sound effects are great, too
+Complex enemy AI
+Runs very well

+/-Story: you wake up in a dungeon with no explanation whatsoever, you have to find clues to piece it together for yourself and unravel the mystery (it's a huge positive in my book, but I know some people prefer a more direct narrative)
+/-You have to spend some time on practicing the physics based combat or you won't be able to defeat the first enemy you meet (by no means a negative either)

-(As most of the negative reviews pointed out) the controls need some getting used to, the camera controls/movement could be improved a bit

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Running down a corridor away from an enemy, threw a chair down, he tripped I proceeded to bash in his head with my 2x4

10/10







In all seriousness, this game is an absolute gem. It is SO different than anything I have ever played and that's what makes it so great.

This game can be and is very challenging and if you're the type to get frustrated easily this is not the game for you, but if you like a challenging game with fun game mechanics then this is the game for you.

The game will take some getting used to at first, get a feel for the controls and the combat; the best way is to either go straight into arena or have a go at fighting some of the first enemies you see until you get the hang of the combat.

The combat is absolutely the best thing about this game and when you first play it you might be thinking, this is clunky and hard to control. but later when you get the feel for it you'll realise that you can do so much.

You can interrupt enemies with large 2h weapons by charging them and preventing them from finishing the swing, or force them into an environment where it is too narrow or full of obstacles, all which you could have set up in preparation for the fight.

The game almost feels like a survival horror Dungeon crawler.

In a world where game variety seems to be dwindling, games are just being cloned or merged into one super category and being stupidly dumbed down; it's indie developers like this that give me hope for the gaming industry.

Why are you still reading? You need this game in your life.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My god the combat is satisfying slice crunch topple enemies (and vice versa!) with sword, metal bar or any object somewhat resembling a stick. Expect to spend few hours learning the physics based system which starts out as a drunken swordmanship simulator. The practise mode against toughening opponents is perfect fun for getting the gist of the combat. Afterwards you want to come back and see just with how little equipment you can manage get through the gauntlet.

Assumedly there's still a lot more content coming, even though you can spend days in the story mode alone, as it is. The game is unforgiving but fair, which really adds to the satisfaction of killing and surviving the opponents. Truly, introducing sledgehammer to your opponent's head has never been this satisfying, as some other reviewer put it. The graphics are bleak and sharp and I enjoyed the aesthetics very much indeed.

The game crashes seldomly, however, you can always return to the exact point of the crash, so nothing is lost in the process. And I have to start the game on fresh boot to get good framerate at times. Still, all this is meaningless to the freshness and quality of approach presented.

Isometric medieval combat has just been redefined. In my books this is a masterpiece already.

This is why we buy indy games! Sometimes they'll actually do something different.
I woke up in a dungeon room clueless. Trying to figure out the controls, I started kicking around a box. I realized this game was something special when I tripped on the box and fell on my face. That happens in real life, but never in video games.
Combat is also different. Axes can get snagged on a shield, a missed swing and you'll harmlessly elbow your opponent. It's like watching two renaissance fair dorks play combat rather than video game characters hack and slash. A fun laugh, but a challenging experiance when you actually try it.
It has a very steep learning curve I'm not sure most Steam gamers can get passed. Gamers that have trained with fencing, larping, weapon martial arts, or even any sport will get this faster than others. The game requires the gamer to patient, mature, and deductive with phyical combat and not just button mash give up and call the game stupid.
Kudos to game dev that think outside the box!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is a game that I've been looking for for years. Ever since I played the original Mount and Blade I'd been craving a skill based, brutal, single player (or coop) experience and Exanima delivers in spades. But it doesn't stop with just that either. Exanima doesn't hold your hand, but it also doesn't leave you wondering what to do. This is  a game that forces you to pay attention, that makes you slow down and really take in the world around you. One time I couldn't find a key to open a door, it turned out that the key was on the floor under a table, where it landed when the zombie I'd just smashed with my axe slammed into said table and knocked the key down. I walked right past that key probably 10 times because I was still in Skyrim mode, waiting for my quest marker to show me where to go and what to do.

Everything in this game is controlled by physics, They can be picked up, rotated, placed with precision even to the point of building things like bridges over chasms and other physics based puzzles... or just throwing a chair in the way of your enemies to make them trip before clubbing them from on high like baby seals.

The combat is unique and amazing and hillarious and brutal. It may be the first game I've ever played where people watching me play, grunt and OOOoohhhh" when I wrap my long sword around the back of someone's head with a sickening smack and watch them fold under the weight of the blade. It's probably the only time I've paid full price for a game on steam. And it's definitely the only time I've wanted to pay more JUST to support the development.

If you have the stones to step up and learn a new way to play games and the hard headedness to keep at it through more than a few painful losses early on then you're going to love Exanima and you'll never be able to go back."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here is a video I made that shows how this game works:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Nal3uxhkcg&feature=youtu.be

This game is very unique first off.  It is NOT at all your average or typical dungeon crawler.

You don't play Exanima running through mashing buttons to do different wild attacks and mad collecting every piece of loot.  You just don't.  This is a game made where you wake up in an unknown dungeon location (although it's the same map and dungeon every game right now, no procedural generation).  You quickly discover that the controls are vastly different from every other dungeon crawling game you have ever played.

To move the easiest way is to stop trying to use WASD period.  Instead put your cursor on the screen the direction you want to move (regardless of which way you currently face) and then hold down the right mouse button.  To walk, put the cursor a little distance from your character.  To move faster, simply move the cursor further away from your character.  It takes a little getting used to and feels quite satisfying once you familiarize yourself with it.  You can use the WASD keys to move but they work differently depending on if you are in combat or just exploring.  In combat they move closer to what we are used to springing your character in the direction forward, left, backwards, or right for W, A, S, and D respectively.  (This is according to the direction you face)  In exploration mode, the A and D key rotate your character around 360 degrees in a circle, W moves you a step forward, and D takes a step back.

Any item that is light enough in weight to be moved by your character realistically can be dragged or moved.  For example if you find a board lying on the ground, pick it up by first moving your character close to it then putting your cursor on it and holding down the left mouse button.  Now you'll see the board picked up from the ground in the air.  You can now use WASD to rotate the board along different axis's.  Drop it in the position you have it rotated in by letting go of the left mouse button.  If the item is an item that can be used a weapon or armor, then you can equip it or put it in your inventory by pressing the I key for inventory" on your keyboard.  This opens a window that shows your character and a space for your inventory.  To equip it
date: drag it to your avatars picture in the window
recommended: and to place it in your inventory
hoursPlayed: drag it to the area below your character.\n\nCombat is this games bright spot.  It looks VERY real.  The movements and lunges your character makes are very
voteText: very believable and doesn't look anything like any of these dungeon crawlers I've ever played.  So if you are expecting Diablo or God of War combat here
helpfulPercent: this may not be the game for you.  That ain't happening here no matter how skilled you become.  Timing and movement are key in combat as well as your positioning.  Simply hit the TAB key to alternate between combat and normal modes.  Now in combat mode
votesHelpful: your cursor will change to a red icon and you drag the cursor  the direction you want to swing any equipped weapon by holding down the left mouse button and dragging.  But this isn't a game where you want to spam attacks as quickly as you can.  This is more timing and accurate paths made by you to attack when your enemy is 'open' to an attack.  If you swing at the wrong time
votesTotal: you'll leave your character open to an attack that could get you killed.  If you have a shield
votesFunny: simply do nothing but make sure you face your enemy and your character will do the best he/she can to block any attacks with their shield.\n\nI have not even come close to mastering the combat enough to feel confident in starting the exploration of the games dungeon yet.  Thankfully

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It being in Alpha and all... all I gotta say is....YES

This game is ogiginal. Something fresh. The combat is fantastic. It is literally drunken peasent UFC. The fist fights are awesome. I like going into a duel with just my fist and my enemy has a sword. I then proceed to juke and jive, float like a butter fly and knock their block off. It is diablo mixed with mount and blade.

The learning curve is tough at first because its such a different take on an isometric action RPG. There is blood and gore. The Arena mode is great and very challenging. The main game has a Dark Souls feel to it, excellent immersion. Each update makes it that much better. Combat is going to get better! Its already a 8 outta 10. You cant spam attacks here you have to counter attack, perry, dodge, wait for an opening and go for it. Nothing is more satisfying that dropping a hammer on an opponents face and watching them crumble into a broken pile. Steal their armor and move on.

Arena-
Its a skeleton right now, but it has the frame work of something truely great and could stand on its own. When multiplayer is added this will be insane. 5 man fist fights in a bar with full physics. I got punched over a table and still won the fight!

-You create a character, add basic gear.

-Good variety of Melee weapons that actually have unique flow. You have to practice with each one. You get good with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ two handed sword...well you might suck with a cleaver and shield. Timing, balance, length, and weight all impact the fight....never seen a game do this to this level.

-You pay a fee to enter one of many types of fights.

-You win money and buy better weapons and gear for your fighter. You can get new fighters and have a team.

-If your last fighter dies...then you are done. Restart. Game over.

-Fist fights, Frays (5 man last man standing match), gauntlets, Duels, Challengers, and many more to come. There are several arenas now, the furniture and the items on the tables are fully moveable. Nothing like knocking an enemy back and them tripping over a chair knocking the table over throwing plates, glasses, and other items everywhere.

-You have a full team base for your team. It isnt fully added but you can see the leve of detail coming.

Campaign-
-Create your character
-Start out with nothing. You wake up in a creepy dungeon. Everything is bound to the physics engine.
-Mindless zombie dudes with good AI are everywhere. You can put buckets over an enemy's head. You can find loot every where. Weapons, armor, keys, notes, scrolls, potions.... and you actually have to find them. They are blinking, you have to find it and drag it to your inventory.
-Dark creepy atmosphere
-Light matters
-Plan your moves and attacks. Get a zombie to attack you and lead them to other calm zombies and they will fight him for you.
-Demons
-Skeletons
-Portals
-Great Dark Fantasy elements. You feel tension the entire time and its great. You know how easy it is to get maimed and die....then its permadeath.
-Level up, get perks
-THIS IS JUST ALPHA AND ITS BETTER THAT MOST RPGS on steam.


Get it....if the developers continue with what they are doing we are looking at a game changer...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stream of consciousness starting... now

I've been gaming for thirty plus years and never felt compelled to advocate a game before now.

The combat in this game is phenomenal.  Perhaps even revolutionary.

While I rejoice in this game's creation, I despair that the control scheme will be too intimidating for some, and that they will not be able to appreciate the depth of the mechanics therein.  If you enjoy Skyrim, but find the combat sorely lacking and unbalanced... if you think Dark Souls is great because of the relatively challenging combat... I strongly recommend Exanima.  Not only for the experience itself but for the support you'll be giving the dev team as they work on Sui Generis, for which Exanima is a prelude.

I can't remember looking forward to a game as much as I am Sui Generis.

I can't muster enough praise for what Madoc and the Bare Mettle team have done here.

While additions and enhancements are still being made, the Exanima campaign in and of itself is nothing to write home about.  I personally found a lot of the exploration to be tedious.  Some will disagree with me but the game desperately needs some automapping.  There's a bunch of crap lying around, and if you don't use a guide you'll wonder how much of it you have to sort and sift through to find everything.

However, all of these complaints pale when viewed in light of what should be the focus here... the great combat mechanics and dynamic environment in general.  I really hope this game succeeds and other developers use the game engine to make their own games, because there are so many possibilities.

The arena mode in this game is worth the price alone.  You'll struggle with the novice arena first, gradually getting a hang of the controls and gradually progressing through the ranks.  You'll come to the first shield bearer and get frustrated with how hard he is to hit.  By then you'll be hooked, and your skills will only increase and finally you will beat the arena and move on to the expert one.  And if you're like me, you'll do it all over again and again because it's so cool and fun to try with different weapons and playstyles.

TLDR - The coordination required for the controls might deter some, but if you can handle that and are looking for fresh physics-based combat mechanics, pick up this game and keep an eye out for Sui Generis.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is an extremely underrated RPG-esque dungeon crawler with less on the idea of acquiring loot and more on the idea of progressing and trying to stay alive.

PHYSICS Let me just start off by saying that the physics in this game are absolutely jaw-dropping, and easily (in my opinion) puts Grand Theft Auto V's physics to shame. Don't be fooled, the physics are no gimmick! The game heavily revolves around the realisticness of you, the other NPC's movement and the environment around you. If you were to run into a piece of rock on the ground then you are very likely to trip up and smash your face in.

COMBAT The combat, again, relies heavily on the physics. It will require your complete attention, a good deal of practise, and a tiny bit of patience. It is not easy, but it is not badly made. How you perform in combat depends on the individual that is playing. Great fun.

GRAPHICS The game is incredibly good looking, and can be run on its highest settings on most machines. The environment and its inhabitants are extremely detailed for a game of its size.  Also, the lighting is perfect, this game can be very dark, and with a nice warm flickering torch in your hand you can truly appreciate the shadows that this game offers.

SOUND One of my favourite features of this game would probably be the sound, if you were to hit a certain material (primarily metal and wood) against another object it will create its appropriate noise. If your sword accidentally gets dragged against a wall as you're walking by then it will create a fantastic scraping sound to accompany it. If you bang a bit of wood against somebodies helmet then you'll get a nice thud to go along with it. The music is haunting and can set a sense of isolation, though you will probably hear that same music during your whole playthrough.

INTERACTION So we know that the physics affect your movement and combat, but it also affects your interaction with the environment. You will need to use your cursor to open doors, lift items such as crates to look underneath them for anything of use and physically pick up and drop things into your inventory, straight off of the floor. It is very identical to the Amnesia series in this sense, and it works very well. But you are not limited to just opening doors and searching for items, eventually you will be given a series of puzzles which will require you to use whatever objects around you to advance to the next room, objects including chairs, planks and small rocks.

Now that we have all of the technical stuff out of the way, what is the game itself actually like? What is it about?

Imagine this, you awake in a large room lying on your face, you get up to find a flaming torch in the centre, equip it and venture off into the pitch black corridors, probably unarmed. In this dungeon-like setting you will encounter other neutral but wary humanoids like yourself. Are they hostile?" You'll be thinking to yourself

hoursPlayed: maneuver around them and you should both get away unscathed.\n\nYou are given one life in this game. Yes

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: I backed this game back in 2012 and have followed it ever since. I have played many earlier versions, and have many more hours of game time than what my steam time implies.

A prelude to a game called Sui Generis (yet to be released), Exanima is an excellent dungeon crawler with a stellar combat system.

Using real physics as the basis, the combat in the game is hugely dynamic and skill reliant. Though the mechanics are simple to understand, there is a deep level of complexity involved in it. You have to aim each swing and each parry, you have to provide power and speed by rotating your character, and gracefully dodge your enemies strikes. It is a difficult system to master, one which requires some patience, but is infinitely rewarding once you get it right. It's unlike anything I have previously played, and a breath of fresh air in the RPG genre. The combat (at the point of writing this review) is still not feature complete, with additional combat manouvers, ranged combat and level system on its way. Despite this, it feels very much complete.

The underworld in Exanima provides a tense and mysterious atmosphere, one which drives you to explore and wonder what awaits around each corner. It is a grim and dark place, set in a low fantasy setting. The game tells its story through the environment, books, parchments. Your character seemingly having lost his memory, it's up to you to piece everything together. It is much like what is seen in the Souls series in this regard, at least thus far.

It is a difficult game. Wether you test your might in the progressive arena mode or venture through the dungeon, the game will surely pose a challenge. And like any difficult game, it features serrious consequences for mistakes. Taking hard blows, or being cut by slashing weapons may leave you with permanent damage. The only way to heal this back up is by using a very rare potion that there only exist a few of in the dungeon, assuming you have the wit to search and find them in the first place. And if you die in the dungeon, thats it. You'll have to start over. Though it can be frutrating at times, it is this fact that makes the experience of progressing so rewarding.

The game treats you as a person with intelligence and willingness to learn, each victory and discovery is earned by you and not given to you. This is a refreshing feeling, since nowadays games mostly treat you as a fragile kid that needs everything fed to him with a spoon. Exanima aims to against this trend, which it very much succeeds in doing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is really something else; I haven't wanted to stop playing since I picked it up. The physics and object interaction is great; whether it's tripping someone up by slinging rogue furniture in their path, or just taking a moment to appreciate the defensive boon one gains by wearing a wooden bucket on their head. The combat is intuitive(although the learning curve is steep) and it feels really satisfying to land a good blow. The maps are sprawling and winding, and navigation falls to strict use of the compass and a journal to make notes- an appreciation for the old school. The gear...I love the gear. From armor to weapons, there are a lot of different things(and variants of those things) for you to sort through to find what caters to your style. The armor all feels very appropriate, too. It's not flashy, over the top 'let your buttcheeks breathe' armor- It's dungeon armor. It is also worth noting that your character tumbling about and falling over when you intentionally run them into clutter is just about the funniest damn thing on the planet.

So throw on your several layers of jerkin, decide whether you want a morning star or a battle axe, and get ready to get your ♥♥♥ kicked all the way to the top. This game is great, you really ought to give it a shot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: This is an Alpha 0,5,3 Review, and the key was provided to me for review purposes.
OverviewExanima is a dungeon crawler exploration game with a very unique approach to combat and gameplay, which is both good and bad, depending on your preferences. The world is NOT procedurally generated, and structured on levels. It features perma-death, and this unforgiving nature of the game forces the player to exercise extreme caution, as every wrong decision could have devastating results.

Before we begin:Note that this game is still in Alpha, and there is no way of knowing how the game will change over time. If I notice anything that might alter the review, I will try my best to edit it accordingly. These points are what I think of the current state of the game, and you will see shortly that a pro/cons list is very hard to put together because of the controversy. Some might like an aspect, some would say it's a deal breaker. As such, I have written these from my perspective. Feel free to move them around the list as you please.

The Pros:Beautiful Graphics - It's clear that the developers put together the graphical system first, and worry about the gameplay aspects after. The game looks beautiful, the atmosphere is tense, the lighting system accurate and realistic, the objects are detailed and physics-enabled. Engine wise, this game is pretty well polished.

Suspenseful Environment - Due to the fact that this game is permanent death, and most of the dungeon is shrouded in darkness, exploring the labyrinth is really exciting. My eyes are constantly jumping across the screen, trying to observe if it is safe or not. The sound of footsteps, squeaking doors and the flickering light of your torch create a creepy vibe that resembles that of a horror game.

Physics Based Combat - One of the main features of this game is the combat system. All weapons and armor have realistic stats that reflect how useful they are to you. Things such as body coverage, resistance to different types of attacks, and how good a weapon is at conveying a certain type of swing, such as slashing, crushing and so on put you make you really consider what you are wielding. Also, everything has mass. You are inflicting damage based on how, where and when you hit the enemy, and the animations are realistic and unique because they are not predetermined motions hard-coded by the developer, they are actual physics simulations.

Hand Crafted World - Something that really bothered me on other games, like Torchlight or Diablo, was that the dungeons were so architecturally unrealistic. Not here. Here, everything has a purpose. It is clear what rooms serve what function, everything is beautifully furnished and equipped, and you can discern sleeping quarters, kitchens, forges, lumber stations, interior gardens, studies, storage rooms and the such. You feel like you are actually exploring a working, used to be living-in and used castle.
The Cons:Unintuitive and hard to master Combat - Moving is relative to the character instead of the camera, and the physics based combat is really hard to master. Prepare to die often. I would suggest entering the Arena mode before attempting to play the main game. You will see what I mean. It's hard to put into words, but the combat is unnecessarily difficult, even if you get the realistic physics, the way you move and the inputs required are unintuitive and a bit too much.

Forced Permanent Death - Many hard-core gamers would see this as a challenge and enjoy it, though combined with the horribly hard to master combat system and movement scheme make it too hard. I've often times found myself not exploring parts of the map because I was afraid of well equipped enemies. It's true, this makes the player think before acting, and encourages a stealthy approach, and I appreciate that, however an option to disable it and use some kind of sensible save system would be greatly needed.

Arena Mode Levels - In arena mode, you can test your mettle and practice combat, but it is structured on levels, and is permanent death as well. So, for instance, say I beat the first three levels, but the fourth enemy is hard to beat. If I die, I have to redo the first three levels again! And lost health is not restored after winning a battle (only the temporary damage is restored). So it's very hard to get to a higher level and practice tougher enemies, which is exactly what you want to do in the first place.

No Random Map Mode - Not really as bothered by this one, as I've listed the detail put into the map in the pros, but if you take into account the fact you'll most probably die many times, you will be forced to replay the same map over and over again, where every item's location is known (except containers, which are randomised), and the path you need to take is also known. I would like to see a random map mode where you can face a new challenge each time.
ConclusionIf you're wondering whether or not you want to purchase this game, here is my advice. Buy only if you want to support development. While I must admit I see great potential in this game and the developers have made a great job thus far, I am generally against Early Access Titles. It is a great game and a greater challenge to face, and you WILL get frustrated by its difficulty at least a few times, but bear in mind - it's still Alpha.

If you liked this review or want to see more of my recommended games, you can view my reviews here, and be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima. The game where everything I've ever wanted from a game came true.
What's Exanima? It's a masterpiece put together with great attention to detail.

Beware: this is not your ordinary isometric dungeon crawler, it's much more. For starters: everything is physics based. Attacks, momentum, part of your weapon that hits the enemy and part of the enemy you hit matters.

The game doesn't feel Early Acess except for the fact that is really short. The variety of items and weapons makes it really suitable for almost every playstyle. The equip regions make sense and are solid. The looting feels great and organic. The combat, while is really hard and has a steep learning curve, it's one of the main things that make this game great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, so I've played enough of this game to make a profound review on it.
This is a physics based combat, it means that animations are not premade and your character is basically a puppet with strings which you pull to make it move. In this game the combat feels like there is actually depth to it, like you are actually hitting something, which is a cause of great sound effects and responsive movement to hits and the environment. You can suffer fatal wounds (red bar) or stamina damage (dark yellow bar) fatal wounds can't be regenerated unless you find a rare blue potion (salve) which regenerates your wounds.
You wear armor in layers which is heavily inspired from the late middle ages, for example:
(Gabeson < Leather Tunic < Breast Plate). Each armor has protective abilities against all sorts of damage values: slash, crash, pierce, impact (which is the weight of the weapon and it's momentum capabilities), weight and also encumbrance (how uncomfortable your armor is to wear).

The game currently has 3 distinct modes, practice, arena and story.
PRACTICE - In practice you choose gear from the startup menu and practice your abilities of combat, this is the first mode you are ought to play, because this game is very hard at first. The practice is made out of novice arena and expert arena, after you beat both you can either advance to story mode or advance to Arena.

ARENA - In this mode you find your self in a room with 2 boards, (Character Management and the Matches Menu)
In character managment you can customize your character with feats which you acquire with exp and gear which you buy from the store (I will get to that later), in addition you can also recruit additional player characters and npc hirelings who can fight either alone or with you in various matches.
The other board is your matches menu, in which you fight your way through random opponents who are divided to ranks  in which you progress as you level up, the higher the rank the better the gear. The opponents are also divided to tiers, the higher the tier the better he fights.
Tiers and Ranks are divided to: inept, aspirant, novice, adept, expert and master. What you can wear as aspirant you can't wear as inept, but what you can wear as inept you can wear as aspirant. To enter matches you are required to put a fee first, if you win you will get the winning reward which is way higher than the fee you put in first but you also have to be risky, if you lose, not only you are risking to lose your character completely, but also to lose valuable money.

Store - In the store you buy your gear with the money you earned from the matches. Currently at the time of this review the high rank gear is somewhat expensive and requires a big amount of grinding.

STORY - Now, also one of the strong points of this game is the story mode, in which you are dumped into a dungeon with only a torch and basic clothes. In the dungeon you will find parchments and books which which give you information about the lore, the dungeon and the story behind it. You will learn from this game to piece things together, and not only getting your information from readable sources, but also from looking at the architecture, the state of the undead which are at the dungeon, their clothing and etc. Think of the story like a piece of art you need to decypher. Also some of the undead at the dungeon are friendly and are not going to fight you on sight, but if you make a suspicious movement, (running, combat mode, or getting too near them) they will attack you.

TLDR - This is an amazing piece of a game, I highy recommend it to everyone who likes
rogue-like games and medieval combat. The learning curve is steep and you are going to spend a lot of time learning the game, but when you do learn the combat mechanics you are going to have a blast.
I wrote my review like a guide so you are free to read it when you feel lost. If you have further questions you can ask me, I've finished all what this game has to offer untill now so I think I can answer most questions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't beaten this game yet. It's sort-of Roguelike, very tricky, but pretty fun.

You make a weak peon and subject them to the horrific trials of you trying to figure out how to play, getting beaten up by goons and tripping over beds and boxes, occasionally getting a meager kit together and then dying shortly after.

Exanima sort of plays like Baldur's Gate or something, but the game is a bit more bleak. A little like Dark Souls in tone. The combat is really the highlight of the game, because it's one of the most unique features. It's strongly physics-based and each character has a system of balance and musculature.

You have a couple of basic attacks, which doesn't sound like a lot, but there is a lot of skill in just how well you execute them. The weapons have very precise damage zones, and won't work well if you get the attack wrong. For example, a polearm with a hook on the end has to hit with the hook. Otherwise you will hit the enemy with the handle and it won't do anything. The fights are often different and unique, and occasionally you can stumble on something and fall over in a fight, letting your enemy clobber you easily. Despite having only some basic swings, fights feel very free-form, and often extremely chaotic. Sometimes things go wrong and you get punished.

The levels are big, and fairly difficult. I had to watch some youtube videos to figure out what I was supposed to do. The game basically doesn't hold your hand at all. It offers a one-time warning of its difficulty.

So I guess it won't be for everyone, but it's a pretty original game in my opinion, definitely worth playing for fans of the dungeon-crawl genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I absolutely HATE this game. It's too hard.

I'm scared - I am literally holed up in a room, fearful for my life. I'm getting a bit adjusted to the darkness, and my torch helps me some. I've found a number a weapons and managed to find something to use as a shield. Where am I? Why am I here? Who wrote this note? Who are these creatures that pursue me. My cuts hurt, I'm out of breath and scared. Oh God make it stop. I can't be alone like this... Is there no hope?

For real though; this is perhaps the most unique game I've ever played. It's a cross between Baldur's Gate, Skyrim, Surgeon Simulator, and - wait for it - Dark Souls. You will die. You will die again. You will rage quit. You will come back.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Already incredible.  I think it'd be easy to write this off as an interesting tech-demo, something cool, but ultimately too flakey and hilarious to be taken seriously.
- Think again - you'll start out looking like a drunken fool stumbling around, but put in a day or two learning and practicing, and it starts to click.  What you'll find is a game that is mechanically incredibly deep, where you can and will learn to shift your weight, anticipate and avoid attacks, follow through on a swing to clip someone in the back of the leg, lunge into someone to push them over a chair before smashing them with an overhead blow.  It quickly starts to feel very natural, and incredibly well balanced.
I know a little of dynamics simulation, and I'm truly astounded by what Bare Mettle have achieved here.  To make it functional would be impressive, to have made it feel natural is beyond my comprehension!

My only wish would be to have it a little more traditional RPG - with dialogue and varied locations, rather than what it appears to be at the moment - a pure labyrinth dungeon-crawl.  A stunningly beautiful one - the lighting and attention to detail is sublime, but exploring does start to get a touch repetitive.
(Edit: I just realised that Exanima is a prelude" to Sui Generis

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm torn on how to recommend this game after this new (beta) update.  The story mode/dungeon is still abysmal, and many of the below complaints become magnfied by the narrow confines and questionable design choices of that mode.  However, the arena.... this is where this game shows  promise.  The mechanics of the game are far better suited for this type of game mode, however since most are buying for Story Mode, it's hard to recommend.

The new arena mode (in beta right now) is much better than the previous iterations.  Persistent character combined with progression (that needs tweaking) as well as a in-game shop, new arena matches (including a 6 man FFA), NPCs that you can recruit...all of this adds much needed depth and content to the most enjoyable part of the game.

Be warned : this game is difficult to learn.  The control/camera system is unlike anything you've played, some say unique, some say downright clunky/broken.  Death is permanent, a lot of progress can be lost.  There is NO mapping feature.  You will get lost.  You will get frustrated.  There are no saves, only checkpoints that are few and far between.  If you want very different combat system and an arena combat type game - I recommend this.   If you want an enjoyable dungeon crawl RPG ...I would do some more research.  You might be disappointed.  Also, the community is filled with hardcore cheerleaders/fanboys/kickstarter backers who will defend EVERY mechanic with religious fervor.  The Devs make no bones about it, your opinion, if its not in line with their 'creative vision', is not wanted, and is in fact, meaningless.

Summary of negatives

-You will die many, many times adjusting the camera during a fight because of the wonky system they have in place where your mouse cursor's location is what you use to turn and face your character.

-If you get too close to a wall, camera will go to a top-down view, rather than turn the wall transparent like other isometric games, which can really screw up your ability to attack/parry/dodge

-Swinging weapons feels wrong. You don't need to throw your entire body into swinging a sword. It's not realistic, I could handle a sword better IRL. Even after 10 beers. Your character displays no finesse or dexterity whatsoever, he swings all his weapons as if they're a 30 pound baseball bat, many times spinning around or ending up wildly out of position because the game engine requires you to use movement/footwork in order to enhance the strength of your blows.

-movement in combat (dash / walk) is sluggish and unresponsive. Your character behaves as if he is fighting in a swamp wearing 200 lbs of armour (regardless of whether you're actually wearing armour)

-Blocking is done automatically and really feels broken. Many times the AI will swing right over/under your parry, some times right through it.

-Overhand strikes are incredibly slow. These are also the only decent way to hit an opponent who has been knocked to the ground, but you will miss more often than not due to abysmal aiming system and terrible control of your character. Inputs are just so exaggerated and lagged to give any real feeling of precision in combat

-Dungeon mode is boring and dreary. Same map every time. Mobs roam, sure, but many spawn in the same spots and don't move until you open the door they're standing behind.

-Loot is limited to armour, weapons, clothing.  The game tries to follow a realistic medieval gear system.  Keep that in mind, this is not Diablo by any stretch of the imagination.  Armour is incredibly valuable for your survivability, and it is not easy to come by at first.

-no map, terrain all looks the same, so unless you are blessed with an incredible direction sense/memory, be prepared to continually retrace your steps until you cave and google the homemade maps people uploaded (yes, they had to make their own maps using graph paper)...or you straight up memorize the lay out of the 3 current levels. You are provided with a compass, and nothing else currently.  This is a major issue for me, I absolutely hate wandering aimlessly through the same areas over and over because I just can't tell where I've been and where I haven't.

-no voice acting, no cinematics. It consists of finding scrolls, books, letters. Story is told in bits and pieces as you explore.

-very little in the way of options and customization

-can't save your game, though every level does have a check point system now, which only came after a large vocal outcry when the game first released. Ironically, requests for a system for saves were met with derision and condescension (Maybe this game isn't for you." / "Go play another game.") by the Insider Kickstarter Elitists.

-devs and staunch defenders of this game will constantly defend game flaws as "realism"
hoursPlayed: "hardcore"
voteText: "challenging" when in reality they're just defending bad design choices and wonky mechanics because they've played the game for a year and have "grown used to it". Suggestions for different control schemes / camera options are met with "We tried it. Didn't work. End of discussion."\n\nThe best way to describe the current system

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is the prelude to a game in development called Sui Generis. It is the result of a successful Kickstarter campaign. While Exanima is mainly a dungeon crawler, Sui Generis is the full blown RPG. It is an RPG with a very unique combat and movement system and also features a realistic physics engine which effects every object in the world. Every movement is generated real-time. It can be fun, frustrating, challenging and very rewarding all at the same time. If you're sick of the old hack n slash, click, click, click, attack, kick, block gameplay then this may be a game for you. It requires patience, careful mouse control, intelligence and diligence to succeed.


It is fun playing in the arena with a mate/s (IRL) switching player after each death. The difficulty is on the difficult side for a lot of players these days. It reminds one of videogames during the 80s only with incredible graphics.
I recommend starting in the arena to try combat before starting a new game. Winning your first fight is a rush. After each fight you can loot the NPC body and take clothing, armour and weapons. Some loot can vastly improve your survivability.
There are saves in the game (to a point). Finishing all opponents in the novice arena will permanently unlock access to the expert arena. In the dungeon however you must finish the entire game using one life unless you check the Early Checkpoints box in the options. Early checkpoints will save after completing each level, enabling restarting a level.

The physics engine effects can make for some very interesting, funny, unique and spectacular moments. Your character (and NPCs) can trip over objects in the world. Objects like tables, chairs and other debris all collide realistically. A fight in a room crowded with objects will usually result in objects being knocked over and flung around all over the place. Picking up objects and placing them carefully can be used to build traps or obstacles for the NPCs to trip over and make themselves vulnerable to attack.

The mouse cursor controls where your torso faces, WASD control your movement and left-click and hold to attack. Dragging the mouse over the opponent while using good footwork to put power into your attacks. Right click is used to move your character in the direction of the cursor outside of combat.
Defense is controlled automatically (to an extent). Place the cursor over the direction the attack is coming from to attempt to block it. Attacks that have enough force can still hurt whether you block it or not. A lot of the time avoiding an attack by stepping away is an all round better idea. The speed, angle, force and range of the weapon attacks will affect how much damage is inflicted during attacks.
Movement during fights is controlled with WASD and can be used to great effect to increase power during attacks. Be careful though, bad footwork will throw you off balance and possibly cause your character to stumble or fall over completely. The movement is also cursor relative. It can take some getting used to. With the cursor on the enemy, pressing W will move you toward the enemy, S will move you away, A and D will sidestep.

Finding items can require a keen eye at times. There is no help given for finding items. YOU have to see them and click on them to pick them up. Sometimes this will require moving objects to search underneath objects or move things to gain access to a door.
A lot of reviews have made some very harsh criticisms of the controls. While I do not have a problem with them overall, they could use some fine tuning. It is not an easy game to pick up and play. Lazy or bad use of the controls can make your character appear drunk if not done correctly.
This game uses OpenGl instead of DirectX, some users have had problems running the game. This issue should be reported and a crashlog posted to get the issue fixed.

The graphics are brilliant thanks to good use of textures, lighting and colour palette. It looks super realistic. Remarkably they have accomplished this all using very little VRAM resources. Minimum specs to run it are a 512MB GPU.




List of features confirmed to be added to Sui Generis include:

New weapons
LAN multiplayer
Persistant multiplayer
Stealth
Stamina
Thaumaturgy (Magic)
Dismemberment
Object destruction
NPC groups
Skills progression (WIP)
Special moves
Fire
Water
Dynamic music
Animals
Trading

UPDATE 0.5.3 REVIEW

Words cannot express how I feel about this game, and I have the deepest desire to play through it again and again.
This is the game ive wanted for years, this is the game I wanted so badly, and Dark Souls was the closest thing to this game and now this game is here and I have no more desire to play Dark Souls, a game I binged on for days at a time.
The combat in this game was frustrating and hard to learn, luckily they have the arena mode which really does help get over the major struggles of learning the combat in a permadeath situation.



Pros

-Very hard, yet learnable combat.
The core combat of this game is fairly simple, left click on the side of your character to swing from that side, WASD controls your character while in combat mode, W being forward of your character at all times and not the top of the screen, double left click to do an overhead, hold left click to continue swinging after you have already swung. Your character will automatically block or parry so long as you arent swinging and the attack is blockable from where youre facing and where the attack is coming from. The autoblock in this game allows you to focus on offense, instead of thinking about press mouse2 to block right before he swings". Its second nature to your character to block

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played Exanima for many hours since Alpha. The Arena itself is great fun, as the technology behind the game is very innovative. The dungeon crawling is atmospheric and immersive.

The combat system might feel a bit intimidating at first, because the controls are so different and the physics a bit unpredictable (compared to other games), but it is in my opinion the BEST melee system in any game I've ever played.

Buying Exanima is a way of supporting Bare Mettle and I've done that twice already. There's enormous promise in both their tech and design and I want to see what they're capable of in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Super serious, Low fantasy, physics based combat system (PBCS) - RPG

In this game, you'll learn to - Fall down - Put things on your head - use laughter to overcome fear.

So, the game is lacking an over all finished state - but everything in it is well polished, everything behaves in a way unlike any other game. with (PBCS) movement and fine control are important *and you will suck at it for a while* but it's rewarding to learn, dragging your huge sword across an enemies face and watching him flop to the ground where you inevitably trip over a small bit of the environment because you though you could fight in the tight corridor.

Every encounter is a true threat - even clad in the best armor, you can ♥♥♥♥ up enough and lose to the weakest NPC's. You must learn never to drop your guard around NPC's when in a fight - and strangly you can also chose NOT to fight most of the first and second stage monsters, as most are fairly passive twords you when you dont sprint around them with a weapon flailing about.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: KS Backer, my recorded steam hours are not indicative of my actual playtime.

If you are tired of current trends in RPGs, I would recommend this game to you.
However it is imperative that you read the store page in it's entirety, watch some videos, visit the public forums.
Otherwise you're gonna have a bad time.

There is a lot to take in from this game, please don't expect to jump in and within 0.5 hours, become adept. Be willing to leave and come back to the game, give it time. If you can't do that, why purchase a game in the first place?
You need to use your head, think about the world and what's around you. Use it to your advantage, trick NPCs or lure them to improve your chances. Let friendly-fire work to your advantage or simply outmaneuver the opponents. Most importantly, learn from your mistakes.

TLDR; THIS GAME IS DIFFERENT AND NOT FOR EVERYBODY

Pros:
- Truly a unique game, unlike anything you're trying to compare it to in your head
- Controls are extremely deep and rewarding
- Graphics and UI are quite nice
- Physics interaction is impressive
- Lighting is unreal
- Optimization is very impressive
- Using your head is rewarding in subtle ways
- Very cool OST

Cons:
- Steep, steep learning curve
- Unclear purpose/guidance at times
- Wonky physics can go awry (double edge sword)
- Player progression elements are limited at the moment (early access, subject to change)
