reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing Exanima since the first alpha version was released several years ago and man has it come a long ways since then! Nearly every single aspect of the game has been improved and continues to do so on a regular basis. Bare Mettle releases patches and content updates quite frequently considering the small size of their team.

Exanima is one of the most innovative games I've played in the past 20 years. Instead of using static animations characters move based off of motion synthesis (over 200 simulated muscles) which allows for very dynamic gameplay; every single fight plays out in a unique fashion. The physics are also applied to everything in the game so it's possible to use the environment in creative ways, like dropping an item in front of someone to trip them or barricading a door with a bench, thus preventing it from opening.

Another amazing thing that I haven't seen done before is the accurate collisions which affects gameplay in very significant ways. For example, when using an axe in order to get an effective strike you need to actually land the blow with the head of the axe; hitting with the shaft won't do much damage but it may block an incoming strike or become entangled on the opponent's weapon, body, etc. On the other hand, weapons with long, sharp blades can do drawing cuts with nearly the entire blade length so even small strikes can be quite deadly. Another thing that relates to the accurate collisions is that armor only protects what it actually covers (and armor can be layered on top of each other in realistic ways).

The game will not hold your hand and it encourages the player to think before acting. In the story mode it's up to you to figure out what's going on by paying attention to your surroundings (things are very deliberately placed and everything has a purpose for existing which can give you clues), reading texts/books/scrolls/parchment, etc. As you start to piece together the bits of lore it leaves you wanting more, to keep pressing on so you can find more clues to determine if you really have figured things out or if you're being misled (perhaps intentionally, perhaps unintentionally). The dark, eerie atmosphere combined with never knowing what may be lurking around the next corner really creates a suspenseful gameplay experience which drew me in from the start and kept me glued to my seat the entire time.

If you're just wanting some instant action they've also added a completely separate Arena mode which allows you to fight in many different match types, hire recruits/hirelings to fight with or alongside you, purchase and upgrade gear, etc. I've sunk many hours into the arena and it's basically like having two games in one (the arena could be an entire game of its own). Eventually there will be low latency multi-player PvP and co-op modes in both the arena and story modes which will further increase the game's replayability factor.

If any of this sounds like it may be the type of game you're interested in I highly recommend you give Exanima a try :). Just be patient and try not to get too frustrated when starting out; due to the complexity of the game it does have a rather steep learning curve. If you are cautious and make decisions based off what you would do in real life then you should be okay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game in the early stages of being completed.  At least, that's the way it seems.

So, the very, very short and vague instructions don't really tell you how to play the game.  I'm actually happy for games like that that let you figure it out for yourself.  But, not when key points of how to play the very limited range of the game aren't explained (like how to attack other people, for example).

The graphics are nicer than I expected
The sound is relatively inconspicuous but helps set the mood of being in a dungeon of sorts
The learning curve for playing the game is relatively high and may require some youtubing in order to figure out
As far as the gameplay... let's just say it's fairly punishing and takes some getting used to.
Combat is basically luck of the draw.  If you happen to get the last hit in, you win.  Otherwise it's like flailing at each other with wet noodles until you get the hang of it.  Then it's like flailing at each other with wet cardboard.


Don't forget to open your inventory when you pick something up to actually take it.
Don't forget that the combat interaction button IS NOT the combat button... that's the turn toward cursor" button
The ability to learn how to dash can't be understated... because it's OP.  And

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima diary: Day 1 - Practice. Drunken fool, lurching about. Why when I swing my sword do I face the wrong way? Axe to back of my head. And again. And again. And again. Fight the urge to smash keyboard, to bite mouse. Learn how to swing sword, kill a few.
Day 2 - Now I can fight, play actual game. No two-handed sword? Just a metal spike? Fight, die, run and trip over chair. Die. Constant terror as no saves.  Stupid  bloody game! Why why why! I swear, if I die one more time I will never play again.
Day 3 - Find sledgehammer. No longer lurching, but skipping round attacks. Magical sensation of sledgehammer meeting side of zombie's head. Satisfaction beyond exploading a line of zombie heads with one magnum shot in first resident evil. Eclipsing even swinging a mace from horseback into some peasant's face in mount and blade. Hunt zombies, taunt, lure them in, iron bar meets face, face meets iron bar. Addiction to the sense of weight with every swing.
Day 4- Already looking for ways to give more money to Bare Mettle so they can release Sui Generis earlier. Deep foreboding that I can never play some poor console port (press x for light attack, y for heavy attack) ever again.
Swing two-handed sword into zombie's neck. Magic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Drunk Warrior Simulator. 10/10

More serious review below.


Examina is a unique game. Instead of using a bunch of pre-set animations, it treats everything as a physics object. Your character is essentially a ragdoll that you puppet around with the mouse. The result is a strange mixture of Dark Souls and Amnesia: The Dark Descent.  Attention to historical accuracy when it comes to Medieval armor, weapons, and techniques means that this game gives a great visual example of what two professional warriors would really look like fighting in the Middle Ages...if they were completely hammered.

Pros:
> Very original concept.
> Not very glitchy, considering it's Early Access.
> Creepy, morbid atmosphere--reminds me of Dark Souls and Amnesia: The Dark Descent.
> Nearly everything can be interacted with, much like with Amnesia.
> Physics are pretty realistic.
> AI is pretty smart.
> Very historically accurate. It looks like the devs really did their research.
> Showcases some types of Medieval weapons and armors you don't often see in video games. Again, clearly a lot of research went into the making of this game.
> Very challenging. Even once you get the hang of the combat, more than one weak" enemy can easily overwhelm you. Again
recommended: one of my favorite game franchises. Very rewarding when you finally figure out how to outsmart your opponent and crush his skull with a mace after a long fight.\n> Has a few elements that are similar to Rogue-likes. You start out the Adventure mode with no equipment and have to collect gear bit by bit as you go. Some of the items are always in the same places

especially if you don't have a shield.

Cons:
> Sometimes crashes during loading screens.
> Took me about five hours before I undertood the combat system well enough to actually kill an enemy. It's pretty awkward and unintuative

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is basically for people scared of the difficulty...
My first few hours with Exanima were some of my most frustrating gaming experiences ever.
The camera did its best to get me killed, I tripped over on gusts of wind, enemies spilled my guts.

6 or 7 hours of practise later, it clicked.

The combat got less frustrating. My attacks landed more often, I dodged more. I was getting better.
I went from struggling on the first two enemies in Novice Arena, to cleaning Novice Arena in minutes.
My first time in Expert Arena, I got two enemies away from the end on my first try, and that's when I realised just how addicted I had become. From now on, there is no resting until I've beaten Expert Arena in my underpants.

There's nothing like the feeling of killing an enemy that has beaten you SO. MANY. TIMES. with a lucky backhand slash after dodging an overhead cut. It's the most lifelike, engaging, physical combat I've ever played in a game. It looks great, feels great, it's satisfying and difficult and rewards patience, practise, and learning. The story mode is pant-browningly creepy, as you're armed with sod all except your wits and however much practise you bothered to put into Arena, and left to explore and escape a classic dungeon that could've been taken straight from Ultima legend. Patience and methodical advancement are the ONLY way you'll survive. I haven't gotten past the first level yet!

Bottom line, don't be put off by the difficulty or controls; you get used to them, and you'll be glad you did!

Edit: I just finished the Expert Arena as of the v6.0 update, 21hrs played. A damn rewarding game!

Edit: I just finished the Expert Arena as of the v6.0 update, 21hrs played. A damn rewarding game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ahh Exanima. This is an updated version of my previous review for this game. I'm going to try to be as objective as possible in this one.

SUMMARY Exanima is the ambitious project being developed by Bare Mettle Entertainment. It serves as a prelude and fully-functioning tech demo for Sui Generis - more on the tech demo part later. It was developed to give those who had backed the original project, Sui Generis, a chance to experience the combat first hand and then flourished to include what it has today. Everything that you see in Exanima is going to be pasted over to Sui Generis, and Sui Generis is going to have the full package. Think of Exanima as a very thorough demo that showcases everything that you can expect from Sui Generis.

GAMEPLAY Exanima has the most unique combat engine that I've encounted yet. Think Mount & Blade meets Physics class. You control your character's torso with your mouse cursor, and you attack with your left mouse button. The game uses a 360 degree isometric camera (top down, at an angle). The way your character moves is based on your cursor, not your camera. For example, no matter which way your camera is facing, 'A' - which is right - will always move your character to the right. This might be tricky at first, but actually allows for more advanced maneuvers such as circling your opponent. Again, it's a very tricky system, but after a while you get used to it and it fits like a glove.

Combat can become the major turn off in the game. At first, I was skeptical of this game's success. The combat seemed wonky and sluggish, and the AI seemed too good at making hits. But as I got better, and the developers improved animations and gameplay mechanics, the game became easier. I still die, but I can handle myself in combat better because I learned from my mistakes.

Quite honestly, this game is not for everyone. You have to accept dying, and have to think of your character's suffering as fun. It requires distancing from your character, and the only comparable experience is Dwarf Fortress. In other words: losing is fun."

STORY

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bought this game couple of days ago. It seemed really nice dungeon crawler in dark athmosphere and is exactly that, for that matter, I got my money's worth. Kudos to the studio for the athmosphere they've created. Also, before I get further, I should mention I play the story/campaign mode. There's a grim story to explore, one that gives hints on past events in journals and books, haven't gotten to the bottom of it yet. Also the combat system is plan awesome and nothing I've played thus far. It will take some time to get used to, but after you get the hang of it, you wouldn't change it to anything else and wish more games would have something similar. You really can feel the difference between poking an enemy with a stick and piledriving his head with a sledgehammer.

So I got everything I was hoping for and more, why not recommended? Roguelike. No, roguelikes aren't bad games, I love them, they don't pat you in the head and make you feel like speacial snowflake like the cesspit of casual games. But this game beign roguelike is bad. Let me explain it this way:

1. Your first run will probably be something like, run around, try moves, meet first hostile enemy, maybe kill him, maybe don't, but probably die of at least the second enemy. No biggie, this was fun, let's do it again! Time spent on your character before death: 3-7min

2. You get better at this, find finally some gear and a proper weapon, actually get further in the dungeon. But you still get beatings every now and then, bit by bit the health bar drops and it isn't going to refill in this game (yes, there are like, 2 healing potions in the entire game...). Eventually you die, start from the start again. Time spent on character before death: 20-120min. This phase repeats over and over again until you either get tired of the game as it becomes a burdensome chore to do the same starting grind over and over and over and over again, or get to phase 3.

3. You get maybe at the next dungeon segment! That's sort of a checpoint, so good on that. Repeat phase 2 over and over and over again with your new checkpoint ability. Normal mob zombies become more of a chore than an enemy. Maybe eventually you'll get to next tier of dungeon where you meet faster zombies with more armor and first skeletons in plate armor and claymores, go to part 4.

4. And that's where I stopped playing. I can accept defeat in (roguelike) games when it is clear that I failed either by lack of skill or beign stupid. With this game, defeat is constantly caused by the beforementioned skeletons and faster zombies. No matter what weapon I used, their attacks were always faster, reached further and hit like a truck. Either I had my block up and couldn't attack, or attacked and became vulnerable. This, while battling camera angles that insisted on putting foreground objects in front of the battle. Always when I thought I had the upper hand (which happened like, 1 out of 10 times) in battle and was doing some damage, another patrolling skeleton came along and quickly finished my hopes of winning the battle. In the end I think I might have figured out a proper way to fight them, given opportunity to try different weapon and tactic combinations, but as it took some 40min to clear the dungeon of normal mobs to make it to the skeletons, I really wasn't interested investing the time. Every time I had to clear my way back to them I became more frustrated with it, doing silly mistakes which led me to getting wounded by normal mobs that in otherwise wouldn't have happened, further reducing my chances of beating the skeletons.

Long story short, I never felt like I died because of lack of skill, more because of game suddenly throwing steroid junkie enemies and his buddies to your face.

Oh ye, side note about using different weapon combos: Better get used to using 1h weapon + torch combo only, 80% of the dungeon has no other light source. Best 1h weapon I found was a wooden board you'll find in your spawning room, as absurd as that is. It has the best speed/reach ratio, which I found the best way to get things done with block/dodge & retaliate playstyle.

I'd hope this game would in the future have a save function. Or non-vertical difficulty curve in completely random spot. At least as an optional feature, which you don't have to use if you're a better player than me and want the roguelike experience.

+Combat system is amazing
+Athmosphere is good
+Combat system is damn amazing

-Deaths in traps you can only figure out with trial and error. Start a new game.
-Fight a hostile mob next to peceful mob, peaceful mob thinks you're attacking it, get cornered and flanked, die. Start a new game.
-Dude with claymore hit you dead from behind corner you couldn't see because of camera. Start a new game.
-While manouvering in battle, get in patrol route of 2 more enemies, pull them, get flanked, die. Start a new game.
-Chase feeling enemy, pull 5 more enemies while at it, die. Start a new game.
-Don't chase a fleeing enemy, continue life, get in new fight. Fleeing enemy returns, flanks you, die. Start a new game.
-Vertical difficulty curve enemy appears. Die. Start a new game.
-Eventually die of all the stacked damage. Start a new game.

TLDR; Good game till it starts beign an a**.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The gameplay, graphics, physics are good, and the system requirements are more than reasonable.

A lot of people have a problem with the controls and the learning curve, but I find this thing highly subjective.
Some people are complaining that they can't even swing their weapons and comparing the game to QWOP, while others are destroying the arena with no armor whatsoever.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kPKRbHBCxkA

I have found only one bug. When I equipped a shield close to a table, I was flung around and crushed to death while receiving an endless number of error messages. But one bug is not a lot, considering this is an early access game.

The real problems of the game are the lack of content and features, and some quality of life issues. I'm almost certain that with time these things will be solved.

The game has a lot of potential, and I think this is the first game in a long time that has a decent and unique combat system and competent AI, instead of just button smashing and artificial difficulty.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Beautiful RPG with gritty and grim aesthetics, as well as a really tactile and enjoyable inventory system. You could waste hours into honing your skill with the original combat system and the minimal UI almost seems perfect.

Unfortunately it tries to be one thing, while it actually is another.

At its core, it has pretty good combat mechanics that make every encounter deadly, but mostly optional. Your mouse also is able to interact with the objects in the game world, letting you scavenge through rooms looking underneath objects which often rewards you with something. The rooms look filled with sensible clutter that convey the idea of that people once used to live in them.

What the developer wants it to be, is a static dungeon crawling experience for ~14 levels (Not even half of them are in the game right now) with an alleged focus on puzzles and enviromental clues that tells of a story.

This is weird, because it does not have compelling puzzles that used to be in older RPG's and Dungeon Crawlers, the most exciting ones are timed buttons and that's about as deep as it gets. On top of that, it used to have permadeath until it changed to checkpoints after X of every level, which is kind of bizarre because the maps are static as well as placements. Those concepts conflict with each other, because what you're getting right now is a gauntlet that you run over and over again with absolute no dynamic element to it. The game gives you a great sense of exploration and imminent danger, but when you die more than once on the same level it loses all of its charm. You start running past every enemy and only picking up the necessities on the way. Dark Souls avoids this problem for the most part, by giving you a very rich experience and often a reward for dispatching enemies because there are multiple systems in place that give it depth and purpose, as well as a rather original death system. What ended up happening in Exanima, is that I really enjoyed the first 20 minutes, until I've died once and that point it lost all of its charm and mysticism, making me speedrun the whole 3 levels it offered at that point. Not because I hated the idea of dying, but because I knew that there was nothing I would need or want in any of the rooms as I've already been to them.

The only way to make it enjoyable in its current form, is by making an original death system that persists through checkpoints in some way or to turn it into a procedually generated roguelike and play to its strengths, which is its combat and the gratification of exploration and loot with random traps and its current basic puzzles.
It honestly plays like I Wanna Be The Guy, because all you do is run past enemies, pick up the same gear you've been picking up for the 20th time and if you magically die (Good luck with that if you're just running past everything) then you have the enjoyment of doing the same thing again, with no sense of progression because there's zero knowledge you need in your first playthrough that you otherwise would've gained with experience in playing any other game.

It tries to be something it's not very good at, while neglecting what makes it good. Perhaps it's just my own bitterness in knowing that this would've made an amazing roguelike, that I can't really recommend this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What makes this game great is that it is different. It's rare nowadays to find a video game that can be described as innovative. I believe that Exanima, or Sui Generis as it will eventually become, is exactly that.

What makes this game different is that it uses a very unique combat system that's entirely physics-driven. For a powerful attack, it requires weight and momentum behind it, along with connecting the correct part of your weapon with the enemy. There is no such thing as button mashing in this game. Within minutes of trying the combat for the first time you will see why. Button mashing, or in this case, continuing to hold the left click, will result in a weak display of tapping the enemy with your weapon and finding yourself dead shortly afterward. Each attack requires you to turn and move your character to put your body weight into the swing, and be at the proper distance to connect with the enemy. Too close, and you'll hit them with the haft or bump into them awkwardly. Too far, and you'll swing wide due to the momentum and leave yourself open to attack. This is very much like real life. No person wielding a melee weapon will stand rigid and swing it with just their arms. Weight and force is placed behind a weapon swing through the hip and torso rotation, foot placement, and overall movement of the body (stepping forward along with a swing), all combined with the motion of the arms themselves.

Each battle ends up a frantic and tense endeavor, but also feels very real and organic. Battles move around as you dodge and maneuver, which in turn causes the scenery to come into play. Attack too close to a wall, and your attack will bounce off and be interrupted. Try to move around some debris on the floor, and you might trip and fall, leaving yourself open to a deadly overhead chop.

It took me about an hour to get used to the combat and start to be able to sense the flow of it, but once I have, I couldn't be more excited to get the full release of this game. Combined with the satisfying and unique combat, the entire game in the single player mode has a dark, bleak, and cruel feel to it. You explore what seems to be an abandoned prison filled with roaming undead, scavenging gear and discovering subtle lore while trying to escape. It DEFINITELY does NOT hold your hand in any way. I compare it to Dark Souls in this aspect.

In summary, this game requires actual skill to play, and is very unforgiving. These are both positive things. If you, like myself, are sick of how cliche, hollow, and unsatisfying modern day games have become, I have a feeling you will enjoy this. This is a game for people who want a legitimate challenge, who enjoy realism or physics-based gameplay, and who enjoy a dark/low-fantasy themed RPG setting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I pledged to the original kickstarter and have played since the first alphas. And I can honestly say that Sui Generis and Exanima is the rpg I have been waiting for my entire life.

Exanima's most unique aspect is the combat. It's something you have to play to really understand and it's the best melee combat I've ever played. Something that I have been longing for forever.

But combat is only a small part of the game's excellence. Some dispatched the game based on early videos as just a technical demo of drunken combat, but they couldn't have been further from the truth. Bare Mettle(the devteam) have an unwavering vision of a game that provides a living world unlike any other game. Currently this can be seen in the focus on atmosphere, detail, world and storytelling in Exanima, but take a look at the dynamic systems planned for Sui Generis and you may understand the huge scope of their detailed and living world where everything has a meaning.

For a starter the combat's movement, camera and overall gameplay may seem overwhelming and very difficult because it truly is innovative and something never seen before. But don't panic! I've seen countless people first raging about it's impossibility and bad design, only to come back and apologise a bit later when they've gotten used to it. Truly the combat is a real skill that you have to learn, train and sleep on before you get anywhere. It can take hours before you feel competent, but it's all fun even when you are learning the basics.

I want to give a big hug to Bare Mettle(and especially Madoc the main dev who coded the whole engine and game by himself) for developing a rpg the world has long been in need for. They are amazing devs who actively communicate with the community on the forums and every post they make shines with their professional commitment and supreme vision for a game that defies all the gamey tropes of this days rpg's. This is the real rpg experience we have all been waiting for so go ahead and throw all your money at these guys, they deserve it more than anyone else!

Indies did it again!
10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is AWESOME.
It's got no real story, or maybe I just dont get it.
Graphics are pretty good.
The setting is amazing - dark, gritty, realistic.

But what makes this game is TECHNOLOGY.
Whoever made this Fighting physics is a f*ing genius, and nothing short of that.
At first I died, a LOT, and the figting looged goofy, ♥♥♥♥♥♥, awkward.
I stepped over hundreds of my characters dead bodies, and at some point,m it just 'clicked'
If you remember your first trys at bicycle riding, it's pretty much like that.
Once you get it, you GET it.
Your Characters movement all of a sudden make sense - of COURSE hell walk like a drunk camel if you try impossible moves.
And after a few more hours it dawns at you just how BRILLIANT this game is.

♥♥♥♥ the short campaign, ♥♥♥♥ the few arena enemies - this is pretty much a proof of concept for the bigger game to come, SUi Generis.
And boy does it prove the concept!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the first game where i have quit the game to write a positive review, before i go right back into it.  Currently it is not complete, so check the website for proper info. In brief;

I consider myself to be a fan of melee combat, easily over 15 years non-stop casual research and various practical application, be it hitting mates with sticks or actual metal longsword full contact sparring. These guys nailed it, i mean really nailed it. The sense of balance, distance, timing, commitment, to every single movement and strike. It's difficult to control - but bear with it. Also ask yourself how yould you build it differently? these guys did a good job and mouse keyboard is probably the only thing that can get close until VR becomes a actual good thing (its really not)

So to close: - it's an unfinished melee combat sim with a good arena mode and the mechanics in place for a great story mode. If your ♥♥♥♥ - literally - ♥♥♥♥ at fighting, this game as far as i've seen has no exploits, get better or die =] Really enjoying it, i'm even gonna take a small combo i learn to broadsword class tommorow night =]

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely incredible. If you love 3d topdown, and you like a challenge, this game is perfect. There is a steep learning curve, but I found every hour spent learning the game mechanics very enjoyable. Admittedly, the physics/controls are a bit annoying at times but they're also pretty funny. I enjoyed watching my proud, solemn knight trip over a bucket and faceplant, or make an about-turn into a wall and fall over. While the controls get easier with practice, you should expect your character to look pretty wasted until you get the hang of them.

I'll be following this game with a keen eye. It has extraordinary potential, and will give you a fun, bug free experience as it stands.

*Tips for playing the game: spend a couple of hours in the arena. I found the polearm to be the most effective. In the actual game, run away from the zombies/shut them into rooms (they can't open doors) until you find some good gear. When you are fully armored, damage only depletes stamina (this regenerates, but you die when it hits 0).
voteText: 14 of 18 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is a fresh approach to the genre. The game tries to introduce real physics based melee combat and it succeeds in a high degree. Every little detail counts, the weight of your armor, the weight of your weapon will have a huge impact on the way your character moves and fights. Going around smashing your keys will get you nowhere. To survive in Exanima you must proceed carefully, think your next move and try to plan ahead.
The world in which Exanima takes place is the second best thing about the game. You find yourself locked inside a dark dungeon, with absolutely no idea of what is going on or why you are there. It is up to you to push forward and start collecting clues and items that will help you understand the story of this place and in the end survive and escape the dungeon. Every little room, every corridor in Exanima is fully interactive and you have to search under every crate or in every shell in order to find useful information and objects. The dungeon is dark and creepy but the game does not have any horror elements, providing jumpscares is not what Exanima is trying to achieve.
Obviously, going around searching for clues, is not as easy as it sounds. There are others locked in this dungeon as well. Most of them will ignore you, but there are some that will try to stop and kill you. This is where you have to use your sword, your axe or whatever else you have found already and using as your weapon. But combat is not the only way to move forward. Exanima allows you to outsmart your enemies or even outrun them and avoid conflict if that is what you desire.
Exanima offers a unique experience not only with the main game, where you try to find the exit of a dark dungeon but also with the arena mode. In arena you will have the opportunity to test different weapons and fight against opponents that use various other weapons and a plethora of tactics to take you down. In there you will have the possibility to test your skills and become better. Something that will help you in the main game a lot.
Exanima is the prelude to Sui Generis, an open world RPG, and it gives us a first look at the dark and unforgiving world of this upcoming game. At the moment, the main game does not have a lot of content to offer but the amazing combat system, the fully interactive environments and the general dark atmosphere make Exanima a must buy for fans of the genre and everyone that is looking for a great challenge.

If you enjoyed this review and found it helpful, then please consider following my curator page. Thank you!

http://store.steampowered.com/curator/10128571-SquidofLuvPlays/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After about 90 hours of game time, I'm content i've got my moneys worth from this game, and i'm still enjoying it and excited about upcoming updates!

About the game then:

It's a very low magic fantasy dungeon crawler, there's lore to you but rather than being spoon fed you slowly figure out
the story through letters that you find throughout your journey.

The game itself has a very diabloesque feeling (think Diablo 1)
Allthough the combat system differs fundamentally, It's 100% physics driven, you control how your sword will swing using the mouse sweeping, thrusting, overhead strikes and taunting etc

There's a wide array of weapons to choose from, all being viable choices. The controls will take awhile to get used to, the first few hours will see you wavering about like a drunk fool until you get slaughtered by the first enemy that you meet.

There's plenty of videos on youtube to help you get started and i highly recommend anyone first picking this game up to give them a go, but once you get the feel for the combat the game will become quite addicting (It is for me at least!)

The game is still in early access, and even though updates could be released at a faster intervall, the content available makes this game well worth the price for me.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ignore the play time, it's a bit skewed since I've played this before it's release on Steam.

A prelude to Sui Generis, an open world RPG, Exanima is a dungeon crawler that uses a completely unique physics-based combat system to test out everything before Sui Generis' release. Should you wait until Sui Generis? Absolutely not. Exanima, unlike most Early Access games, feels complete, polished and worthwhile. Here's why:

Exanima is genuinely one of my favourite games, which seems like a good start to a review. It's incredibly atmospheric, nail-bitingly tense and, above all else, completely satisfying. Starting off in a dungeon with nothing but some flimsy clothes, you have to scavenge and gather increasingly powerful gear, fighting your way through until you, hopefully, find an exit. I assume there's an exit, anyway, despite the 2 weeks I spent playing the game, I still didn't complete it.

All of this is done through entirely physics-based animation. The walking/running and the combat is all managed by physics, meaning you can stumble over clutter around the room which leads to either hilarious results, or your death in combat. The combat itself, however, is the most unique I've seen in any game. As you swing your weapon you have to manually twist your body to generate more force behind the swing, dealing more damage. When the enemy attacks you will have to manually position your body to either dodge or block the attack. And the enemies act exactly the same, meaning you will have to time your attacks to get in between the enemies defence and deal damaging blows. Each battle is totally unique from the last, as enemies move differently, attack in different patterns and react to the world around them. As a result, each battle feels personal and unbelievably tense. Even low level enemies right at the start of the game can beat you to death if you don't pay attention.

The game has a tough learning curve. Upon launching the game you get a warning This game is unlike others
date: throw away all expectations." It's not lying
recommended: and when I first played it
hoursPlayed: I ignored it. As I stumbled through doors and drunkenly fell over rubble in Goat Simulator levels of hilarity

I spent far too long fighting and dying and fighting and dying until I reached the final "boss". It was a heart pounding battle rivalled only by Ornstein and Smough in Dark Souls

reviewText:
Early Access Review

pros:
The combat is very satisfying and rightfully punishing.
The equipment interface is pretty free. there's a lot of different types of armor that you can wear together to make different armor combinations.
The graphics are pretty nifty for an isometric game.
The arena is a fun feature to sink time and tinker with combat.

cons:
the main game is frustratingly cluttered, making it hard to manuever with the controls, and even harder to engage combatants. its a shame, because if this game took place somewhere that wasn't a narrow hallway, it would be a lot of fun to encounter and fight enemies.
dark lighting. I often find myself wondering if I'm picking up an item, clicking on a static texture, or moving debris. there are alos quite a few spots with no fixed lights, making it impossible to see unless you're wielding a torch, or decide to toss the torch onto the ground. to some, that may be a bonus. I prefer to see the games I play.

overall, I really enjoy the combat of this game, but could care less for the main game/dungeon crawling. if you're looking for a loot filled dungeon to explore, you'll be disappointed in the bareness of the dark halls. if you're looking for a more punishing dungeon crawler with minimal noise and complexity, this game is for you.

I ambivilantly recommend this game, but from what I've seen, Sui Generis ( the game that exanima prequals ) looks stellar. If you're on the fence about this game, maybe just wait for Sui Generis to come out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First: I played this game´s beta extensively before it was even released on Steam, so do not be fooled by my playtime.


Now that I got that out of the way, I can say that Exanima is already a brilliant game which deserves the attention of every RPG enthusiast and anyone who is interested in melee combat.

At the moment, Exanima mainly offers two things and does both of them euqally well. First there is world exploration. The main campaign is set in the underworld, a large system of tunnels, chambers and basements, in which your self-created protagonist wakes up after crashing through the ceiling. With little more than the clothes on your body, a mysterious half-torn note and a torch you set out to explore your surroundings... Everything is interactive by simply grabbing it with the mouse, so you turn around the boxes and barrels and your quest for anything you can use. Maybe grab a piece of debris as a makeshift weapon, a barrel lid as your first shield and enter the hallway in front of you... Soon, you meet the lavyrinths inhabitants, animated corpses who roam the corridors. Some of them seem to ignore you, others maybe startled by your presence, and some are outright hostile. Suddenly you are forced to fight for your life, either by desperately using the few things you have at hand, or by making a run for it throwing chairs, ladders and everything you can grab in your pursuer´s way... The game engine and physical simulation allows for all kinds of creative behavior.
After overcoming the first obstacles, you slowly start to gather new weapons, armor and other useful things. And at some point you realize that you aren´t simply exploring some video game level, but a functional, realistic setting. You search through cupboards in storage rooms, stumble over washing buckets in bathrooms and find a new hammer in an apparent lumber mill. No, that epic sword will not be hidden inside a toilet stall... but keep your eyes open and use your brain. Everything you find feels valuable and as soon as your own survival is secured, you start to uncover the history of this place... who build it? What happened to the inhabitants? How did you get here? ... maybe time will tell ...


The other large portion of the game is the combat. Exanima´s melee is unlike anything seen in other video games. There are no set animations, every action is the exact result of player input and subtle mouse movement is all that is required. Wider movements leads to wider, harder but slower blows; diagonal movement can cause diagonal cut;, slash for your enemies legs or his head, step into his blow and block his arm so he cannot strike you, riposte his slash, run him over or trip him or strike his unprotected body parts: Yes, the game even simulates armor in detail; everything you wear only protects the parts of your body it actually covers; but armor can be worn in layers with the super simple drag-on system...
Face opponents of various skill levels, from the blunt undead with no sense of self-preservation to the hardened swordmaster in the game´s arena mode. Enemy difficulty is not determined by higher stats, but by how well they master their weapon. Every combatant has different skills and his or her own style of fighting: Watch, adapt, overcome, even if it will take you a while.

... and this is where I mention the issue some people have with the game: Due to Exanima´s vastly different approach to combat, it really takes some time getting used to. In best Dark Souls fashion: Prepare to die. There is a quickstart guide which explains you the basic controls and interaction capabilities, but no real dedicated tutorial. You will feel wonky at first, not really knowing whats going on... similar to learning how to swordfight in real life. Delving deeper into the game´s combat takes some time and learning. But once you get the basics of attacking, blocking and timing down, you will experiment with ripostes, feints and low blows untill every battle is a frantic dance of action!
Yes, the game is hard and the learning curve steep, but once you get a hang of it it will be infinitely satisfying. Experiment with weapons, techniques and fighting styles to overcome the challenge! The skill ceiling is basically infinite.



Pros:

+ very atmospheric dungeon exploration
+ a game world that feels real and interesting
+ physical interactivity of nearly every object
+ rewarding (player)skill and item progression
+ extremely nuanced melee fighting system with endless possibilities
+ every fight exciting and frantic
+ enemies which differ by behavior and weapon skill, not hitpoint or damage values
+ seperate arena mode for the ultimate combat experience
+ detailed character creation
+ superb graphic and sound design (especially lighting)
+ extremely well polished for an early access title
+ already hours of content to explore plus hidden secrets and a degree of randomization

+ really dedicated developers who are into this game with their heart´s blood


Things to come, but not yet implemented (and thus not part of my review):

• Per session and global character skill progression
• Large non-linear main game following early content
• Build and permanently save characters by completing early content
• New encounters, items and environments
• Ranged combat and new close quarter manoeuvres
• Numerous moddable thaumaturgic powers
• More complete arena game modes featuring outdoor arenas
• Complex NPC interactions and dialogue
• Cooperative and competitive LAN multiplayer



Cons:

- steep learning curve / lack of dedicated tutorial


That is really the only one. Once you adjusted to this unique system and dive into the nuances, you are in for one incredible round of dungeon exploration and frantic, deep and highly nuanced melee combat on which you can easily spend dozens or hundreds of hours. Highly recommended!

Dont play this game if you hate losing/dying (but buy it anyway to support the devs :3), this is by no means an easy game, this game doesnt hold your hands, if you arent careful you will easily die and have to start all over again (there will be a checkpoint later in the game). The controls are unique compared to other games so it takes a while to get used to, most games uses static animations, in this game animations are simlulated muscle movements and can be altered realisticly from external forces making movements really dynamic.
The combat like many other things in the game is physics based, timing and precision is needed to be good and features accurate hitboxes, all objects are physically formed as they looks like, this makes how armors and weapons are shaped quickly more important than their stats" (stats shown in a objects description isnt the actual stats

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I must say that this game is incredible.  It is difficult, but also very engaging.  The music, the lighting, the way the camera works, and especially the combat, keep your eyes peeled.  You are constantly trying to see or listen for your next potential opponet, because you know that if you engage them in the wrong area you are sure to lose.

I think my favorite aspect of this game is that each enemy presents a challenge.  Even a poorly equiped zombie with a crutch (yes a crutch) for a weapon can kick your a#@ if they take you by suprise.  Even after you have geared up, if you pick too many fights you put yourself at great risk.

This game take a while to figure out, but playing the arena is immensely helpful.  You will learn the basics of combat, and simply how to control your charecter, as it is quite unique.  Once you have figured out how to fight, the expert arena allows you to refine those skills and try out some of they higher end gear.  **Spoiler** the later enemies in the arena are full plate and ready to smash you in a few blows.

I actually managed to reach the end, but it took me about 20 runs.  I call them runs because the game functions essentially like a rouge-like.  If you die you're done.  You can quit/save at any time, but that save is scrubed when you start again and should you die you start back at square one.  Each playthrough is somewhat unique in the gear that you will find, but many useful items are consitently there.  Also, the layout of the map is the same, but there are many places to explore, and you are constantly faced with the decision to push deeper into the dark (where the best items are) or stick to the places that are well lit, and safer for combat.

All in all, I highly recommend this game, and I hope to see it prosper.  It is innovative, exciting, and frankly exactly what I have been wanting for a long time.

Thank you for making this game, and please continue to develop this gem.  I am anxiously awaiting more content.

Good luck to everyone who decided to try this game out, and if it feels akward at first, give it a few hours, and it will quickly become addictive.

-EPY

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is a challenging RPG from a very promising and loving company. The gameplay revolves around a complicated physics-driven combat system and exploration of a mysterious dungeon. Combat is very tough, rewarding, and stressful. You'll likely die multiple times at the hands of the first enemy you fight, until you learn the combat system.

Overall, Exanima is very well made. Great visuals, excellent sound design, and very good gameplay. Buy this game if you want a fresh and interesting RPG experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Double hard dungeon crawler with true physics based combat. You will be exasperated at first, as the controls will not make sense, but when you get it down, you'll be caving in skulls left, right, and centre in some of the most satisfying fighting you'll have experienced in a long time.

Currently there are no mission pointers, or even clues, as to what you're supposed to be doing, but have a cheeky gander at some YouTube playthroughs, and you'll be off and away.

It's also beautiful, atmospheric, and creepy as f*ck. I'm addicted and I still haven't made it off the first level.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is my first game review, so it may not be up to snuff with some others out there. That being said, this game is beyond amazing. I have very limited free time to enjoy games these days, not nearly like when I was younger. What I spend my free time playing is crucial so my time is not wasted. I don't play many games and Dark Souls series has been my exclusive game of choice for over 3 years now. This game has over taken that, and its not even a full game yet! The combat system is like nothing else I have ever experienced. It connects the player with the game on a deep level. Every swing counts, every back step, strafe and feign. No matter how good you get at fighting, a naked guy with a candlestick can still kick your ♥♥♥ if your game isn't absolutely on par. That being said its a punishing game, progess is sometimes slow (permadeath). it add yet another layer of depth and immersion and makes you really consider all options before proceeding. This is more than fine. This isn't a game that holds your hand and gives you some meaningless trophy for opening doors and stupid ♥♥♥♥ like so many games today that just basically hand you everything on a silver platter. you have to earn everything in this game. IT IS BYFAR THE MOST REWARDING GAME I HAVE EVER PLAYED. I encourage everyone to support Bare Mettle. They are changing the RPG genre as we know it. I can see a future where all fantasy and low fantasy RPGS are based in a physics world where everything is unscripted and the player must precisely aim their attacks. Not just spam the attack button. If you're on the fence about this game try it!!!! Be patient though. It takes time to get familiar with fighting, just like in real life. If you picked up and sword and starting fighting you're not going to be instantly good at it. My biggest piece of advice is SMALL MOVEMENTS.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The dynamic physics based fighting system in this game is really fantastic and something you've probably not experienced before in this genre, but it works wonders and I wish more games could implement something similar.  It is difficult to get used to the unique controls in this game because it is such a different concept compared to how these kinds of games usually approach the controls, but even though it is difficult it is entertaining the entire time you are getting familiar with it.  The character dynamics make each fight different, and there are occasionally hilarious and brutal moments that occur as a result of the physics.  This makes it exceptionally satisfiying when you land deadly strikes on an enemy or get knocked around yourself.

The visuals in the game are all pretty good.  I'm not too hard to please with art necessarily and don't run games at max settings, but this game runs well and looks good on my older computer.  The game has a very realistic looking art style and I love it so far.

I'm most excited about the adventure campaign panning out, what I've seen so far looks absolutely fantastic but needs a lot more work to be something more fun and accessible to players who don't have a lot of skill.  It is especially brutal in that you only get one life and the enemies are extremely difficult.  As a fan of dungeon games, this game has massive potential to become something truly memorable so I hope the devs continue to work on this.

I'm defenitely looking forward to getting the other game that is being developed in tandem with this one now, if it utilizes the same dynamic fighting system and has visuals as good as this game it will probably be awesome.

Since it is early access, here is my super optimistic dev wishlist for things to implement..

- Unarmed enemies who are easier that have only slash or bite attacks.
- Randomized dungeons/levels.
- Randomized quests/stories.
- Randomized treasure loots.
- Randomized scrolls that give permanent advanced magics.
- Randomized hidden passages in dungeons.
- Offensive/defensive basic magics.
- Variety of fatal traps you can place.
- Dismemberment option.
- Removable underwears!! ;)
- Being able to eat, sleep, poop, and pee.
- Crazier hairstyles.
- Saving/Loading.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Please note i have put 50+ hours before playing the steam version*

This game, is what some of us have been waiting for. A game, which demands you use your brain, instead of rock paper scisor technique... or textbook ''This is gonna make you win press button'' gameplay. You will die, you will rage and call ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t... and you will always come back!

First of all, the obvious.

Combat: If you ever played and love the old classic, Die By The Sword, you remember the feel of landing a clean strike on an enemy's head. Aiming your blow, timing your moves, preparing your strike. And the feel, the impact, you knew you made this hit, not some simple ''press Left Click to strike face'' mechanic.

Exanima, has the same feel, but with more simple controls, beautiful graphics and an amazing physics engine. Each blunt strike has you feel the impact of your shot. Each bladed strike has you feel the slice of the swing, even if you simply hit with the tip of your blade. You feel the damage you do, instead of just having a boring hit marker or some health bar go down a little. Each weapon has it's own weight and feel. Each swing feels different based on momentum and movement. With a little practice, it gets easier to use your characters weight to control the swing and give it more power and makes combat even more satisfying.

And the best part about combat in my opinion, is you can never predict the outcome of a fight, like in real life. But you can still prepare depending on what your opponent is wearing. A naked Undead with a club? Use a two handed blade to get an advantage. Skeleton with a sword and shield? use a heavy blunt weapon to counter his blocks. Even then, you might get hit a couple of times, even die... but the feel when you defeat a hard enemy... rarely felt in modern gaming!

Movement: Moving around in and out of combat can feel a little weird at first, but when you get the hang of it, it all goes perfectly together. Kind of plays like a classic dungeon crawler, but with more physical restrictions. Your character builds momentum, his limbs are physically part of the world and everything you see in the world, can be used by you, or against you. For example, if you walk in a room full of chairs, you are bound to trip on them some time. Solution? Use your brain, like in real life, don't walk in chairs. Like real life, if your leg goes up and fall down in a chair hole, you will get your leg stuck, basic physics. This game, emulates these physics perfectly, requires you to think before running face first in a room full of... evil furniture. Sure, sometimes you will have some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t moments, like in every other games, but most of the time it is going to be because of you!

Sword is hitting walls when you fight? Use a shorter sword, don't fight close to a wall, swing from a side opposite to the wall

Information you know, and must use. That's the key to enjoying Exanima!
If you know chairs are a dangerous tripping factor, avoid fighting close to them. if you know, your sword is too long to fight in a doorway, avoid fighting in a doorway.

Kind of like MOBA players who whine because their cooldown time is 3 seconds. They know it will take 3 seconds to cooldown, but they whine because it took too long and they died

In the end, i enjoy the game a lot. It has it's moments, sure, like everything else in the world. But when you actually make your way further than your last play, it feels good! Beating a previously tough enemy in the arena, feels good. Finding sweet loot that helps you in hard situations, feels good!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's important to note that this game is a stand alone dungeon crawling version of Bare Mettle's game, Sui Generis which is still in development. Exanima is basically the same game, minus all the features they plan to have incorporated in SG. They may update Exanima to include some of these combat features, but even as it stands now, it's a very well made game. You can look up the Devs here for videoes of their progress http://www.baremettle.com/

The most important factor in this game is that it uses a physics based combat system. Picture something like Diablo, or  Baldur's gate, where it's dark and creepy and every aspect of combat is affected by numbers and stats. This sword does 1-10 damage, this armor has X ammount of defence or protection. It doesn't quite work the same in Exanima. Gear does have stats, somewhat, but they're more statistics of the physics that make that weapon function. Weight for example will be a large factor in how quickly you can swing your weapon. Slower in turn means that the weapon will likely have more force and impact when landing a hit. Whereas lighter weapons that are well balanced will allow you to attack quickly and stay on your feet easily while dealing less damage.

The health system, like the combat, is also very hardcore and realistic. Taking a sledgehammer to the head may outright kill you, and if not, your maximum health will likely be reduced permanently from how serious the wound was. Similarly, being cut by a knife or sword while wearing simple normal clothes will cause serious damage even if it wasn't a powerful hit, but attacking someone in full platemail with a tiny dagger will likely do almost nothing. The other exception is that armor only provides protection to the part of the body its covering. So that same platemail wearing person, without a helmet on of any kind, could still be hit in the head/face for serious damage.

The music is dark and gloomy. Would have liked to see a change in tempo/theme when in battle. Sounds are excelent and everything sounds like it should. Slashing at someone wearing chainmail sounds like you're hitting chainmail as opposed to skin. Kicking a box or barrel accidently, makes a noise. Running with a torch causes a flame ruffling sound. Enemies seem to react to noises as well, though I've not seen too much of this yet from my currently limited playtime.
Gameplay is fun, creepy, stressful and everything inbetween. There's no save function beyond exiting to continue playing where you left off later on. As a result I died at least 20 times before making any real progress and decided to practice combat in the arena mode, which I would suggest to any new player for sure to get the feel for the controls.

If you're interested in a game that makes you feel powerless, like you would be if you were armed with nothing more than a stick. If you want a game that doesn't have over the top explosions and fancy screen filling graphic soup, but instead realistic sword clashing combat. If you want to actually have to practice fighting, not to leveling up a stat, but to actually feel like you yourself are training to be a better warrior, this game will still kick your ♥♥♥ and make you feel like any mistake you make is your life forefit.

*Edit* After clearing both arena difficulties several times, and finding weapons and combat styles I prefer using, I can only say that I'm that much more in love with it now and anticipating SG's release even more. Also, as noted by every negative review in this game, the controls are simplistic, but very hard to master (Try changing your movement mode from hold to double tap if you dont like that style). Why anyone would be looking for yet another boring, cookie cutter dungeon crawler, I have no idea.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes, the combat system can seem sluggish but if you gave two of your friends swords and tried to control them just using a keyboard and mouse, I imagine it would be just as sluggish.  The animations cannot switch instantly like traditional games.  Characters have to use their muscles to swing, stop their swing, then swing in the opposite direction.  You try doing that with a 10kg weight.

The combat will probably be fleshed out more and right now is simple but still totally fair and you can still pwn it to a pretty great degree.  I would advice going straight into arena mode for ages before the main game.  People have to get use to a new system rather then adapting current combat systems.

This is one of those games achieves a gaming element that hasn't been done before, you'll see for yourself after you test your might against it's combat system.

This is just a pre-game to the even more ambitious open world they are trying to create.  Please support these games so they can complete their goals and more!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR; If the following succinct review is too long for you to read, then pass this gem by as you clearly won't have the patience to learn to play it. :-)

If you are old enough to have played 'Die by the Sword' then you will find this game gives you some of that same feel. Combine the dungeon crawling and/or arena gameplay along with their plans for Sui Generis (look it up!) you will be incredibly stoked for this game. Give it a try! Support the cause!
If you end up buying it, be sure to be in full patience-mode (tm) to learn how to fight. Once you get the hang of it you will love the combat system as it always ends up being something that you personally (and not any character) must be proficient at and *maintain* proficiency. It adds a wonderful degree of positive stress to perform well in each match lest you let your character (and progress) die quickly and without much ado. Be sure to plan on getting up from the computer and doing something else a few times while you manage frustration during the learning process. Give it a few hours of learning and maybe a few YT vids. :-) Also, try the arena (in pugilism!!!). It is the most forgiving as you learn timing and range of your attacks.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is a great deal of fun, the combat is something innovative and new, and when mastered it's absolutely fun to play around with. The game feels quite fluid, the atmosphere is great, and the armor and weapon design is excellent. If you want to just do combat, the arena mode is great. That said, if you want an RPG experience, wait for Sui Generis, the real version of this game to come out. While the game is fun in arena mode, the actual dungeon crawling is nothing but a pain and a massive waste of time. One small slip up can get you killed, coupled with no saving, you're forced to started completely from scratch. If this were a rogue like with a procedurally generated dungeon each time, I'd find this more acceptable, however, without it, it's nothing but constantly doing the same thing over and over again only to make one mistake and die and then do it over and over again, which leaves the player frustrated and without a will to play. In it's current state I cannot recommend this for an rpg experience which I was expecting. However as this is early access hopefully they'll add in a save function of some sort that wont force you to start completely over from scratch.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I backed this game during its kickstarter, and it's been worth the wait. It's a very fun dungeon crawler with a complex physics-based combat system.

There are two game 'modes' so far: the story campaign and the combat arenas. In the campaign you're dropped into an underground area and need to fight or evade some zombie-like enemies (and some others...) to find your way out, and find out what's happened to everyone who used to live down there. The story is revealed mostly in books and scrolls, so you can choose whether you want to read them or not. Environmental storytelling also plays a big part; the maps feel like 'real' places, with workshops, mess halls, sleeping chambers, medical areas, armouries, even a winery. The atmosphere is tense, and aided by a great soundtrack.

The arena mode is where you can engage in pure combat against a variety of foes, and this is where most of the replayability is. The combat takes a while to get used to, but that's to be expected since this is really unlike anything else out there.

The combat moves are not simply pre-set like you find in most games, but rely on the physics simulation, so you throw more weight into your swings by timing your moves with your character's momentum. The simulation is very precise, so if you hit your enemy on a part of their body that's not covered by armour, you'll do more damage. Same goes for you, so you need to keep an eye out for armour with good coverage -- especially important in the campaign mode where healing options are few and far between.

Different types of weapons are suited to different situations too, so if your opponent is wearing heavy plate it's best to use a heavy crushing weapon like a maul or mace, while bladed weapons are better suited to fighting lightly armoured enemies.

The best part is, it's all based on the physics simulation, so it all makes logical sense. A heavy crushing weapon will hit like a truck and can even knock enemies to the ground where you can finish them off. You can even get tangled up with your opponent and swing them off their feet -- or they can do it to you. The result is a combat system where no two fights are the same.

Overall, highly recommended, but remember that it is a hard game, and it does take a while to learn how everything works, so don't be discouraged when you first play it and get destroyed by the first enemy. Once you learn the controls, they work very well and with practice and patience you'll start dominating. The list of upcoming features sounds great so I'm looking forward to updates.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Some of the best fun I've had just goofing around in the arena.  You'll feel pretty crappy about the game, get angry at the controls, upset when the enemies ignore your guard or neatly slice you open.  Just keep at it, when you get your first hit/combo/attack that you wish you'd recorded you'll be hooked.  Then it starts to become intuitive, you learn to handle the character, to flow with momentum, feint, judge range, control your movement rather than letting your weapon control you.  This is where the game REALLY blossoms, the tactical importance of a step forward or a step back, judging your opponent, finding ways inside their guard and directing the cutting edge of your strike for the weakest armor (often enough it's the face).

It's still in early access, but based on what I've seen things can only get better.  I love coming home and dumping an hour or two into hacking away at the NPCs.  For anyone interested in this game, I'd highly suggest you also look at their website for their open world game Sui Generis (still in production as of this writing).

HIGHLY recomended for anyone that likes a challenge and likes a quality game !

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Full Disclosure: Backer from KS and started playing this with alpha so it will probably come across as biased. Oh well.

What Bare Mettle has accomplished in this game is truly amamzing. They created their own engine, and their own physics. I see others stating what games this is similiar to but when it comes down to it, there is nothing like what Bare Mettle has come up with. I get caught up just playing around with the physics. Yes the controls are awkward, and yes hard core gamers have a hard time with them. Why? because they have it ingrained into their head how things should be controlled on a screen. It has become apparent that those that have no preconcieved notions about how to control a character take to these controls a lot smoother. I could keep going on and on about the game, but bottom line is, it's a great game, it's only going to get better and it's cheap. How much do you make an hour? This game is 15 bucks, does this game justify 15 bucks? If you are willing to take some time and learn how it works, yes, you wil get hundreds of hours out of this game, and that's in the state it is now, they are going to be adding more and more. Not sure why you are still reading this, just click add to cart already.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Extraordinary game, active development, low price for a great deal of content, and you're funding an incredible project (Sui Generis).

The Good Things:

++ Incredible, realistic physics.
++ Extremely innovative combat system. Very satisfying, skillful, and fun. And this is coming from someone with several hundred hours in Mount and Blade.
++ Beautiful graphics/visuals. Dynamic lighting is spot-on.
++ Lots of content. I have 20+ hours and I've never gotten passed level 2 (5 levels total as of this review, planned for 14).
++ Interesting story.
++ Great character customization.
++ Great, beautifully simple equipment system.
++ Active development.

The Bad Things:

-- Navigation. Seriously, this game NEEDS a map. These levels are huge and maze-like. I get you're trying to create a difficult, confusing experience. But it just feels frustrating, and doesn't make sense from a narrative nor mechanical perspective. You have a journal; there's no reason you can't draw a map.

-- Replayability somewhat lacking. The only randomly generated elements of this game are the items in chests. Everything else is static. This detracts from replayability.

-- Unsophisticated puzzles. This game describes itself as something of a puzzle-solver, when really the puzzles are no more than exploiting game mechanics or doing speed-runs.

-- AI is dull. All of the enemies have just about the same fighting style (wildly swing and walk towards you).  This can, at times, make one of the most creative combat systems I've ever seen very dull. EDIT: After playing for a while longer, I've encountered new enemies with new and vastly different fighting styles.

IN CONCLUSION:

This game has more potential than I've ever seen from an early access title. The developers are dedicated and communicative. I look forward to Exanima's future, and look forward to the release of Sui Generis. Great job Bare Mettle Entertainment.

I will update this review if development ceases or slows down.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you want a button mash, game does everything for you, typical rpg then don't waste your money.  You won't like this.

If you want a challenge with satisfying simulated medieval combat, and don't mind a steep learning curve, this game is for you.  Get it now in early access while it's less than $20!!!!!!!

Most people have problems with the combat.  That is the single most frustrating thing to me.  It is also the most rewarding.

I've had the game for over a year, and kept putting it down because I would get so frustrated.  An hour here, 30 minutes there.  Just tried again a couple days ago, and suddenly it clicked.  Now I have spent as much time playing in the last 2 days as I did the whole year before the combat clicked.

So yeah, I recommend it.  Just be prepared for the learning curve, but know that it pays off.  Extremely satisfying once it clicks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to thank Splattercat for falling onto this little gem. Bare Mettle really haven't done anything another developer has done before in RPG, except they have created a physics engine that is truly sublime; especially for an independent label. You truly feel your reactions are the cause of your demise or success, and as much as you curse the sod that killed you, you equally curse yourself for your presumption. Not just your own physics, but the AI too seems as balanced as a Bolshoi ballerina. It's reactions too can often embarrass the human's at times, and I'm not even on level 3.

You are paying for the physics here, and not much else. There's a fairly formulaic story, which is progressively interesting, but that's about it. It's the skill of slaughter which is going to define this engine and while it screams for PvP, a more expansive backdrop would perhaps be far more engaging.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: As TwoPumpWarrior mentioned, i am also a KS backer and my play time has nothing to do with my steam play time, there have been months between the first release and steam release. ALSO, check out the community guide me and a bunch of guys put together: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=437266682

I can say without a sliver of doubt, leaving out dungeon siege 2, that this is my faveorite game ever made. This is simply the prelud to the full game and it's already captivated my interest and i'm hooked like a drug. You can just call me another fanboy that is gonna praise the game regardless of what it's like, but if you have that mentality just stop reading now.

BareMettle have put their heart and soul into making this game, they are a small indie dev team and they've made their own engine, models, phyics system and they've done so remarkably well. The graphics are great for a game such as this, the combat is a never done before style and it's the best thing since sliced bread, the lore right now is secretive and we don't know a great deal but what we do know and what we have read has been interesting as hell and i'm craving more as i write this!

Honestly, if you play 1, 2 or even say 4 or 5 hours of this game and say the controls are clunky, the combat is drunken silliness then please just play it more, it took me a couple of days when i first started playing this game in march last year but i've never been happier once i got used to it and started kicking ♥♥♥!

I can't say much more really, Murf made a great comment in his review, what is £10.99 for a life long purchase. You're paying 1/4 the price of your average triple A title and you're getting more from it as lets be honest, most triple A games are a pile of horse ♥♥♥♥. So just do yourself a favour and buy this game.
