reviewText:
Early Access Review

INTRO:

Exanima (V0.5.2)
Developer:  Bare Mettle Entertainment
Publisher:  Bare Mettle Entertainment
£10.99 as of 21/05/15

Exanima is  Bare Mettle Entertainment's first steam release and is a new, early access RPG which features a unique physics engine. The engine gives the user a refreshing control system that is easy to learn but hard to master. You wake up in a medieval prison of some sort, with just a letter in your pocket and a torch on the ground next to you, the rest is up to you to find out. Alternatively, you can play in arena mode which puts you in a one on one combat situation with 2 difficulty settings.
In combat your character is subject to balance, physical limitations and momentum. For instance, swinging a huge sledgehammer will send your character off balance and running into the same direction and it is up to you to correct it to steady yourself. This isn't particularly recommended as you'll most probably end up staggering around like a guy who's had too many flagons of mead. If it's not the mead that makes you fall to the floor it'll be your opponents weapon colliding with your face. If you've ever swung a heavy object you'll know exactly how it feels and best of all, the movements in the game are believable. You really get a feel of how your character moves and how to adapt to the weapon you're using. The combat makes for a challenging yet rewarding experience that can lead to a very intense, addictive experience.
*Insert picture of title page*
GRAPHICS:

In short, the graphics are excellent. The gloomy visuals really put you in place of a medieval dungeon. The lighting effects are exceptional, the shadows provided by the torch and other scarce light sources are very good and realistic. If you stand next to a crate all the individual gaps inside it shine the light through the object and at a wall. I spent a considerable amount of time in the starting room just admiring the graphics, as well as chuckling at the potential of derpy legs and comical trips, which I will cover a bit later. Also, my girlfriend took a short look and compared the game to an “Indiana Jones Gladiator” aesthetic which actually isn't too bad of an analogy on a first look, which also gave me a giggle.

AUDIO:

Exanimas ambient audio really fits in well with the game setting, the music is gloomy and spooky, easily being reusable in a horror game. The footsteps echo nicely and the weapon noises are realistic and well created. Both the graphics and audio give the game an impressive first look.

GAMEPLAY:

So now to the gameplay, with most of this section will be dedicated to the games physics system.
If you don't want to go through all the technical aspects, the TL:DR section provides a nice, humorous story of one of the situations I caught myself in game.
Controls are quite minimal but complex in the way they can be used. Generally WASD can be used to move in an old style resident evil type of way out of combat, with A and D rotating your character whilst moving forward or back with W and S. You can alternatively hold the RMB which will make your character follow the cursor. I opens your inventory  where you drag and drop items from either the environment or from a dead body onto your character or into your inventory (which is seemly unlimited I might add … where in his underwear is he hiding all those axes?!). There is possibility for a situation I call “derpy legs syndrome”, where the character can easily trip over objects or gets his feet stuck into the environment. Whilst being a little annoying in the middle of combat it's actually quite amusing when it does happens.
TAB puts your character into his/her combat stance, when you do this, WASD changes to now react relative to the direction of the cursor. As of this, your body rotates to the direction of your cursor, which is actually a very important part of the controls and can help or hinder your character's balance. A and D will make your character strafe whereas W and S will move your character forward and backward.
Holding LMB will cause your character to swing his weapon, the direction and force depends completely on how you control the character. The damage you cause is dependant of:  the speed of the strike, where the strike hits the enemy, the area of your weapon that hits, your character's balance and the stats of the chosen weapon. When you're not attacking, your character attempts to defend automatically. It's helped by your character's posture and the direction you're facing, which adds another element into how you position and control your character. Or you can just run head on into your opponents body and hope for the best (which is actually a decent tactic against weapons with a sharp or blunt edge on a pole). In a matter of speaking, the game puts all the pressure on YOU. The game is very skill based and only you can mess it up for yourself.
There are an infinite amount of tactics you can apply as you play like for instance counter striking your opponent as he starts a huge swing towards you. Beware though, the only place swinging like a madman trying to dismember your opponent will get you is face down on the floor. The AI is in no way dumb, especially in the arena mode. Your opponent also tries to look for your mistakes and weak spots and will capitalise when you're off balance.
Weapons have 2 main stats, and a large amount of others which chow what type of damage they cause (slash, crush, pierce etc)
Weight: Self explanatory, the heavier the weapon the harder it is to swing. They also have the potential for the highest damage however they are harder to use.
Balance: Balance dictates how balanced the weight is. For instance, a small sword is well balanced and controlled easily whereas a top heavy sledgehammer can send you flying and staggering around like a lunatic if you don't stay in control.
Pro tip: As much as I have tried to figure out, the physique of your character doesn't effect your strength of ability to handle heavy weaponry, as of this creating a skinny character leaves less for your opponent to hit, making you a harder target.

TL:DR

So after getting used to the controls I hop into the arena. I get to a fight between a somewhat rotund guy with mace and shield. With my superior intellect I end up whittling his health down by taking advantage of his wild swings sending him off balance constantly. As the fight was folding to a conclusion, I wind up a huge swing with my trusty two-handed sword. My opponent barely blocks it with his shield, staggering him and spinning him around exposing his back to me. This was it, I prepare to end my domination with a huge finishing blow but just as I start my swing I see my opponent flailing back towards me. I release LMB to bring my sword back to defend but it was too late. What I inevitably ended up doing was helping my opponent pull off a 360 bludgeoning that was reminiscent of how kids spin around in circles as fast as they can pretending to be a tornado. Next thing I know my character's body fell to the floor like a sack of potatoes whilst sporting a large, mace shaped crater in his cranium.
The thing is though, I wasn't even frustrated! I winced, chuckled, shook my head and pounced right back into the action to exact my revenge. The unpredictability that the physics and AI can provide, leads to amazingly tense combat, potential for hilarious scenarios and challenging gameplay.


OVERALL THOUGHTS AND CONCLUSIONS:

The combat system is very well thought out and surprisingly realistic.
Exanima has a very refreshing take on the RPG genre, giving the player a unique and connective experience with the character and the combat system. It's enjoyable and addictive and the unique and unpredictable combat means I will be coming back for more for a long time to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I play a lot of difficult games, and there is a difference between genuine difficulty and artificial difficulty. My primary gripe with Exanima (beside a lack of content as of my writing this), is that the physics engine that the devs are so proud of is honestly just unrealistic and frustrating.

There's no reason for my peasant-fighter character , in nothing but a cloth shirt and pants, to be wobbling around and tripping over his own feet. As many other posters have said, 90% of people after a heavy night of drinking could fight and swing a weapon better than the characters in this game.

The game itself is an interesting concept, runs well on my PC, and has a really gripping art style and atmosphere. However, the drunk" combat just kills it for me; the experience is neither fun nor rewarding enough to warrant playing the game for any prolonged period
date: nevermind paying to do so. Many other combat games do a much better job of allowing players to show (and be rewarded for) their skill without forcing them to spend dozens of hours acclimatizing themselves to a nonsensical and downright silly combat system.\n\nWorse

This game is fun as hell. Let me just put that out there. It;s great. I love the combat. I haven't delved much into the whole dungeony part, and have spent most of my time in the practice arena's and the rest into the regular arena mode. The three main problems I have are:
-Camera is the WORST THING. Like holy crap, the camera is annoying.
-Second, The arena mode fighters take WAAAAAY too long to skill up. Like, in order to get to the point where you have swords and metal parts in your armor, that character will have had to have HUNDREDS of battles. And that part is when it gets the most fun! That's why i like the practice arena. It ramps up quick.
-Lastly, The dugeon is slow. It takes a WHILE to find useful gear od even enemies. And there's no map, so you have to try to remember where all the locked doors and unexplored areas are. I undersrtand if that's how the game is meant to be played, but I want a map you can pull out to at least help a little.
Nevertheless, The combat is really, REALLY fun. I've always loved physicsy games, so This was amazing. Just ramp up the speed of the dungeon and arena mode, because I don't always have the time to slog out so many hours to make so little progress.

column34: and largest part of what makes Exanima worth playing
column35: is its combat. Instead of simply pressing a button to make an attack with a pre-canned animation that if it connects does a constant amount of damage (ignoring target armor/stats)
column36: each attacks damage in Exanima is based on physics. Defence is handled automatically
column37: with characters attempting blocks and parries at any attacks coming at them from the front. Attacking is more complex
column40: and accurate movements. While swinging a weapon
column41: movements of both your and enemy characters can affect how the weapon strikes an enemy. Stepping into a stab increases its damage
column42: stepping back lowers it. A polearm swing at to close a target that strikes the enemy with the pole does far less damage than a proper strike with the head. This

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

A challenging and overall great dungeon explorer with the best combat system I have seen in any RPG game and lots of replayability.

You spawn in a dungeon completely clueless. You don't know where you are and what you have to do, the dungeon is dark and you have no mini-map. While exploring the dungeon you face many enemies who respond to your presence differently, as they can attack you on sight or they don't attack you at all if you are not in aggresive stance. Every fight you have in this game is different and unlike other games you will have to play more careful because critical damage done to your character will not heal. This means you will have to be aware of your surroundings and wether there are objects around you which might make you trip during a fight.

The way armour works in this game is fantastic, your character is very fragile and having your whole body covered in platearmour will not suddenly make you very powerful and unbeatable, you will still have to think and play very careful for you can still die at this point too.

The game has a lot of secrets and puzzles which can be solved by using objects in your surrounding, it gives the player freedom to figure out how to solve puzzles with more than just one way to do it.

This game is not for everyone, if you are looking for an exciting and challenging RPG game then you won't regret this purchase.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would strongly recommend the combat arena before starting a new game!

Fighting is hard to get your head round at first but the combat physics are uniquely superb. Fighting someone with a chair leg is very different from using a machete. Add to this the range of weapons both you and the opponents can use combined with where you fight them, a corridor, around a table and no two fights are ever the same.

A few people have been complaining about the permadeath but its worth noting that as you progress you get better Armour which means when you fight you don't loose any permanent health, just stamina which is regenerated after the fight, so essentially it does become easier than when you first wake up wearing rags and have no equipment.

There is health potions that do heal anyway but they are considering adding 'checkpoints' to the early content to save your progress. There is also a skill system on its way so you will be able to earn permanent skill points for starting builds on new characters.

It's worth noting that not all enemy's will attack on sight, which is handy if you want to hide out the way till they go past and have an explore about.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the first review I've ever written, and I felt compelled, because I'm afraid this game might get overlooked by those surfing the store.

This game, while in early access, already contains plenty of content for you to feel out. This is because you will spend a good amount of time learning the mechanics, and even then, if the enemy gets a lucky hit, it could all be over for you. Exanima will make your heart pound as you navigate the dungeons, unsure which NPCs intend on attacking you, and which just want to be left alone to wander the halls.

The physics engine is so refreshing. While unlikely if you're walking, if you're moving too fast you can easily trip over objects laying on the floor, or just trip, and take an enemy down with you, both stumbling up to try to bash the other's brains out. The only negative I've noticed is that, while strafing in combat, both you and the enemy sometimes cross your feet, which any HEMA enthusiast can tell you is a no-no in melee combat.

If you're iffy on this game, I would suggest going ahead and putting your money in to it. The learning curve is quite steep, taking quite a bit of time to master, but the basics only take a few minutes to learn.

Early Access Review

Exanima is a subtle game. A lot of care has been taken crafting the world. The developers are perfectionists and everything looks functional and as it should be. I think this greatly increases the immersiveness and quality of the game.

There is a learning curve to fighting. Once you actually take the time to learn the 'flow' of combat and how you can defend and attack (by practicing in the arena) it is a very dynamic and satisfying experience. Many people are not familiar with it and are quick to react adversely if they have not mastered it in the first three hours. What can you do.

The game is well worth the money if you're looking for an intense and immersive dungeon crawling experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had been interested in this game a while ago, but I hadn't actually been paying attention to whether or not it had been released, but upon viewing a playthrough of it on YouTube the person playing mentioned it was on Steam. Bought it, and I've been playing it for almost 4 hours straight now. I haven't been doing anything in regards to the main game, just messing around in the Arena and having fun.

I've gotta say, once you get used to the control scheme... this game is a blast to play and is rewarding in and of itself when you pull off some amazing fights against some enemies that were originally giving you such a hard time.

The fact that it's entirely physics based is another beautiful thing. Combat feels like it has oomph, but in a way that feels realistic as opposed to overly slow (i.e. it seems the developers realize that swords don't weigh 10 pounds, but at the same time they also seem to know that medieval combat is visceral).

Definitely recommend this game, even on the basis that I've only played in the Arena so far. If that was all that this was, I'd still recommend it. Especially for the price. Worth every penny.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a remarkably fun game solely by virtue of it's combat system.  To the uninitiated, it controls rather awkwardly, with everyone essentially being a ragdoll animated by physics.  Once you get into the swing of things, however, you tend to find that this is about as skill-based as an action melee game can get.  Hits and misses are entirely physics-based.  You have to work with your movements, build up momentum properly, time everything just right, down to a shuffling of the feet or a swing of your weapon.  You can win any fight as long as you know what you're doing.

It's all based around realism while still being balanced.  Blades don't require as much force and have a greater contact area for doing damage generally, while blunt instruments are the opposite.  Armor will protect better against blades, reducing it to less-lethal blunt damage, while maces and morningstars will bully your tin can until you're nothing but tomato soup inside.

Once you get good at it, nothing can really compare to smashing someone's stupid face in with a mallet, or even a cleaver.  It's all very satisfying, as many others would testify.

The arena mode sates my need for progression, and I look forward to seeing how the game develops.

--

The only real gripes I have are mostly things that will be ironed out through development, like pugilism being a bit broken in that there's way too many one-inch-punches, and you cannot seem to block with your fists at this time.

Oh yeah, and that short characters are quite disadvantaged for obvious reasons.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game and I really hate this game. It's super hard, like old school NES games hard, smash my mouse and scream at my computer hard.  That being said, what the dev's are doing here is nothing short of astounding.

They're making a new type of game. It's super hard to learn for an old school gamer like me because it's sooooo different from anything I've experienced, and with a 450+ game library I've played a lot of them. The physics is amazing, the combat, when I can actually control it is super rewarding, and the look and feel of the game is beautiful.

I don't really like the controls of the game, but I can recognize that some of that is my preconception to what controls should be like. Even so, I think more can be done to make it easier to learn... maybe some tutorials, different camera options, etc. For example I'd love to see what a first person view camera would look like in this engine and with these physics.

I've been following this since it's kickstarter inception and I really can't wait to see Sui Generis, though what really excites me so far is the engine that is being built. I've never seen anything like it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely Brililant!

The combat mechanics in this game are unlike anything I have experienced before.  Imagine taking a game like Diablo, and replacing the click-click-click attacking mechanic with a highly complex, extremely interactive combat system!

The first few hours of play my character moved around like a drunken vagabond, but as I played more, things started to work and soon my character was walking around with confidence, smiting foes left and right!

Despite being EA, there is alot of content here already, the Arena is endless fun (try hotswapping with friends, its awesome fun!) with lots of different weapons and armors to find and use.  The 2 dungeon maps currently available are big and detailed.   Despite only having 2 maps, I havent made it off the first one yet!

Pros :
Fantastic Combat Mechanics
Great Graphics
Emergent Gameplay
HARD!
Creepy fitting sound effects
Minimal HUD

Cons :
Wonky camera (at times)
Funky procedural walking system that can make your character look drunk
Relatively easy to get impossibly stuck on objects (rarely happens accidentally)
Currently no form of progression outside of a single life.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent! Finally a game where combat has evolved into something tactical and more involving. The use of physics here is the best i've seen so far in a fantasy game.

Actually the Arena mode is really fun in it's own. There's a bit of a learning curve to combat, but it didn't take me more than maybe 5 minutes to get fairly good at it, totally worth it. One thing i learned was to really pay attention to the enemy's movement (more than my own).. You shouldnt really look at your character at all in combat, instead just pay attention to the red crosshair and where your hits will approx. land and when. Yes, that might sound totally obvious, but it probably isnt since we're not really used to this type of combat in games - we usually just click away and eventually we win, this doesnt work here (which is great).

The graphics is great, both textures and lightning. The environements i've seen so far are a bit dull though.

There's a great feeling of accomplishment when you win over the more difficult enemies - this is missing in most fantasy RPG's.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine yourself on a precipice, staring out across a vast gulf of empty space. Far below you, as you teeter on the airy brink of a screaming descent, you are just barely able to make out a teeming, seething mass of color and light; tantalizing, gleaming with a banal allure, its glittering generality draws you in, calling to you with a melancholic siren's song, tempting you to take the step and plunge willingly into its garish embrace.

However, your lofty vantage point, and the laborious climb you undertook to ascend to this megalithic perch reminds you of why you are here; and like a lungful of biting cold mountain air, you see with painful clarity the hollow emptiness of the false promises of those plaintive voices, which to the weak and cowardly sound like the lyre and flute of a lonely goddess.

That is Exanima. That is the difficulty and reward for mastering a game which I can only describe as revolutionary, ambitious, and truly different from all the other RPG's, triple-A titles, formulaic franchises, and other money-making schemes of the big publishers and their ilk.

Many of you are skeptical of Steam Early Access games, and for good reason. Oftentimes investing in an unfinished product leaves that product in a perpetual cycle of development, where the developers lose their incentive for fixing anything or adding meaningful content as they rake in more and more money from people like you, the people who give their money and time in the hopes that the creators will actually use your support" towards the common (and advertised) goal. Why would you financially support their endeavor otherwise?

These developers care. They care about making something which is not only totally different in the way the core gameplay operates
date: but is also helped along and advised by the players and community. They have made a game where every action
hoursPlayed: every combat and subtle move made and choice in positioning has weight (pun intended) and impact (pun intended there too) in your playthrough. Every object
voteText: every part of your character
helpfulPercent: your equipment
votesHelpful: your weapons and armor
votesTotal: have a physical presence in the game world which no other game has ever come close to realizing. Yes
votesFunny: there is indeed a steep learning curve
commentsCount: but the reward for your time and patience in mastering the technique is truly satisfying
column16: as is the knowledge that the money you paid for this game goes not only to further Exanima support and development
column17: but also towards Bare Mettle's magnum opus Sui Generis.\n\nIf you have been searching for something different
column18: something difficult
column19: something rewarding and worth your time
column20: you've found it. I don't write reviews much
column21: but Exanima and Bare Mettle Entertainment have earned my praise a hundredfold. Please support this game and these developers
column22: it's worth every penny.\n\nGood luck. And good hunting."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to be honest, I had doubts about this game. But there was no reason to, this game is briliant, bloody, BRILIANT! I absolutly love it.

I started up the campaign, and it lead to a character creation page. While the custoization is pretty great for a game like this, I would have liked to see a little more. Then I began the game, and immidiatly died at the first hit. So, I started the arena to get a feel for the controls. And even though the dungeon crawling is one of the main selling points, the arena mode itself is enough to justify the $15 price-tag. Each enemy in the arena behaves differently, and most importantly they act human. They stumble, they miss, they misjudge distance. I don't know how much money the AI programer makes but give him a raise. after dying in the arena, you restart with all the equipment that was on your character. It feels great to get that one step further in the arena because of it. That being said, it would be appreciated if that were also in the campaign.

I love this game, and it's more than worth your money, but unless we critisize, the game can't progress. So here's a list of things that I would like to see in future updates.


- A tutorial.; this game is hard, and I know that a tutorial might cheapen the experiance of learning manuvers, but it'd be nice.

- more character customization; I just think it'd be nice.

-gladiatorial multipayer: a 1v1 multiplayer mode would make this game a lot more fun. Though the AI arena is amazing, it would be cool if we could hone our skills and chalange other players

-More weapon variety: maybe let us have a rapier, or maybe let us use two one handed swords, daggers, you know things like that.

-more gore; it would add somwthing to the feel of the game if there was noticeable wounds and blood splatters on the characters and environment.

- and open world adventure mode: I know that this is a bad thing to ask for and it would be very hard to make. But it would be nice to see an above ground, open world adventure mode. Joining guilds, going on quests, slaying monsters, htat sort of thing, much like more modern RPG's like Oblivion or The Witcher 3

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, I'd like to say that I very rarely write reviews. The only other game I have written one for was How To Survive, I believe. So that alone should show how much I feel for this game, but let's get right into it.

Pros:
1. The combat system is incredible. While hard to master at first, you eventually get used to and come to love it. the fact moving your whole character and swinging your weapon both make a difference together is marvelous and the way your weapons can sometimes clash and get stuck for a moment, just like they would in reality, is fantastic.

2. The character customization, yes, you can create your own character from scratch. Whether you're fat, thin, muscular or not. Your sex, height, age (physical), and hair style/colour is all interchangeable.

3. The variety in weapons and armour, and even clothing is quite fantastic. (this coming from a person who, out of his two hours of play-time, has only played through the arena mode and just started the story.) From simple linen clothing to light leather armour and finishing with things like full-plate suits of classic medieval armour. And with the armour, come individual weapons and shields to come with them. From greatswords to axes and sickles to spears.

Cons:
1. Perma-death. Let me start by telling you all that this game is -hard-, and I really mean that. The combat style, as I said, is difficult to master and sometimes a battle is won or loss by a matter of a single lucky swing makes it genuinely brain-numbing. This is a hardcore game, as it says, but we could atleast get a none-perma-death option, right? Maybe even just mid-game saves?

2. As it stands, this game is still in early-access and has a long way to go. And not only that, this is merely a prequel, as stated. So there is not a huge amount to do other than follow through the story and spam the arena mode like I've done for a good while, admittedly fun, but it will get old fast.

Conclusion:
If you are willing to put up with the limited (I use that term very lightly) content outside of the story, then I say go ahead. If you want to support the development of this game, I say go ahead.
If you are expecting and hoping for a lot very quickly? Then maybe wait a month or so. Wait till there's a bit more for the game to offer you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pure awesomeness!

Insanely fun, frustrating, satisfying, cruel, realistically violent, unique, skill-based combat system.

Challenging, scary, interesting 'story mode' with an atmosphere I have missed in games for a long time.

Brutal arena mode, in which you can get used to the movement and combat system. Beating arena mode on expert will make you feel like story mode will be a breeze. Guess again ;-)

Never have I seen such a game. Even though they are still developing more content, the re-playability seems to know no end. Every fight is different. Every item in a room has its own physics and can be interacted with as such.

Tired of point and click combat systems? Want to know what it feels like to swing a sword into someones leg? Or get a sledgehammer lodged into your brain?

Pure awesomeness!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When Shadow of the Collosus first came out I was 12 , and since then I was dreaming of games where all the animations and the gameplay mechanics would be generated by the physics itself.
Since then , a few step towards has been made : GTA 4 (Euphoria) , Sumotori , GangBeats , Growhome , and now this one.
It looks a lot like tavern fights where both of the oponents would be drunk.
But it definitely have some greatly responsive controls.
It's a lot more precise than you can actually imagine, and the ragdoll is really working.
It's really something you should try ,it's like a mount and blade but made with euphoria.
I'm getting closer to what i've dreamt for futur video games as a kid.
Next step : A shadow of colossus with procedural animation
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing, and its still in early access. Once I beat it I anticipate doing all sorts of varied runs and even speed runs, but thats once I beat it. How you adapt to this game is impressive. You start out in the Arena barely being able to take on the first couple fights. I remember getting to the third and asking myself if this was finally the boss. (it isn't) But after much practice you'll be able to clear it without taking mortal/red damage (the damage that doesnt heal).

It is hard adjusting to the camera controls and especially swinging left-right and parrying, but once you do it's incredibly rewarding. A lot of complaints are about no-saves and hate having to replay it over and over, but there are easy ways to not let this effect you, once youve cleared an area the first time, make a mental note of what is actually important, then once you die you can breeze through the area grab what you absolutely need and keep running to where you were last. I have also started to limit myself to only a run or two every now and then to keep it fresh. This game has a ton of potential and is so much fun once you get used to it.

Early Access Review

My first minutes of playing this game...

I woke up in a dark dungeon illuminated by no more than the light that sat next to me. about 15 minutes of getting my bearings, equiping the only weapon i could find, a small iron ♥♥♥♥ing stake and trying to figure out how to door. I was met with a large sprawling system of more ♥♥♥♥ing doors and plenty of corridors, Upon opening the second ever door i found, i was met with some clueless zombie barstard swinging an axe almost uncontrollably at me. After a quick look through the controls i figure out how to toggle into combat mode. My time had come... i entered combat, started swinging at the poor zombie fellow in an autistic fit of rage, only to find the wounds I created were innefective and the most i had really seem to do to this fellow was knock him on his ♥♥♥ with the use of the near-by boxes.

Health running low I hit the legs, and by that i ♥♥♥♥ing ran as fast as the poorly scant animations would take me... My health at this point was looking like the dislike bar of any number of justin beibers videos. I. Was. In. Touble. I ran and ran, finally finding an open door, this zombie ♥♥♥♥ still hot on my heels, i found a large metal bar, which in comparison to my simple small iron ♥♥♥♥♥ at the time, it was like seeing ♥♥♥♥ing excaliber dislocated from the rock, sitting right before me for my fat-♥♥♥ characters use. I quickly popped it in my hand, and once again entered combat mode. My health at this point was like you could barely see any yellow anymore... Anyway i took a few swings at him, the reach on this ♥♥♥♥ off bar was HUGE, i mean i was landing blows, he was starting to loose blood, i was feeling good. However after i swear i had almost downed him at this point his ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ friend came stumbling through the door, saw me, and started full on sprinting at me to get a piece of that ♥♥♥ with his SLEDGEHAMMER. I decided to cut all losses and run as fast as i could in hopes that i loose mr and mrs autism. I ran through the door i had just came into directly past these to zombie ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, only to find... Yep thats right, I TRIPPED ON THE ♥♥♥♥ING DOOR FRAME. My fat ♥♥♥ character stumbed in the only was i could describe as, ever seen a turtle on his back trying to flip over but he just cant because of his fat ♥♥♥♥ing shell. Yea. Thats me, exept with 2 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ zombies on my ♥♥♥.

Still on the ground, the one with the sledgehammer reared his hammer over his head, going for a downward strike, i start pressing evey ♥♥♥♥ing button on my keyboard in hopes that he gets his ♥♥♥ OFF THE FLOOR. Nothings working, my character just wont get the ♥♥♥♥ up, the sledgehammer is then driven into my defenceless skull and I am killed.

11/10 would play and suggest to everyone on my friends list.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is just a wonderful game, currently in Early Access and with a lot of content still to come. It's a prelude to the main game, Sui Generis. I backed this on Kickstarter so have been playing early versions for a long time. The graphics and sound are excellent, but the physics system is outstanding. It makes character control and especially combat a hard to learn, frustrating pain in the proverbial, until you get the hang of it, then it's seriously addicting. The developers have a vision for a very unique game experience, even the earliest videos will show you some of the scope of this. I can't wait for it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The developer is trying something new, and there are some good times to be had with this game.

It's beautiful in motion, and just about everything is intuitive and dynamic. If you want to open a door, click and drag it open. If you want to pick up a key, open up your inventory and drag the key from the world into your bag". Want to equip a sword or a piece of armor? Drag it from the wherever it is onto the little representation of your character in your inventory. Boom.

It feels really good to acquire and equip every new piece of armor and every new weapon. I would heartily recommend this game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is one of the few current games that has piqued my interest, and consequently I've put in many hours. There are a few things to take into account with this game. The combat and controls have an extremely high learning curve that surpasses many games. It allows for high precision and control over the arc of your swing, granted you have a steady hand and can anticipate the movements of enemies. This point should not be discounted; the skill cap potential for this game is extremely high.

As for the general atmosphere, the game features a low fantasy dungeon crawler setting. There are also numerous puzzle elements that have clever solutions. The graphics are high quality, and the game features an engine which was made purely from scratch. The AI patterns are quite sophisticated, and against unskilled players will feel ruthless.

Footwork is important in this game, and understanding how the WASD keys augment your damage by adding force to a swing is integral. The overhead and thrusting motions are fantastic and there are multiple weapon classes with different weight and swing speeds. The different weapon types feel extremely responsive once you are familiar with the timing.

The arena mode is another game type which is extremely addictive. I recommend playing the arena mode first to aid in developing your combat skills.

When reading these reviews take into account the hours played by the reviewers. This game is not one that can be properly assessed unless you've developed your familiarity with the combat, and can master the controls. Otherwise you're listening to frustrated players who want to blame the game rather than admitting they aren't very good.

The developers are hard at work on Exanima but are currently limited by a small staff. However, it's clear when reading the forums and seeing the responses that they are very invested in this project and are extremely perfectionist in their work. The game is well worth the current price, even if it is only 5/14 levels completed.


Takeways:

- Incredibly difficult; not for the fainthearted
- High skill cap
- Wonderful art style
- Unfinished, but continuous updates

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Arena Mode Review.

The CONTROL SYSTEM LEARNING CURVE here is a thing of painful beauty.  Over 24hrs i grew from a stumbling drunken bum tripping over his own weapon, to an aggressive clumsy berserker dashing about performing huge looping sword swings that sometimes connected with messy results, on the way i learned to barely survive by tangling my opponents weapon with my own and tripping them, or barging them into walls, combining sidesteps with horizontal cuts, and overhead swings with lunges forward or back, before finally reaching the pinnacle of defensively keeping my opponent right in my weapon arc and my neck out of thiers while slicing in accurate ripostes to counter their attacks and hamstring them while they flail madly at me.

Having said all that about skill, luck still plays a huge factor here, the AI is mean, well armoured, apparently drunk and holding some truly unpleasant weaponry which they have no compulsion about swinging madly at your head or sometimes even their own.

Beat the Novice and Expert arena, 24hrs, proud of myself, that was some seriously sweaty difficulty, long drawn out barring lucky cuts" gladiator fights where you have to survive with enough health each round to tackle a series of increasingly difficult and variably armed/combat styled opponents in a row
date: looting their corpses after each fight to improve your ability to survive further.\n\nClassic beat em up mortal kombat tower climb game structure

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima takes place 20 years before the events of it's succeeding game Sui Generis, in it's current state, it isn't close to finished.
That being said, it is still a great game. I recommend this to anyone who enjoys RPG's, anyone who enjoys physics based games, and realistic combat. Battles I've had in this game rival the choreography of Game Of Thrones.

Now, let's restate. Exanima takes place 20 years before the events of Sui Generis, it is a prelude, this is basically a game to hold you down until Sui Generis comes out, but don't take that lightly, the Devs work hard as they can to pump out updates every week or so, they work 14-17 hours a day all week to make this game possible. I've immersed myself in the community of this game, the people are great, everyone is helpful, kind, and courteous, the Devs themselves interact with the community on a normal basis, respond to support emails and respond on the Discussion Forums.

But more about the game, the game itself is in 0.5.2, in this patch, they fixed animation and the Drunken movement" of the characters. This made the game easier for people to play
date:
the controls are a little less than smooth but the learning curve is detrimental to being able to move correctly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tired of games that not only hand-hold, but give the player a proverbial bj, and then make em’ a sandwich? Like being ganked in Dark Souls, or do you appreciate the unrelenting brutality of Cat Mario? Well, you’ve come to the right ♥♥♥♥ing place young grasshopper.

After about three ingame minutes of enemies combining a slew of weapons with the player character, you’re face and rear will be effectively nonexistent on this plane of reality.

But don’t worry.

After about ten hours you’ll get the hang of things… hopefully. Thankfully, the learning curve is superb, and there is a nifty arena mode to get your bearings before hitting that campaign grind, and your inevitable flooring by enemies which make hardened Souls veterans cry for their mothers in terror.

And the game is in beta. The ♥♥♥♥ hasn't even hit the fan yet.

Exanima is unique, and brings a totally new meaning to dungeon crawler.

Why are you still reading this? Why haven't you bought the game yet?! OH GOD WHY?!?!

*curls up into fetal position, whispering silently*

“Exanima, exanima, exanima…”

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is difficult and unforgiving.  Harder than Dark Souls.  This a game where if you die you start over from the begining without your gear.  There is nearly no healing in the game.  Your life bar can be regenerated slowly but take too much damage and part of that bar can no longer be regained.  In the future there will be a global skill system for your character that stays with you after you die and there will be 1 save after the third floor as well.  Do not expect a cake walk!

The physics engine is really interesting.  The swings of your sword will change based on your mouse direction, your momentum, and the direction moved.  The result is a very cool combat system but it's very difficult to learn.  It takes hours to get the hang of because no other game has similar controls to really compare it to.  Your first couple of hours will be spent fighting your character movement in combat instead of the enemy.  There is an arena mode that lets you practice combat that I would recommend spending some time in and also watching a few youtube videos to see what efficient combat looks like.  Once you do get the hang of the combat controls then you can progress a lot further.  The physics engine also allows you to move objects to set traps and emcumber enemies.

It has a dark and gloomy environment that plays well to set the mood and the graphics are good for this kind of top down isometric kind of game.  It leaves you scared to open doors beause you never know what kind of hellish enemy may be waiting for you behind it.  Many choose to opt for the passive route and avoid combat as much as possible.

The problems with this game is that some parts become tedious.  There is a lot of mouse dragging.  It would be nice to double click an item to pick it up instead of having to drag and drop everything into your character bag and on to your character.  Starting over with nothing also gets pretty tedious after a while especially because the game is so hard.  If you have the tolerance for a truly difficult game and enjoy the kind of top down dark fantasy world with minimal magical then you will probably like this game.  They plan on adding a cooperative lan feature which would be cool but what I really would like to see is a true multiplayer system kind of like diablo 2 where we could get a few people in game and travel together.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Two men facing each other in an arena. One dressed head-to-toe in full plate, the other in chainmail. Dramatic music trumpets through the room. The one in plate wields a two-handed hammer, the other a claymore. A clash of titans. They edge toward one another, keeping steady on their feet.

Claymore takes a swing, hammer steps back, then lunges forward in full swing, claymore blocks with an almightly clang of metal. Hammer swings again, risky, as claymore dodges to the side gracefully, slashing along hammer's back. He yells in agont, but this does not deter him. He gathers himself and sets himself on the defensive. The dance around one another, carefully assessing each other.

Claymore lunges, hammer counter-swings, but claymore was feigning, and immediately slashes in reverse. Its over for hammer...almost. Sheer luck dictates the blow struck his hammer's shaft, and grants him precious time to counter. A sharp swing doubles back along claymore's jaw. No cry of pain, no scream. Only blood. The blow landed, and was deadly. Claymore staggers around, clearly dazed. Hammer steps forward, claymore lunges. Hammer dodges back, the sword gliding off his chainmail pauldrons. Claymore swings back, becoming desperate now. Hammer crouches, dashes to the side and brings the mighty weapon directly into the ribs of his opponent.

This time he screams. His sword falls to his side, his body limp and lifeless. Hammer is the victor. What a fight.

How hard could it be?" I asked myself after closing the above youtube video. I promptly bought the game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a difficult game. Very difficult. It takes a long time to learn to get used to the controls, to figure out good tactics on how to fight, and then more time making those tactics into a habit. And then each time your character dies, you need to relearn those tactics again. It's a deathly hard system, and it's very similar to Dark Souls in that way. Your character is no inhuman hero. Your character is only as good as you can make it, and that means you need to practice a lot.

This game does not hold your hand.

I've sunken almost two hours into the game and I've still only managed to beat the first 4 levels of the arena on novice difficulty.

A lot of people will be scared away by this. It seems a game made for hardcore gamers, and it is. It was made for the likes of those whom play Dark Souls, and admittedly, I'm not one of those.

But I still managed to get into this game. The story is told to you in fragments, you don't really know what's going on, but it catches hold of you.

The combat system does so even more.

It's tough because some of the controls are clunky. The fact that you must move your mouse a certain way to strike with more power, or in a certain direction is not something even hardcore gamers are used to. It's very much a system I would think would work better with a Wii or other motion controller.

Furthermore, movement is clumsy. It's impossibly hard to go where you want to go, and because these movement controls apply relative to your character, you have to pay constant attention to which way your character is facing, rather than trusting a camera angle.

But all of this, while they should be cons, feel... Right.

It's intriguing. It's innovative. And it's an incredibly captivating game in every aspect, from atmosphere to functionality and utility.

Even the level design was made with great care, and the graphics, though beautiful and almost photorealistic, run beautifully even on my mid-end computer.

I didn't expect to like this game.

It has, in two hours, become my favourite.

Buy it. Give it a try, because even if you're a casual gamer, this game is worth it, and you will fall in love with it.

And, thanks to Steam, if you don't like it, your money back guaranteed!

All in all, I rate this 10/10.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nLot's of potential here, but the combat needs some serious tweaks. Rather than a fluid and deadly dance, what we have here is a drunken shuffle with swords. Characters lurch around like your uncle after too many beers, holding onto only the tiniest semblance of finesse and balance. The first thing that must be improved is the combat movement. Rather than big lurching steps, it should be smaller, more responsive and much more fluid. This would make dashing more important as well, helping you score a telling blow after your enemy leave themselves exposed. A lot of the time I would find myself ramming my opponent instead, due to not being able to control the size of my movement. If I didn't get closer, I would be out of reach, If I did move closer, we would start cuddling. Another option I'd like to see is an easy movement or key combination for a straight stab, which would be useful in aforementioned cuddling situation. Another implementation I'd like to see is a guard break or sword beat, meaning you would knock their weapon aside for a moment if you hit it hard enough, breaking their parry and allowing you to land a strike. I'd also like to talk about the tracking system in combat. I find myself spinning a full 360, no matter how much I keep my cursor in position in front of me and on the enemy. Perhaps slightly more tracking would help keep your bearings and get that sissy ballet stuff where it belongs. (France)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is phenomenal.

This game has a VERY steep learning curve until you learn how to survive in combat and find some useful tools. Currently (early access review), this game has permadeath and a fixed room layout with some randomness to items in chests, lockers, and on fallen enemies. You are going to die. You will learn what rooms are safer and where some gear is stashed and with practice, you will explore further.

What makes this game really stand out is the physics of combat. Weapons have heft to them and will hit harder or softer based on your momentum, the part of the weapon that strikes, and the armor in that striking spot. Bladed weapons cause permanent damage against poorly armored bodies, blunt weapons will cause temporary damage through armor, and you can die from either. You can parry attacks based on your facing and the angle of the incoming strike. You can evade away or close the distance in a clutch to negate most if not all of the incoming swing's damage. You can cancel your attacks in feint taunts, and the AI will react to your techniques... every single combat encounter is life threatening. Multiple attackers will try to surround you and corner you... their attacks can and will hurt each other... lighting will frequently be a disadvantage... objects will get in the way... your inventory will only let you use your two hands to hold a weapon, a torch, a shield, but never all three at once, so do you open a door into the dark with a shield at the ready, or do you hold your torch and hope to not see a mace raised and ready to strike...

... and there is supposed to be even more added as this game develops... ranged weapons, magic, skill trees... but as-is, this game's engine is amazing to watch and very rewarding to use once you get through the learning curve.

There are some current glitches of clipping errors (losing keys behind locked doors), no active in-game hints, objects on the ground aren't the easiest to pick up until you learn the better pixel areas to grab, and your in-hand gear will often snag on the walls or room objects, leading to oddly twisted limb graphics... but its early access... you have to expect bugs, and despite the bugs, this game is TOTALLY worth the price, right now.

I can't wait to see what this develops into!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe undeniable main appeal of Exanima is its novel physics-based combat system. What I like about the game—for all its well earned reputation for exceptional difficulty—is that once you get the hang of combat, it starts to feel very statifying, physical, and remains always dangerous. It is not at all about how quickly you can mash buttons and swing the mouse around, but rather a highly tactical system where you have to think about the most effective use of the weapon in your avatar's hands and the weaknesses the enemy reveals that you can exploit physically. Even hits from weak enemies can be lethal, if you are careless in exposing an opportunity. And, of course, the same goes for your enemies. In short, combat in Exanima feels more real" than any game not based around firearms I've personally ever played: real in a satisfying and very fun way

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Written Review (Video series can be found at the bottom):


Overview:

Exanima is a game that i have been looking for for a long time. It is a mixture of frustration and excitement, mingled with the joy that i find myself feeling whenever i choose to delve into its dark and mysterious world. The fact that the story is not laid out in front of you is a challenge that almost anyone who has ever played an RPG would be more than happy to take. Every time you find a parchment, a book, or even a signficant room - it's like lighting a candle in a dark room: the more candles you light, the more you can see and understand. It can be interpreted any way you want. Some people may see it as a story of death and destruction, and others may see it as a story of heroics in a time when heroes were few and far between. You will run through the campaign (what's implemented so far) multiple times, and always find something new to either play with, or discover. Unraveling the story of this world is the objective (IMO) - but you will find yourself fighting tooth and nail for every page of it.

Once you step over the threshold of the first room, there is no going back. You will be sucked into the cruel world known as Exanima - where around every corner there is a different evil, and every sound leaves you clinging to your torch, and praying that you might soon find the light.

Will you survive long enough to tell the tales of the underbelly of the world?


Combat:

Exanima features a very unique combat system. Understand that you will not be able to master it within the time frame of your first session of play!

I have been told multiple times by one of my friends (who is new to Exanima) that the characters look like drunken hobo's fighting: but i do not see that. I am not going to sit here and say that i have mastered the combat, but i certainly understand it more now. To me, the characters seem very controlled and professional. They no longer flail around wildly swinging swords and -maybe- hitting each other. Having said that, the combat can be seen in multiple different lights - and mastered in a variety of ways.

The two sides of this spectrum are realistic/historical" and "Gamey/competitive".

Those on the realistic/historical side tend to incorporate real life experiences that they've picked up from studying historical manuscripts
date: or from learning other styles of combat (boxing
hoursPlayed: ect.).\n\nThose on the gamey/competitive side tend to see the AI as what it is. They know how to shake up the AI so that it is defensless
voteText: and easily take them down with minimal harm done to yourself.\n\nRegardless of how you personally manipulate the combat of the game
helpfulPercent:
each side has their up/down sides.

(The spectrum i have explained above is formed from my own opinion!)


World:

One of the most interesting dungeon/underbelly worlds I've ever seen! The world is not only made up of torture chambers and prisons: this world truly feels like it was lived in. There are hospitals
votesHelpful: housing complexes
votesTotal: training areas
votesFunny: storage rooms
commentsCount: manufacturing areas: everything! If i had to compare it to anything
column16: i would compare it to the world of Metro. There is more to the world than just the metro and stations. Does that make sense?\n\nThe environment in the beginning is very true to the dungeon crawling genre: dark hallways
column17: cold stone walls and floors
column18: prisons and gritty areas. I find that this is good to have in the beginning because it quietly tells you that the game won't be a walk in the park. The details are amazing. You will find everything in this world that contributes to the fact that people lived
column19: worked
column20: and died there. I absolutely love the detail of this game.\n\nYou will find
column21: though
column22: that the world is not as bleak as it seems at the beginning of the game. I won't spoil anything
column23: but the world becomes really beautiful - but even more deadly!\n\nOne of the biggest and best things that caught my attention as soon as i entered the world was the fact that nothing was bolted down. You can ransack a room if you want
column24: barricade a door from enemies with the items at hand
column25: build bridges across endless pits. Hell
column26:
you can even put a bucket on an enemy's head and watch him flail around a bit! The fact that you can truly do whatever you want with the world is a big plus.


AI:

The AI is something special to this game. Each one is different. They all have different personalities that contribute to the way they behave (obviously).

Some enemies you will find run straight at you even if you are not a threat to it. Others will stay stand-off-ish until you get to close. However if you keep your distance and don't look directly at it
column27: it will leave you alone. Some enemies will watch you fight another enemy
column28: and some will join in. You will find that some run away and hide
column29: and others will run to bait you into an ambush.\n\nUnderstanding the AI
column30: and figuring out what to do in almost any situation involving it
column31:
is a huge part of this game - and is quite exciting!


Difficulty:

Understand that there is no difficulty slider in this game. The game is simply hard - and it continues to get harder as you move further into the world. Nothing is handed to you. You must fight
column32: desperately sometimes
column33:
for everything you have.

Some AI (like the ones at the beginning of the game) are easier to take down - but are still a threat because you have nothing.

As you progress further you will find the fights more tense - but still relatively easy.

Three quarters of the way through the current content you will be fighting for your life. it will not be easy. You will encounter enemies you never expected to encounter
column34: and you may die because of the shock.\n\nIt doesn't matter how far into the game you've gone. It will always be a challenge. The payoff is survivng these challenges
column35:
and moving on to the next one!


Conclusion:

Exanima is a magnificent game that can only get better as it is developed further. Everything from the world around you
column36: to the secrets it holds - to the monsters that you fight
column37: and the dangers you are confronted with. It makes a reputation as being difficult
column38:
but rewarding. Anyone who is interested in hardcore roleplaying games should definitely pick this up. Those of you who are not into perma-death can still play because they have early checkpoints: but understand that there will not always be checkpoints to fall back on!

Willy McBride

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a lot of fun, but it's vastly different from games you're used to.  Combat is based on physics and it's definitely something you have to get used to, but after you do get used to it, it's fun.  Exploring the levels is a lot of fun.  The environments are creepy, and it's dark and you don't know what you're going to find.  I like that the game doesn't hand hold you and you have to explore and try different things.  The arena is also a fun past time if you just want to do some combat. Right now there's not a ton of levels and content, but it's well worth 20 hours or so and the developers have been adding some great stuff.  I look forward to seeing what the full game is going to be like.

If you buy it, keep in mind that it's not finished but you can still get a lot of enjoyment out of it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI had an itch for a dungeon crawl, remembering Ultima Underworld and wanting to revisit that dank vibe.  I learned of this using Google to search for a modern version of that type of game and came to this.  Exanima has exceeded my expectations!  I am blown away at how well made it is, and this is just the beta of the precursor to the actual final product 0.o.  Very addictive, but I do get my face split open more often than I would like.  I am getting better though, I've made it to what I assume is level 2, went through some steel double doors and the zombies just keep flailing away with crutches and bedpans, omg!  Even though I have found some fine armor (layers of it) I unfortunately I had to use the jar of blue goo I found on level 1 after a fat zombie gashed me open while I was comparison shopping some fresh duds on this corpse I just made.   Oh well, I'll just restart again if I die, I think I have the first level memorized now, lol!  The most fun I have had with this type of game in 20 years or so.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI just happened to notice this game while just browsing through, looking for something to tide me over while I wait for bigger things to come out this year, and even though the game is missing a lot on content being a early access game, it doesn't disappoint with what it does have so far. The atmosphere is spot on for the type of dugeon crawler/adventure type game it is, combat is very satisfying once you gain some experience with its hard to learn but interesting mechanics and physics and there is a real sense of danger when you are surrounded by multiple enemies or something strong is chasing you down. The physics based looting, combat and movement means you can have a real tactical advantage by putting chairs, benches, wood planks and anything else you can throw between you and your target, sometimes tripping over furniture that you have thrown at them. Healing salves are rare and far between, so some thought and consideration in your actions is highly advised, not all enemies will be hostile towards you immediatly. Items and equipment gained a bit later on feels like it really makes a difference when attacks that used to do half your health or most of it, hardly do anything once you equip a bit of leather armour or chain mail abit further in. There is still much missing, most of the story, more levels, enemy variety and more choice in equipment, but I would recommend picking this up and supporting this developer. I'm hooked in and looking forward to seeing what else they bring to this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Initial reactionsThis game is interesting. It combines solo combat from Mount and Blade with the isometric view of Diablo and the difficulty of a Souls game. Combat feels almost like you need to be lucky to score more hits than an opponent, though it does make logical sense. The physics are a little rough, but they are mostly real feeling. Blocking a door with a book case is a viable escape plan.

It is difficult. Don't expect to be able to jump right in and do well. This isn't like Dark Souls; you've probably never experienced anything quite like it before. You are puny and pathetic like your enemies until you learn to be better and out-gear them. The enemies see your weakness and will punish you for it if you let them. This is a nice, challenging and oh so frustrating game so far. I will post a more thorough review after more than a few hours in it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For those of you who don't know it, Exanima is sort of a prelude, demo and experiment all baked into one for another game called Sui Generis, so this review will probably apply to both of those games.

For starters, let me just say that this game is awesome, there's just no other way to put it. Having that said, let's get down to what this game is all about.

It is a 3D top-down RPG set in a medieval-ish universe. Exanima places a lot of focus on physics (character movement, combat, interaction etc) and it's being performed very well. Im not really sure how they've done it, but movement in the game is not fixed animations from what I can see. If you run through a hallway and your foot get's caught under a fallen chair, your character will fall flat on his/hers face.

Not because of some trigger on the chair, but because your foot was caught and was not in the place your character expected when he/she lifted his/hers other foot up.

Same thing applies to combat: If you smack a warhammer right across someones face, it will send them twirling to the ground, again, not because of some script telling it that it was a special move, but because that character is simply not able to maintain balance and resist the sheer force.

This would apply both ways however, if your character swings that warhammer and misses, then your character will most likely be forced to follow the warhammer with his/hers entire body in an attempt to slow it down and bring it back into position for another attack. That's time that your opponent is likely to take advantage of, provided he/she is equipped with a lighter, more manageable weapon.

There will also be a kind of magic called thaumaturgy". However it is not in the game yet and can only be seen and read about in lore and videos from devs.

Right now there are two game-modes
date: Arena and a gamemode that has not been named yet
recommended: but it strongly resembles a campaign-mode
hoursPlayed: so that's what I'll call it.\n\nIn the arena the player is pitted one on one against NPCs with various equipment. When the player has beaten the NPC he has the ability to loot the NPC and use his/hers equipment. When the player so chooses he/she can then move on to the next stage of the arena
voteText: with a more well-equipped (and possibly slightly more tactical?) NPC waiting for him. After each victory the player is also rewarded with a slight healing boost (not much though).\n\nIn the campaign-mode
helpfulPercent: the player wakes up in a dark room without anything else but the shabby clothes on his/hers back and a part of a note (I won't spoil too much). He/she is then left to explore the area
votesHelpful:
uncovering the story as he/she progresses further.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So have you ever played one of those games where it's so frustrating to play and so ridiculouysly hard to master, but all you can do is keep trying because it's so graphically pleasing and so satisfying when you get even just one kill? This is THAT game!

There's no tutorial, BUT there IS a quick help guide which helps tremendously in some cases.

This game NEEDS a quick tutorial in the beginning, kind of helping the player with mouse gestures, and ways to make better contact with your foe. You can eventually, somewhat, sorta strike the opponent, but not very accurately or with much force it seems. But maybe with more gameply I can figure it out.

It'd be cool to see more animations when your enemy has low health as well. Maybe he starts limping, or guarding one side that you've been striking most or more blood on that side as well as chopping limbs off would be great and help just so i'm not gussing how many times i gotta strike this guy with my sword! I love the idea of no health bars for the enemy's because it seems more realistic and different! I love that your character automatically blocks for you, you just have to be careful when to strike otherwise you'll get hit and quite rapidly from the npc's. Maybe difficulty levels would be a nice addition to the game as well!

This game has the coolest physics i've seen in such a graphically enhanced game it blows my mind! The Way YOU control your weapon puts you right in the battles and makes you feel like you're the blademaster! It feels and looks really great!

The Arena is a cool feature as well! When you die though (which is very often, at least for me; maybe I suck who knows) You either have to
A) Quit all the way back to the homescreen and reselect your character and weapons again or,
B) Click Exit that appears on the screen when you die which takes you to your character selection page
(the game remembers your gear and character but it's still a pain to go all the way back to the beginning)

There should be an option to select retry or restart as soon as you die, and the game drops you right back into battle with the gear you already have.

Overall I haven't gotten past the first npc i've met in the career" mode
date: so the hours you see are mostly spent reading the quick start guide and playing in the arena constantly clicking EXIT
hoursPlayed: NEXT
voteText: and finally back to START

and starting back from square one in the arena. It's all actually pretty damn fun slashing your foes with the swipe of your mouse in an entirely NEW way. Something I personally have never seen done in a game before. That's what kept me playing and coming back for more! Something totally new and I was willing to learn the basics becuase it was so damn fun asthetically pleasing to watch!

7/10 for graphics and gameplay! For this being early access I'd say that's a pretty fair score considering the difficulty! Needs some work and more features but overall it's a great game and I will continue to play and wait for more updates! Great Job Devs and Keep Up the Great Work!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've held off on writing this review because I want to be careful about how I approached it, at this time the game isn't complete and all I've really done is played through the Arenas focusing on the combat system, and that really is the selling point of this game, its unique combat system.

If you're like me you have a special place in your heart for all things Medieval, there have been low-fantasy and high fantasy settings, a variety of gameplay structures based on certain degree of random rolls and a lot of rules which, while somewhat immersive, didn't always make sense and seemed to miss that certain un-nameable something. The combat system in Exanima fills that void and sets a new standard for low fantasy medieval combat, truthfully what excites me most about it is the notion that if this game is moddable all the wonderful that can be revisited using this wonderful system, I shall explain.

First off, there is a learning curve, like learning to swim you'll have to figure out the combat system through practice which the Arena is really good for. After a lot of trial and error you'll start to learn the new system and adapt to it's unique mechanics, what begins to form is and intuitive display of medieval combat that really plays out like real combat. There is no arbitrary % chance to block" your character will always do their best to block an incoming attack

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW... and take 3 hours of time to get used to its awful controls.

You will die and lose all of your progress very very very frequently. You will trip over furniture, be smacked in the face with a sledgehammer and get stuck on a door frame in the middle of battle.

But it is all worth it. This game was made with real love - the environments, which at first seem to be Baldur's Gate-era grey grit, actually have deep and distinct detail - the rooms are laid out smartly, the lighting well-planned and the objects feel real and weighty.

The combat starts off like jello ragdoll and ends up being a fluid, organically dangerous ballet of real swordsmanship. You will at the same time dread, panic and delight when you see the shadow of another person in the doorway.

Exanima deserves your attention.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt is just as the developers said, it is a difficult game, but not a hard one. And the permadeath actually makes you feel your decisions and play differently. It is joyful for as long as it lasts. The arena is a top training ground and I managed to master expert mode after some hours. So I felt like hitting the streets. BUT after I came a long way; I was accidentally killed. So I am not masochistic in no way and I dont want to play all the same stuff over and over and over, because you can be killed just so. Admitted, its your own fault: One hasty retreat backwards into some furniture, one time flattened, one time hitting the wall with your swing, one time swinging too short. Its all in the game and its all your fault. BUT I simply do that, I am clumsy and then to start all over again? After I came so far? No. So there is a savescum method and actually it robs you of the feeling you get from permadeath. But yes, considering all these stupid deaths I had and imagining each time to have to start all over? No, I would have thrown it away by now. So I traded the real feel from permadeath to actually being able to finish the game. And with this tweek, I do absolutely recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been waiting to review this until I've thoroughly beaten the three levels there currently are. Not sure if more are in the works. I'm writing this as of version 0.5.3

Short version: Most unique combat in an RPG I've played in many years. The most tense RPG experience as well. Interesting physics that works very well with the style of the game.

So, the first thing to note is that combat in Exanima is unlike any other RPG I've ever played. The closest I could describe it as would be to take Mount and Blade's combat, throw it into an isometric RPG like Diablo, and then add a heavy dose of physics. It takes a little getting used to, but that's not too surprising since it's so different. Some people can get frustrated, but give it a few hours of honest trying. Try different weapons. They all handle differently and have their perks. I found it to be a very satisfying system that generated new thrills in each encounter both in the arena and in the dungeon.

Speaking of which, I enjoyed both game modes thoroughly. Arena mode should definitely be played first, unless you like to die due to unfamiliar controls. Being in the arena gives you a great sense of progression as you down each opponent and loot their gear. Opponents get more and more aggressive and are generally smart.

The dungeon mode is very atmospheric and is quite tense. More tense than any isometric RPG I've ever played. In fact, extend that to RPGs in general. Once you get decent gear, learn how to survive, and take out a few zombies, the tension eases a bit. However, death still comes easily in this game. The tension also comes from the copious amounts of shadow in this game. You'll be stuck carrying a light source for most of the adventure mode.

There's not a whole lot actual game content in this at least just yet. However, I'm not at all disappointed in my purchase. I can't wait for either more content or for the release of Sui Generis, the game for which this is a prelude to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a precursor alpha game to a larger scale experience, it currently has two modes to play. Single player with intense dungeon crawling levels and the newer Arena fighting. I've had the game for some time now, but when they added the arena stuff, my friend and I spent almost 6 hours learning the ins and outs of how to play the game, fighting mechanics, economical strategies, and fighter management. The game doesn't hold your hand at all. Once the difficulty curve of fighting is conquered, you have to earn money based on fights for your manager (main character) or the men and women hired to fight for you. The money is spent on gear and for wagering in higher ranked fights. The RPG elements are focused on fighting techniques and physical abilities that can enhance your fighters. There is also a great deal of customization from appearance to types of weapons. The only drawback is that the amount of content within the game is limited, hence being an alpha.

In conclusion, this game has very high standards for an indie game. The combat is satisfying and entertaining. The team has great ambitions spearheading this project and I hope to see it through.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is a physics and simulation-based dungeon-crawling Action-RPG and precursor to upcoming open-world ARPG/simulation Sui Generis. You must use your mouse to swing your weapons, and to interact and move objects around in the world. Just about everything has collision. Enemies can hurt each other; AI is engaging, although zombie like in many ways in the current iteration.

The game involves a lot of survival/scrounging in the beginning and is more about steady exploration/discovery than pure dungeon running and looting.

Exanima has a dark and minimalist low-fantasy setting. The dynamic lighting, animation, and graphics in general are really nice.

Even though many things have not been implemented, once you get a taste of the combat and concept, and if you are a fan of action RPGs and adventure games, you will know, as I do, supporting this is really a no-brainer.

If you like: Ultima, Dark Souls, Diablo, Elder Scrolls, Baldur's Gate, Divinity, Planescape, etc. you'll probably find something you like here with many more features, weapons, and mechanics to look forward to!

Highly recommended.

Good work so far, Bare Mettle!
