reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is doing to top-down isometric dungeon crawlers what Demon Souls did to third person action/rpgs, i got from it the same raw feeling of danger and excitment i got when i first played Demon's Souls.

And like DS this game is unforgiving and will not hesitate to crush you and kill you in the most humiliating and brutal ways but you will learn something new with every death, there is little hand holding here and the learning curve is pretty steep, but all that makes it really really rewarding, even killing a single foe here feels like a grand victory of epic proportions, you made it ... You survived ... And the other guy is lying bloodied on the floor, pat yourself on the back and eat a cookie, you have done it and survived another brutal fight (cause here when a character dies here they die for good, no coming back from a 10 kg sledge hammer meeting your skull at high speed).

Also note two important things, first is that this is still a work in progress early access game so expect some bugs (quite rare though) and also that its story mode is still incomplete (though i could barely survive the first area till now and there are three of them as far as i know), but it is playble and quite polished showing the serious effort the devs put into it.

Second is that it's a physics based game, your character's body, your enemie's and the enviroment objects are all physics enabled, and it's not just rag-doll physics .. You and everything around you are under the influence of physics all the time ... This dramatically changes how combat plays out and generally how you traverse the enviroment, running from an angry hammer-wielding dude that can bash your skull and kill you with a single well placed hit to your face .. See that chair .. If this was a normal game you would probably tear right through it or push it aside, but here it can be quite dangerous,this chair can really trip you over and get you killed in the most humiliating way possible.

Cause that dude with the hammer will be more than happy to smash your head on the floor before you can even get up, so next time you see a chair while running from angry dudes with hammers make sure to avoid tripping over it, and maybe take a sec to push it in their way, maybe they will fall over and give you a chance to take them out while avoiding their hammer getting introduced to your poor face (usually a very brief, loud and bloody introduction that ends with you dead on the floor), i mean who who would have thought a chair could make such difference in a fight (unless you are into bar brawls), it does here in Exanima, so mind your enviroment and use it to your advantage, got an angry mob chasing you with cleavers and axes, run into a two door room/hallway then close the door behind you quickly and bar it with chairs, ladders and wooden planks, and always beware the angry dudes (or dudettes) with hammers.

And did mention i love the character models and character creation here, there are both male and female characters available and a very nifty body type modifying graph (that i wish all RPGs had) along with few hair types and realistic hair and skin colors to pick from, also the gear equipping system is neat and realistic (you can wear up to three layers of clothes/armor and they all offer varying types and degrees of protection from the various types of damage in the game (slash, blunt and pierce damage), not to mention it's quite an accurate depiction of medieval armor and your chatacter will look pretty rad decked in realistic full plate armor after starting out with nothing but rags (and i'm yet to get there but the Arena mode allows you to try the look of items before you buy them, and the high-end items cost a lot of gold, which you earn by winning arena fights), one day you sweet full plate helmet, one day you will be mine, hahahaha ... ahm.. Never mind that, i just got a little excited!

Long story short it's a game for those who want something creative, exciting and challenging, something that simulates the look and ferl of medieval combat pretty damn well, it's all for you if don't mind it having a steep learning curve.

If you want to get instant gratification, empowerment and to just obliterate dozens of enemies per minute steer clear of Exanima, go play other isometric hack & slash dungeon crawlers like Diablo 3 or Grimdawn (which are damn fine and i play them too, but they are very different from Exanima), these games unlike Exanima don't punish and
Kill you for flailing your weapon around, they encourage you to do so and make it enjoyable, but Exanima's methodical slow paced phyiscs enabled combat this just gets you killed, it surely isn't for everyone but if you can get into it and learn its innerworkings it can be extremely rewarding way beyond any of those other games in the genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great stuff. I'm not usually a player of top-down games, but I can't stop playing this one!

If you're new or thinking of playing it, it's well worth doing the gauntlet of arena mode before starting the story mode. That way you can learn the (difficult) ways of combat and not get jumped by a man with a pipe while exploring a toilet, like I was. Beware the toilets.

EDIT: Once completing the temporary story mode I do have a few recommendations/suggestions.

Firstly would be to increase the responsiveness to movement, it can be infuriatingly clumsy and slow to respond and move when you're trying to escape someone chasing after you with a sledgehammer.

Second could be to add an instant retry option in arena mode rather than having to go through the customisation screen repeatedly.

Third would be to smooth and refine movement in combat, as of the moment the movement is a bit jerky and awkward. It can end with you in very precarious positions.

Fourth could be to ensure that at least some NPCs remain peaceful unless provoked. All too often one will suddenly decide to swing at me while edging around them, when up until that time they'd been perfectly jovial. Although it does add a good feeling tension, when there's multiple NPCs around it becomes more of a game of hide and seek than exploration.

Fifth it would be interesting just to see a few NPCs having little fights between themselves. Just out of interest!

Thank you for producing a great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great stuff. I'm not usually a player of top-down games, but I can't stop playing this one!

If you're new or thinking of playing it, it's well worth doing the gauntlet of arena mode before starting the story mode. That way you can learn the (difficult) ways of combat and not get jumped by a man with a pipe while exploring a toilet, like I was. Beware the toilets.

EDIT: Once completing the temporary story mode I do have a few recommendations/suggestions.

Firstly would be to increase the responsiveness to movement, it can be infuriatingly clumsy and slow to respond and move when you're trying to escape someone chasing after you with a sledgehammer.

Second could be to add an instant retry option in arena mode rather than having to go through the customisation screen repeatedly.

Third would be to smooth and refine movement in combat, as of the moment the movement is a bit jerky and awkward. It can end with you in very precarious positions.

Fourth could be to ensure that at least some NPCs remain peaceful unless provoked. All too often one will suddenly decide to swing at me while edging around them, when up until that time they'd been perfectly jovial. Although it does add a good feeling tension, when there's multiple NPCs around it becomes more of a game of hide and seek than exploration.

Fifth it would be interesting just to see a few NPCs having little fights between themselves. Just out of interest!

Thank you for producing a great game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game rocks so far. It feels like original Diablo with a twist, or two (good twists). The Story is actually compelling and rather well written, something rare in games recently. I really like the controls once you get used to them and the arena mode is a nice addition! The artificial intelligence seems complex and has potential.

I was somewhat skeptical and turned off by the quirky animations at first (from seeing trailers) but after playing it and seeing all the details I got immediately hooked and it all makes sense within the physics based world and it's very fun to play around and fight. It also adds a lot of personality. The art is very well done (the UI could use some work though, mostly the fonts that could be simpler)   and the game runs SMOOTH. It's so well optimized, I haven't seen anything like this lately. Custom engines FTW.

Very unique game with lots of potential. I haven't beaten it and I'm scared of going on. I feel bad now for getting it on sale, will definitely throw my money at the devs when Sui Generis comes out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let's be clear about this game : For now, Exanima is all about combat and physics. It is a game purposely made as a prequel of Sui Generis, an ambitious RPG made by the same devs that'll use the same physics-based combat.

Expect something unfinished, yet highly enjoyable and innovative. Fight mechanisms seems very odd at first but you may become a little more skillful after practicing several hours in the Arena. It is really important to understand that Exanima is not a game for everyone. It takes a few days to apprehend it, yet it depends on how you approach it and every encounter may cause you to die. You cannot save in Story Mode and death is rather quick and punishing.

Exanima was initially created for a community to emerge about Bare Mettle's project that is Sui Generis, so, before writing any review about this game, be it positive or negative : be patient, try and master the combat system and only then you can give your opinion. Don't get me wrong, I don't want to be rude here, I wanted this to be clear for those who plan to purchase the game, because then you might have a real gem in your hands that is Exanima. Just, be patient.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is apparently not for everyone but some will love it.
So here's a list of properties to see if this game suits you:
You...
- Enjoy a good challenge.
- Don't mind learning to play a new game. (It takes some time)
- Like gritty dark dungeon crawling.
- Like scavenging for loot.
- Don't mind wobbly movement. (Has been improved a lot!)
- Enjoy physics even though it won't always look 100% realistic.
- Love not getting good gear straight away.
- Like rougelikes/permadeath (There is one checkpoint in the game, but extra ones can be turned on)
- Can handle dying (see above)
- Like running and fleeing
- Don't mind being weaker than you're opponent
- Like oldschool rpg
- Like low fantasy (less magic)

It's dark, it's gritty, it's got meaty physics based combat.
I have enjoyed it immensly, it's one of the best and freshest gaming experiences I've had in a while.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Combat is difficult.  Not a button masher so it takes time to learn, patience to play.  It does need a save function....I hate starting all over after death.  So beware...difficulty and no save function can equal frustration.  Lastly, no clear manual on the game mechanics.  Took me a while to figure out how to use a key.  Also, items are so small...for a person who uses readers to see fine print, this can be a problem.

Having said that I enjoy the game, even though I've played 8 hours and havent gotten past the first level.  It has a setting and atmosphere that I love, decent graphics, and most important realism.  I kinda wish there were no stats on weapns and armour.  I'd prefer to choose gear based on its discription (i.e. replace a rusty item with a sharp bejeweled one).  I hope the developers keep tweaking the game.  I want it to simulate what I may be able to do If I were the dungeon, it seems to be in that spirit.

Can I recommend it. Yes. Especially to those who want someting new.

DOTA, WOW, FPS addicts may have difficulty adapting.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo my friend let me play the game for a bit and I immediately saw a problem, tho small it is kind of annoying. The movement is tailored to your characters pov rather than the player. What I mean is that if your character is facing towards the top of your monitor, the controls will seem completely normal. However, the second your position or direction is changed all of your movement controls change suddenly and without warning. At first I had absolutely no idea what was going on because I was moving all over the place rather than where I wanted. Once I realized what was going on I understood but it did not make it easier. If you are used to every other game with awsd controls this game will confuse the living crap out of you and will be quite agitating unless you play it enough to get used to the controls, which depending on the person could take a short time to a long time. I actually hope this changes and it could be that the directional buttons and awsd would move you in the same directions every time regardless of your characters direction, I think that would make the game a lot easier to get into without the muscle memory getting in the way. Aside from that my only complaint is they need to make dual weilding a thing. I have no idea if it is planned or being looked into but I think it would be interesting to see. Maybe it would be hard to balance with the mechanics of this game but I would still like to see it. Other than those things I think this game is pretty good and has promise.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I found this Early Access on YouTube and was quite impressed. The combat seemed equally challenging as it was satisfying, and I basically bought it immediately. It's promising to see game developers, indie game devs at that, doing things that haven't been done recently, prying away from the bland, casual RPG's of late.

My first impression upon playing the game was the atmosphere, the music and the lighting give it such an eerie sense of danger. The learning curve is steep, so steep that I can hardly get passed the first four fighters or so in the arena, and yet, it is immensely satisfying when you pulverise an enemy within the first few seconds and collect some genuinely interesting loot to carry on to the next round. The combat is revolved entirely around the physics of the game, the harder you swing, the harder you hit, and it takes skill and patience to anticipate and react to your enemies movement.

It's safe to say I'll be supporting Bare Mettle throughout the development of this game, it has piqued my interest, and exerts endless potential.

Early Access Review

Massively Addicting!! Great Game!! Note: This game is still in EA Meaning Some Features are not included, Meaning Saving as well.. Knowing this this is a great game and Truely 1 of a kind! There is Literially NO GAME OUT THERE LIKE THIS.. And this is just a prelude of whats to come in Bare Mettles Games.. Combat, Movement, and down to ur physical Stature All Matter in the smallest thing.. My advice to new players is to play arena until u beat at least novice before trying the Story. Many of u may say why or what not, but i say because of combat u wont get it down in 1-2hrs or maybe even that day.. I trained in arena (after dying horribly multiple times on the first mob in story first), yeah u dont have to fight every mob but we new guys deff wanna try our luck against the first encounter lol that said after training in the arena for a day beating novice and expert, I found the dungeon to be quite challanging instead of impossible. still havent gotten through the 1rst floor but deff getting close!! I cant wait to see the Main game Sui Generis which will an open world rpg... Also i wanna note a few things that may help the new ppl in their travels
1. In Combat SpaceBar is ur BEST FRIEND use it often and u wont find urself directionally confused lol
2.Physical Stature matters in how strong and how fast u will be( so if ur a fat guy u maybe be in trouble lol idk havnt made a fat guy lol
3.armor is based on realisticly what ud wear. Would u wear 1 thing or would u layer ur clothing so ud be better protected
E.g. A belt may have some btter defense then a sash, but a sash has way more coverage then a belt does, so ur enemys have a less chance in exploiting the open points in ur armor.

Hope this helps.
Thanks bare mettle for an amazing game and cant wait for the main game!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh boy, where do I start? Okay, I'll keep this simple: Exanima is an amazing AMAZING dungeon-crawler type RPG. It ushers forth the feeling you get playing Diablo or Neverwinter Nights. Music/Graphics all are fitting and beautiful. I like the lighting style. Now the one thing that everyone says is difficult is the controls. In specific, combat. I can't blame them for feeling that way, but seeing how complex the system is makes me appreciate the game even more. As far as I know, it calculates EVERYTHING. And yes. That means it's more difficult. But you know what? I LOVE it. Every single battle you have to truly FOCUS and calculate. It's very strategic. And in fact, every battle results in sweaty palms. Every moment integral. It's immersing in a very amazing way. So yes. Battle controls take a while to learn effectively, but it's SUPPOSED to be complex. So it's a GOOD clunky! Dark Souls is easier in my opinion. But that's because battle is a simple mechanic to learn. Add in a few exploits, and bam. Dark Souls is easy. But the battles here.... Now that's REAL life and death.

EDIT: What about a simple lock on system? Because when I'm fighting someone IRL, I focus on them, and usually only them. Just an idea.

RATING: 11 controls out of 8

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unique and beautiful game engine for this genre that seems promising. Environment contains items that have more of a functional than window dressing feel. Physics-based fighting system requires some tweaking by the developers but has the potential to make each encounter unique and not a series of mouse clicks. It's also not as difficult to master as some claim. Just spend time in the arena and experiment.

Developers appear to be taking the same approach as Elite: Dangerous; start with a unique game engine and add content in response to player feedback. I would recommend buying the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The most promising early access game available to date and with a forseable completion date given by the developer there is no reason not to buy this game.

A real old school dungeon crawler with a twist. Exanima forces and rewards you for being perceptive and aware of your surroundings, with an emphasis on searching every room chest and corpse to either progress with a key or find beter gear. Without any sort of HUD (aside from a health and mana? bar) Exanima very much makes the player look around the room and with no hints to pick anything up it is very much up to the player to interact with their surroundings and pick up what they see.

Aside from being this old school game Exanima is very focussed on being a game with an emphasis on physics whether this be to determine how much damage you deal to an enemy as you bash their head in with a blunt object or to hold a lever down with a rock (or to fall over a twig) you must be constanntly thinking physics.While this may seem obscene as you stumble around falling into your enemy once gotten used to clearly adds a huge level of depth to the game.

As mentioned the physics play a big part in this games combat this also allows the combat to be very strategic and indepth as every strike you make could be made more effective with how you strike an enemy and with what weapon. On this note Exanima can be considered a very unforgiving game with at current no check points or save points this game will leave you contstanly on your toes with the determination to not sent back to the beginning. Some people may say this is bad but if you enjoy a hardcore game like Dark Souls then this game is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is tough. Exanima is hard. It's not for everyone. It's a very different kind of game. Different to what we've become used to.

That being said, what it is, is a lot of fun if you can get into it. Immerse yourself into a high risk dungeon crawler with purely physics based combat. The controls are clunky and take some getting used to but eventually something just clicks and things just work". At times I'll find myself frustrated that I can't understand how they work
date: cannot replicate something impressive that I did previously
recommended: and yet there's a certain joy to watching things play out differently every time.\n\nFights in Exanima are quite dynamic. As you tread down a gritty dungeon corridor the shambling form of some zombie or ghoul lurks up ahead. Having played other games you'd expect it to lurch forwards to attack. Not in Exanima. While some of the foes are automatically hostile others stop to size you up
hoursPlayed: decide if you're a threat or if they think they can take you on. Many's the time a shambling bag of bones takes one look and thinks better of it. They shuffle off in another direction.\n\nDo not try to kill everything. Attack everything and you die. Health will not generally replenish without healing items (which are few and far between). Attacks can cause lethal damage or nonlethal damage. One regenerates naturally. The other does not. Armour doesn't reduce damage so much as it transforms percentages of lethal damage into nonlethal (and then reduces the total a bit as well). Fights in Exanima are visceral
voteText: gritty and nasty. Fortunately most of them are avoidable. Patrolling ghouls can be lured into empty rooms and then the doors shut upon them
helpfulPercent:
locking them in.

To begin with darkness will be your greatest enemy. Take the torch. The torch brings light. Unfortunately it also brings it's own problems. When one hand is occupied with the torch it cannot also be used to bear a shield or assist in the use of a two handed weapon. Enemies thrive in the dark. In the earlier portions of the game you'll really need the torch to see where you're going.

The game also currently features an Arena mode to hone your fighting skills. This is quite a popular feature with many players although I have yet to fully master it.

While this game is still in Early Access it's been quite a positive experience. The devs are supporting it with updates. More features are planned. Some of these have already been implemented. There should be a list on the game's store page. Overall I'd highly recommend this game if you like difficult challenges that feel very rewarding but are hard to master."

This game is epic. I played a game year ago similar to this and this one comes out on top easy while keeping all the same elements. Right now there are two game mods, both are amazing.

First off you have the adventure Story" mode. In this mode you spawn with nothing but the clothes on your back. You see a torch and grab it since it's really your only light source and possibly the only things you got to smack something with. With that you head off in a physics based adventure. My first task was trying to open up the door without knocking myself down when I smacked my face with it. In good time I managed to get the door open and head down a hallway. I saw a lot of these hallways and got lost everytime I've been in them. I could only remember the first two doors

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima,

Where do I start...? I followed this game via Kickstarter a couple of years ago now. And whilst the team are behind schedule in terms of development, they are way ahead of the industry in terms of intuivity, innovation and most importantly listening to the customers/backers/followers/fanatics...

The first thing to happen when you play this game, you will die, and at times you will feel you have done enough to vanquish your opponent, let me tell you the game doen't lie!

Armored opponents will take stamina damage... Unless you hit them in the cracks of their armor and you will see a spray of blood, this is more satisfying than I am describing. If you bring a heavy weapon down on their helmet, their legs will buckle and I can't remember if I read this on the forums or not, but will make them very aggressive and clumsy for a few seconds (concussion).

Attacks feel random, but they are not, its your movement, cursor position and mouse clicks that are at fault. Side step an attack, perform a counter on a off balance enemy and you will send him hurtling across the room buying yourself some valuable space. You will soon learn how to feint and riposte in this strikingly accurate portrayal of medieval/fantasy combat.

Don't get me wrong, there are weird little bugs sometimes (very rare) and some things do need balancing. But the combat draws away from the main idea behind this game, they hope to acheive an RPG never seen before in terms of freedom. And if you are really serious about purchasing this game, I advise you to check out the videos on the official website, they will give you an idea of the mechanics and how interesting this game can truly be.

When I backed this I spent £60 because I believed in it so much, for £9.99 it's a steal...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

$12.74USD is a great price as the game is on sale. I missed the kickstarter, but within an hour in, I can safely say combat is the most satisfying top down experience I’ve had. Unlike other games where animation is just that, this really relates to the overall gameplay. Also, as a roguelike dungeon crawler this is by far my favorite because instead of rooms filled with disposable enemies, every enemy so far has felt like an up and personal combat experience, making every victory meaningful as the next can lead to death.

Things I love right now--
+Camera movement helps maneuver environment.
+Survival Horror created by fear of dying and atmosphere.
+Controls are very easy to learn.
+Arena Combat is a quick starting point.
+Smart AI that can be fairly battled.
+Unique Physics.
+Environment can be used for combat.

Issues I have right now:

-my wrist is killing me, so I hope the #steam #controller will fix the no controller support.
-for some reason “action” doesn’t recognize this as a directX game.
-can’t bring in a buddy (listed in the soon to come features).
-missing sword styles per sword, at current each sword seems to have one style.
See http://elf-comic.thecomicseries.com/comics/9. or witcher series.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great game.
The control system, while seemingly unwieldy at first, is the best example of analogue physics-based combat I have seen. It has seemed for a while can either have serious, move-based combat or physics-based combat (The results being Chivalry: Medieval Warfare and Toribash, both of which I have enjoyed). However, this game has cracked (mainly) the inverse kinematics necessary to make your movements both free and realistic. there is a great sense of weight and you find yourself identifying weak points and opportunities. The spiked wood - barrel lid combination has done me well, but knocking craetures senseless with a two-handed iron pole is also fun. Graphics are perfect for the combat, with a bit of blood staining clothes and hair. Not as unecessarily gory as it could have been (See previous games mentioned), just enough for a realistic experience.
Arena mode and campaign highly recommended.

The concept of this game is great -- if you ever played Die by the Sword, you might see some similarities.
The combat is tough to learn and pretty punishing at times, as you make one wrong move or time swing, and that's it, fatal blow.
The gameplay itself feels pretty polished, what it lacks are the features, saves etc.
I'd like to see some additions to the combat like swinging angles
Overall, another original concept that I hope will continue in it's development - as this could be a great finished product

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WARNING!!! DO NOT BUY IF YOU HAVEN'T GOT ANY PATIENCE, BECAUSE THIS GAME HAS A STEEP LEARNING CURVE!
HELPFUL TIPS (if you bought the game) :
1) go to the arena and find out what weapon you are most comfortable with ( i highly suggest 2h sword )
2) beat arena at least on novice ( i recommend beating expert too, by the time you do it you will probably understand how to hit things)
3) when you start the main game get the barrel lid in the room where you start ( it will function as a SHIELD )

THOUGHTS ABOUT THE GAME:
I honestly cannot believe i already spent more than 10 hours into this game. At the beginning i hated it, because i kept dying every 5 minutes , but after a couple of hours i have completed arena on expert and almost beat the main piece of the game.
At first i thought that the combat system is clunky and characters do seem to act like a bunch of drunks but there is something about this game that is just charming.
I do love the sound of clashing weapons, the sound of weapons hitting flesh and armored parts, the overall design and theme of this game, and ,SUDDENLY, the combat system too (but only after figuring out how to hit things).
This game has potential and i'm really looking forward to see what will this game evolve into.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is really cool. Your positioning and facing matter, as does the types of weapons and armour you're using as far as speed and effectiveness are concerned. The controls do take awhile to get used to and can seem janky, but you need to pay attention to your mouse positioning and the positioning of the enemies around you.

I also find it easier to avoid the drunk lurching by changing the dash to double tap instead of holding a key down. This can be done in the settings menu.

Definitely recommended to check it out, it's not quite like anything else I've played.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Think Dark Souls with an isometric style top-down view. In this game you have to think and use the environments to your advantage.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=azRkfGP-Vfw

Explore, fight, survive and unravel mysteries in this unique and unforgiving 3D isometric RPG set in an original dark, low fantasy world. Exanima's exceptional attention to detail and realistic simulation of all things aim to provide a deeply immersive and dynamic gameplay experience.

Features include a deep skill based combat system, complex and smart AI, fully interactive environments, an advanced damage model with accurate collisions and locational protection, roguelike elements and an arena mode to hone your combat skills. -  Recommended!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAre you tired of games with tight, responsive, easy to learn controls? Then here's the game for you!  Play this top down dungeon crawler with no character progression beyond picking up discarded junk in a dusty room or off a luckily slain zombie.  Control a character as graceful as the guy from QWOP with a piece of wood stuck to his hand! Getting chased by zombies"? don't worry you won't have to run for long once your character trips and falls on their face over one of the hundreds of pieces of clutter or even just by scraping a wall with their boot!  Who needs progress? finally a game where you can not save and you can listen to your character scream blarg! at the same time as you when they die from spinning 180 in a fight and being beaten to death by a gangly man (zombie?) with a bit of wood."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In a few words…Fresh, Unique, Challenging, Fun.

Exanima stands high above any other iso rpg I have played. I’m not a reviewer by any means but a job well done deserves mention.

Firstly, be prepared to spend some time learning the game, there are game modes that cater to this.
Once you get acquainted with the controls the fun really begins. Every hit is registered on the body part it strikes, you can see your opponents head snap sideways or their sword react to blocking a blow. On a very strong hit, their knees actually buckle. Speed and power can be added to your attacks with certain mouse movement as well as stepping into attacks.

Some notes on combat. There is a magic formula of audio feedback and character movement/reaction that makes things feel very organic. You can intuitively tell the difference between a hard hit and a glancing hit. Combat is unrelenting and intense, especially when you are down on health and can’t afford to take another hit.

The dungeons are very dark, and well designed the one torch you get is your friend. Things are laid out with very distinct areas; workshops, living quarters, taverns etc. all of which are meticulously laid out and eerily vacant. Exploring the levels takes time but you are rewarded with finding items which otherwise may be missed.
Despite being early access, the game runs very smoothly and has a polished look. I applaud the Devs for perfecting the system over adding content.

Exanima will not hold your hand, it’s meant to be a challenge, but the greater the challenge the greater the satisfaction when you come out the other side.

Early Access Review

If you like tight corridors, using only your wits and what you find on the floor to stay alive, and being alone in a maze filled with undead that can kill you just as quickly as you can kill them, you might like this game alot. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I raged hard when I first got my buttoms handed to me, but man, after a while you sink into this world of dread and remorse . It's horrifying, it's challenging and keeps you on your toes at all times.

Early Access? Does not feel that way. I played my 6 hours straight, without any pause inbetween. I barely can imagine what the full version will look like. Most of them all, I remember the quiet hours in small, dark cellars, the crackling sound of my torch and the quiet steps of the horror that was waiting infront of the door, which I was blocking with the help of a chair.

Forget le edgy Dark Souls - this game pairs realism with a dreadful world filled with horror.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well Jeeeeesus christ. This game take your will smother it under an especially fat hippopotamus and tear bits of it off and mash it and thrust it into a furnace, and it feels so good. If you already like the look of this game, just get it. I'm positive you'll enjoy it.

Okay, okay. Look. I have to reccomend this game with a grain of salt large enough to choke a pigeon. It's harder than nails. It's tougher than bolts. It's so brutal that I would call it criminally insane in it's persual of killing you. This game is brilliant in a really really quirky way, and I love it. And I've beaten all of the different modes. But it took me at least 8 hours of straight up combat to get anywhere decent with the combat system.

This game requires a really healthy dose of patience, because if you ask me it's unnecessarily difficult. You'll swing and a miss and get whacked real good and lose a quarter of your health to lethal damage. Feels awful, any non-lethal damage heals back pretty quickly, but now you have to fight forever onward with three quarters health. Perma-death is on.

Y'know what feels amazing though? Drunkenly slaughtering your way through a half of a horde of zombies while locking the other half in bathrooms, because you realized they're stupid enough to do that. Sprinting down a hall barely doging the reinforcements put there just to trip you up and then slamming the door at the end of the hallway in the face of your persuer. Lifting a basket, and finding holy ♥♥♥♥ a leather vest thank the gods I have something other than a t-shirt to protect me. Nervously cracking a door, seeing a dark menacing figure standing in pitch black on the other side, then slamming it in his face as you hear him sprint against it whacking it repeatdly with his chair leg. Dodging in and out of swings against a dangerous opponent slicing his kneecap off and just barely having time to block his furious counter-attack. Using something other than wood debris to kill someone.

Trust me, this is a game of many frustraitons. But so is Dark Souls, Spelunky, and Hotline Miami. I bet those took you a while to get used to. Just, y'know. Practice in the arena.

You'll do fine.

I'm sure.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've 68 hours logged in this psuedo game and I'm pretty obsessed with it still. The physics based combat is a real challenge, and honestly a fun challenge. The first thing I did was fight my way through the Novice Arena, then Expert. Expert took me a long time to beat. Each opponent has their own quirks besides the unique physical contraints of their chosen weapon. Once you can reliably beat the Expert Arena, you'll have a false sense of confidence going into the real game. A say false, because the arena is this lovely well lit open space with the same opponents attacking you the same way each time you face them. The real game has dozens of objects in each room that can trip you up, doors that can tie up your sword arm or foul your weapons strike, and randomly patrolling zombies that can double or triple team you when you least expect them to. Narrow corridors and other tight spaces make swinging two handed weapons a crap shoot. And yes, sometimes (rarely) the engine itself will let you down and you'll find yourself stuck to a wall for seemingly no reason during a fight. This is why, despite the devs intentions and some players' strong feelings on the matter, I do suggest using the savescum method on occasion so you don't have to start all over again when something really stupid happens.

With a simple escape-the-dungeon crawl being this fun, I can't wait until they patch the quirks and add in all the other features like theurmaturgy, ranged weapons, weapon thrusts and other techniques. Oh yeah, and release the real game. If you missed the kickstarter like me, this is a good way to support the devs and still get a fun playable game out of it immediately.

Early Access Review

This game is possibly the most challenging game I have played to date. The combat system is unforgiving. A single mistake can mean the difference between you winning or instantly dying and having to start over from the very beginning. Would I recommend this game? Yes. See, this game and I have a love hate relationship right now. I'm still not quite used to the combat system, and as such have not ventured into the story mode just yet. As I said, the combat is unforgiving. At the same time, however, it is the best combat system I have seen in action so far this year.

Overall, I would rate this game as such :

Difficulty: 10/10
Fun: 7.5/10
Replayability: 10/10
Chance of making you go bat-♥♥♥♥ insane: 10000000/10

All in all, for 12 bucks this game is definitely worth it. Unless of course you would rather play something easy like Dark Souls or some other such nonsense.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The atmosphere is dark and it’s gritty. The tooth and nail combat is unforgiving. Never before have I experienced an RPG that has catapulted me so far into the zone of helplessness. There are times in the story mode when I will catch a look of my reflection in my monitor and my jaw is on the floor, filled with suspense at what might lurk in the dark beyond. Equally exciting are the times in the arena when I will take a hit to the back of the head with a sledgehammer, after which I vocalize my avatar’s pain. The controls only add to the suspense as I spend a lot of my brain-power calculating where I can shuffle back to if a particular hostile starts swinging. Having the room to fight is always nice. I have been in fights that reflect the drunken brawls that many report as blades clink and clang against the walls of narrow corridors. Sometimes the fights are messy as baddies take chunks out of each other in an attempt to reach me.

It is clear to me that there is a group of people who are going to play this game for under 10 hours and call it quits and I understand where they are coming from. I often find myself exiting the game out of frustration because there are so many variables at play. Even so, the 12 hours I have spent in Exanima has been the most rewarding time I have spent in a video game in my entire life as far as combat is concerned. I started out feeling hopeless, and after 12 hours of practice I have garnered hope. So far, the story is lacking, and that’s fine. In my opinion this is an amazingly sugarcoated tech-demo that is allowing me to check out a physics engine and combat system that was built from scratch. And as everyone knows, cookies made from scratch beat the living ♥♥♥♥ out of that store-bought crap.

Buy this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a fun, very tough and unique game. I haven't been this excited by combat in a game since I first played Dark Souls. I spent the first 5 hours swinging my weapon around like an idiot in the arena. After a while, it paid off nicely. I ended up whacking a guy in the face with an axe and knocking him over. When he tried to get back up, I did it again and then finished him off with an overhead swing.

The arena seems the best place to start, since the story mode itself is permadeath. I wish more games had an arena mode instead of a tutorial, It was a really fun way to learn.

The game will feel unfair at first until you notice your enemies are often just as clumsy as you are. It will probably take you a few hours to learn how to fight and who knows how long to master. It’s worth it though, because it’s so satisfying when you land hits; you can feel the weight behind them.

Once you get the hang of combat, it's time to try the story mode, which presents a whole new challenge. From what I have seen so far, the story itself is hidden in notes and other things around the levels. I prefer this to the big flashy 20 minute cut scene, which shows you something you could of figured out on your own in only two.

Over all I would say the graphics are good. It has a dark atmosphere to it that really suits the game. The sound and music also go a long way to adding to the eerie atmosphere. The crunch of your weapons when you land a hit is just perfect and makes landing those hits all the more satisfying. For a early access game it runs beautifully, even on my outdated and pretty bad laptop.

It reminded me of Dark Souls even though it is a very different game. I like very much being reminded of Dark Souls ^_^

I bought this for the full price and I'm glad I did, which is rare these days. I can’t wait to see where it goes from here and I highly recommend giving it a shot if it seems like your kind of game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Diablo meets Dark Souls

ambient game full of endless tunnels.
zombies, caretakers and skeletons
all able to kill you in a whim.
the true meaning of an endless bottomless box.

this game had me searching every nook and cranny
of every room i came across just to try and find
keys that lead to more searching.
the foreboding and dread i felt playing Exanima
was a real treat.
the fear of what lies around the next corner,
or what creature wanted to smash my skull in
gave for a real feel of despair in this dungeon.

ppl will complain about the combat, and after
my first hour i was ready to fumble thru the dungeon and
get an experience of it. but after 3hrs i feared nothing,
well almost.

the joys of exploring and watching your back for
unsuspecting attackers was quite exilerating.
and whats more it never gets old.
the feel of Exanima flows really well all the way thru the game.

perseverance thru the (so called) crappy combat system
will yeild such awsome rewards. and like in dark souls - at 1st its
a nightmare but once you get the hang of it you will wonder what
every one was complaining about...

spoiler their are healing potions :-O

so what ppl say is true... its dam hard
the combat system is wonky (broken to the nonpersistent)
-but after a little effort you become a god, slaying all in your path-

lots of fun, cant wait for a full release and a hell of a bargain for $15

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A revolutionary physics based combat system, never seen before in any game. A combat system that makes you think, and takes MANY hours of practice to learn! Exanima is the prelude to SUI GENERIS. 100% recommend!

PROS:
-An original physics based combat system that you've never experienced before
-Most satisfying combat when you actually overcome your opponent
-Physics affects everything, move objects, see them flip. Trip over boards, bodies, or chairs. Physics AFFECT gameplay, and combat! Your opponent can get his spear stuck on a wall, object, etc but that means SO CAN YOURS.
-Runs and performs great on lower end systems.
-Weapons each have their own strengths, weaknesses, ranges and damage capabilities.
-Armor really affects combat
-Graphics and lighting are great
-Fun Arena where you can practice fighting opponents and learn the game.

CONS:
-Learning curve is HIGH for the game, combat and controls
-Clipping issues in the game, such as getting stuck on objects (still Alpha)
-Lacks Tutorials in game at this time, but probably will be in for release
-No save game feature, this is for the hardcore - However if you exit the game when alive, you can continue where you left off. Your save gets wiped when you die!
-Camera/Controls could use refinement,

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To sum it up this game is a gem! One of those games that comes out of no where to remind me why I love games!

At first I had some trouble figuring out the movement, and it was quite frustrating. But I kept coming back for more
and practiced in the arena until I beat novice and expert mod.

I'm a huge fan of games like chivalry, Mount and blade, and dark souls. I love good melee combat in a game, I think this game might have some of the best and most realistic feeling melee combat I've been dreaming of. Once you get used to the controls, you feel like you're really in charge. It's super satisfying to step in and out of range while taking swings and then landing a blow on a zombies face and watch their head snap back with blood spraying out.

Get this game if you're a hard core gamer, love a challenge, and are willing to stick with things until you get the hang of it. The pay off will be more than worth it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a fun, very tough and unique game. I haven't been this excited by combat in a game since I first played Dark Souls. I spent the first 5 hours swinging my weapon around like an idiot in the arena. After a while, it paid off nicely. I ended up whacking a guy in the face with an axe and knocking him over. When he tried to get back up, I did it again and then finished him off with an overhead swing.

The arena seems the best place to start, since the story mode itself is permadeath. I wish more games had an arena mode instead of a tutorial, It was a really fun way to learn.

The game will feel unfair at first until you notice your enemies are often just as clumsy as you are. It will probably take you a few hours to learn how to fight and who knows how long to master. It’s worth it though, because it’s so satisfying when you land hits; you can feel the weight behind them.

Once you get the hang of combat, it's time to try the story mode, which presents a whole new challenge. From what I have seen so far, the story itself is hidden in notes and other things around the levels. I prefer this to the big flashy 20 minute cut scene, which shows you something you could of figured out on your own in only two.

Over all I would say the graphics are good. It has a dark atmosphere to it that really suits the game. The sound and music also go a long way to adding to the eerie atmosphere. The crunch of your weapons when you land a hit is just perfect and makes landing those hits all the more satisfying. For a early access game it runs beautifully, even on my outdated and pretty bad laptop.

It reminded me of Dark Souls even though it is a very different game. I like very much being reminded of Dark Souls ^_^

I bought this for the full price and I'm glad I did, which is rare these days. I can’t wait to see where it goes from here and I highly recommend giving it a shot if it seems like your kind of game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Physics. You will want to play this game for it's physics, although your character seems to sometimes have issues with face planting. The lighting is also very pretty. The actual gameplay is unforgivingly hard. I mean like lost souls hard, but with perma-death tacked on top of that. If you die, you start over at the beginning. No save points, no check points, no quicksave. The devs seem firm on keeping it this way, and that's a shame, because the game has a lot got a lot going for it and 90% of the players will never take the time to experience it. I've been using the 'save game' hack from the community forums to create artificial save points, which, trust me, only gives me a fighting chance.

You will need to play in Arena mode for hours to get the combat down. How you swing matters as much as what you swing. I'd recommend reading a how to combat" FAQ before playing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've never written a review, so it's already a testament to this game that I would write one.  This is categorized as positive because of its polish, but I personally feel negative about the game.

It's difficult to describe; honestly, I don't think this game is that good.  After seven hours, I think it has a brilliant concept that is flawed in execution.  It has an absolute AMAZING idea going with its combat.   That AMAZING idea is pretty crap in execution.

The combat is, and I think all posters will agree, ♥♥♥♥ing insane.  It's fun.  It really is.  But you will die . . . and die . . . and die.  You click and attempt to hit the enemy.  They block.  They swing.  You definitely can block, but you move slow.  Your movements have weight.  Has the weight of your swings and movements been balanced for maximum fun?  I don't think so, not yet.

I'll admit: seven hours in and I can't defeat the novice arena (a training area).  Anyone who tries to compare this to Mount and Blade is wrong--there you could at least go PvP and end out on top after seven hours.  That is not your situation here.

Here, you have been roofied and sent into an arena.  Your drunken arms flail about as they attempt to roll dice to keep you alive.  As you get better, your roll better dice.  Nonetheless, you roll dice.  It's HARD to come out on top of the AI.  (You don't roll actual dice.  It just feels random.)

Despite my negativity, I think I'll buy Sui Generis in the end (the game this is the prelude to).  I will especially if there is co-op multiplayer.  But I think it will all fail economically.  Why?  Because people play games to be heroes, not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who get beat down like an AI bot after five minutes.  Most of my friends can't stand this game, and I predict many people won't want to play this game.  It puts the developer in a difficult spot: do you stay true to vision, or do you try to make a living?

I predict the game in its current state--and Sui Generis--either can't stay as it is or will be a commercial flop.  That said, I think I'll be one of the people who tries to make it NOT be a commercial flop.

Yeah, I begrudgingly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great game for someone looking for a unique experience. The difficultly is based on how you play the game.  It's actually pretty easy if you play an absolute coward. I managed to beat the 3 available levels naked by running away from everything- didn't even need a health potion.

If you want to be brave and fight, you should still try to avoid conflict during the first level. By the time you reach the third level, you should have enough gear to prevent most permanent damage. Combat takes awhile to get used to as well. I recommend using two-handed weapons since it is easier to keep your distance from the enemies and avoid double clicking.

The game still needs quite a bit of work and is pretty short. My character got hung up on the walls frequently while fighting, and it is difficult to equip a weapon while fleeing from an angry zombie (hotkeys please). I also wish the camera would zoom in more on the character- keys are very difficult to see currently when playing on a laptop screen. I also feel the game could use more variety in the environment. I had big issues with running around in circles since many areas look similiar and there is no map. The last thing the game could use is more balance in the difficulty of the first level. The beginning of the game was very repetitive and frustrating from all of the dying. A second checkpoint could help prevent that.

If those negatives scare you, you may want to wait before buying the game, but definitely check back in a few months or year. Even with its faults, it is fun and shows great potential- co-op would be amazing in a game like this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have to say, as someone who has always loved the isometric, DnD-esk RPG, Exanima does it well. It's been a long while since I last went for an early access game as the system is too often abused, but I am glad that I gave Exanima a shot. While it is clear that the game is still missing that last bit of spit-and-polish (it is an early access game after all!) the core mechanics, atmosphere, and overall player interaction clearly show that a lot of time when into the development process.

The mechanics are such a suprising delight and demonstrate an agreeable direction for the natural progression of the core mechanics introduced years ago and seen in many dungeon-crawl/baulder's gate type games. Adding a new depth of interaction and the corresponding introduction of a physics-based world will set this game apart from those it draws inspiration from and defintely prove satisfying for years to come. I still need to put many more hours in to fully grasp the interface, but just from a short test drive I can tell there's not only depth to the mechanics, but unlike many rougelikes or action RPG types that typically rely on mastery of a cheese-strat, this is appreciable, rewarding depth. There's just so much for the player to work with both in and out of combat.

The atmosphere was a pleasant suprise as well, as those degrees of consideration tend to get backburnered for a large portion of the development. Textures looked good both from far away and up close, character development was wonderfully, needlessly complex, and being dropped into the world with just a torch, wandering very confused, and getting immediately killed by the literal first enemy set the tone that the world of Exanima is not to be taken lightly.

All in all, at this point, I would certainly recommend trying this game out. The mechanics are deep, the world seems legit, and to top it off the developers seem to genuinely care about their product. For the last point alone I think that's worth some weight as steam is far too riddled with developers" selling asset-flipped garbage for $15 a pop.

TL;DR
Recommend it. I am genuinely excited to see where this game (and developer) goes in the future."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Adventure or try your hand at merciless permadeath as the world's clumbsiest human!


In short, this game is an amazingly fun and quite challenging to master! (I haven't mastered it yet)
It is essentially an isometric combat game in lieu of diablo, but the combat is based entirely on physics. You have to carefully maneuver and swing your weapon about. Left clicking makes a swing, but you still need to amplify the swing by moving the mouse. Alternate attacks are possible, such as stabbing and overhead, but keep in mind that your entire body is a physics object, meaning I literally tripped over a corpse while fighting! It's nearly impossible to describe but truly, truly groundbreaking, and worth playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all I am not an avid reviewer so this won't be such a thorough review, that aside I have to say this game is an amazing concept I have long been waiting for up to the point where I wanted to make a game like this myself!

Also note that THIS IS A EARLY ACCESS!!!! The game isn't full finished, they rolled it out to gain more support for the games development, think of it as beta testing (Alpha rather...).

Pros:

- Baldur's Gate / Diablo / Champions of Norath feel to the game (aside from the combat)
- Amazing Graphics and Engine very smooth performance
- Combat was great (does need work though)
- Dark and creepy atmoshpere leaves you feeling alone and lost like Dark Souls
- Medieval theme (just love this era)
- Is being updated steadily

Cons:
- Not a complete game (While the game was fun I found it disappointing when there wasn't a lot of content at launch)
- Not being able to save a created character or save in general
- Wonky animations (though for a physics based game very good it can be comical at times and throws you out of the immersion)
- Character creation is very limited
- No randomly generated maps to keep things interesting (gets boring when you expect whats ahead)
- Only two gamemodes (lets hope the add more things)




Those are the main highlights of my cons and pros, the other things I have yet to disclose are just minor things that have occured to me but I have a feeling will be fixed as time progresses. Aside from the cons those are problems that can be fixed on future updates and it doesn't really kill the experience for me but it can be frustrating at times. I wish the developers some luck and support because I love the idea they have for this game. It has soooo much potential I recommend this game as it can become the greatest RPG yet! We may eventually get workshop support and maybe multiplayer? Who knows what they have in store guys!!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is like an isometric Dark Souls with a unique physics-based combat system. If you're a fan of the Soul series' atmosphere and high learning curve, you'll probably be a fan of Exanima. Its combat is visceral and despite the rather unintuitive controls, actually very realistic. In all likelihood, you'll probably spend your first few hours in Arena mode learning how to manage distance and timing as well as how to utilize your weapon's weight and momentum. Admittedly though, the camera will probably be your biggest enemy. I don't know why the devs felt like the camera shouldn't snap to your character's back during combat, because most of your fights will be between you, your foes, and the camera. You will be tapping that spacebar. A lot.

While I can't fully recommend Exanima in its current state since it seems to be missing a lot of ease-of-life features, it seems like the final product has a lot of potential. Exanima is definitely a game to keep your eye on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very promising game.

The controls may feel a bit wonky at first but as you get more comfortable it all makes sense.
Definitely one for the more persistent gamer that expects a challenge. Getting comfortable with the hurdles provided by the combat system is a must so your first destination should be the arena.

I love the combat system because it makes every fight mater and death is never far away ;)

Very realistic fighting , movement , reactions and physics. The graphics are detailed and look really nice.
Good music , realistic sound effects.
Overall a lot of attention to detail and love is in this game.

I have no qualms in recommending this game based on the combat system alone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is definitely in a place now that I can recommend buying it.  It has a wonderfully dark and challenging story mode, and a great arena mode wherein you pit your created fighters against AI to make money and raise your fighters abilitity to use better weapons.

The combat is hard.  I recommend turning down your mouse sensitivity for this game because you will end up losing track of the cursor while trying to alternate between swinging your weapon and keeping your guard up.

Another feature I love about this game is the AI.  If you encounter another person in the dungeon, and give them space without attacking or getting too close, they become accustomed" to your presence and will not attack.  Certain AI will attack you no matter how carefully you approach them
date: but it adds a whole other element to the game
recommended: where you need to try to judge whether or not you should attack.\n\nThe looting is fantastic as well.  Doors and items placed around can be manipulated with the mouse
hoursPlayed: which is extremely satisfying

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is quite amazing and unique, also hilarious if you know what to do.
You start off fumbling like an idiot until you learn the weird somewhat complicated controls, you spend a few hours getting ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as you flail your your little noodly arms at all the zombie people, giving them hugs as they slide their weapons into your flesh.

After a while you start to learn how to use your legs, you're able to keep a safe distance now but still manage to keep yourself within range of the enemy for you to rush in and attack, but oh no, all your blows are being blocked, you must learn how to use those puny limp little arms of yours. You rush in and do an overhead swing, they block and try to swing, you back away. You use your small metal spike and do an alt attack while rushing, you get them in the gut right as they get ready to swing again, there blow is stopped by the side of your jiggly body as you press your spike in. You freak out as they continue to try and swing, your limbs are entangled now, it almost looks sensual as the enemy writhes about between your legs, eventually they are on the floor unable to get up for a moment, you manage to step away and remember the game has a crouch function, you crouch over him and repeatedly stab him in the eye with your spike.
You have just sodomized and brutally killed a man carrying a bedpan, congrats.
You steal his clothes and equip his bedpan, and continue on.

Next you see a person with their back to you, they are carrying a two handed sword that can obviously ruin your day.
Next to that man you see a bucket, you remember you can move things around so you pick up the bucket and adjust it so it falls on his head. He doesn't care, you move past him and get startled as he begins to move, instead of attacking he instead bugs out as the bucket falls through him, removing his hair and trapping his arms, he starts flying around the room with the bucket wrapped around his waist, his sword still in hand, he flys by and kicks you in the head, knocking you down. Amused and terrified you try to get up and leave, but no, the bucket decides that you aren't going anywhere and it throws itself at you, slamming you into the door, your hand gets jammed in the door but you take no damage.
The bucket finally stops flinging the man around, instead spinning him on the ground behind you, getting closer, the blade still in the mans hand knicks your leg, you realise you're absolutely screwed, watch in horror as a spinning man with a bucket around him slashes at your legs until you bleed to death.

Fun game, extremely unique, get it in Early Access while you can still turn into a breakdancer using a bucket.
It's a rare glitch but it works, just drop a bucket on your head.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been following this since the initial kickstarter and have nothing but great things to stay. Updates aren't as fast as other games but they are always great and worth the wait. There is so much fun to have with what is currently available.

An issue people may have is the learning curve. This game plays unlike any game you've ever played before. This might be difficult for some people to adjust to. Once you do it is some of the best fun you will ever have.

I have nothing but high expectations for the final game and absolutely no reason to believe the devs won't meet them. They have proven over the past couple years to be extremely dedicated, sincere, and open to community feedback.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Truly innovative, in-depth, and immersive.
I decided to pick up this game because of the heavily physics-based combat and intriguing story mode, and was very impressed once I got the hang of it. I pride myself for being terrible at games in general, but this one really makes you want to imrpove your playstyle and it demands practice. The vast majority of the negative reviews I've read feature complaints about this aspect of the game and talk about the clunkiness(?)" that comes from the control features and I feel obligated to point out that the "clunkiness" is a result of Little Sister Video Game Syndrome (LSVGS); you know when your little sister wanted to try out that FPS she saw you playing? Remember when you introduced her to the concept of looking around in a 3D world with a control stick (or mouse) and it just baffled her and she couldn't quite get the hang of looking around so she decided to strafe until her crosshairs met something she wanted to shoot? All of us experienced some kind of control barrier with games (especially 3D ones) before we got the hang of them. This game is incredibly innovative and that innovation introduces control mechanics that are simply new.

I don't think a pro/con list does any video game justice so I'll leave you with this:

Exanima is a prelude to an ambitious project

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While far from perfect, this game is a breath of fresh air for anyone looking for a complex and realistic combat system in action RPGs.
As far as i know this is the first game ever to have an entirely physics based movement AND combat system. (Even walking is simulated, which means you can trip over stuff and taste the delicious ground and makes for many hilarious moments)
Swordfighting feels absolutely amazing once you get the hang of it (As a veteran of mount and blade, chivalry and dark souls it took me about 2 hours, it might take much longer without experience in at least some of these games)
The dungeons are extremely athmospheric and, combined with great light and shadow effects, provide a claustrophobic, creepy maze for you to find your way through.
If you enjoy the exploration and mystery of dark souls and the realistic combat of games like mount and blade warband this title is at least worth keeping an eye on.
Also you can wear a bucket on your head and body check enemies. 10/10
If you usually only play softcore titles like assassins creed and enjoy that kind of combat or are looking for something like Diablo/PoE STAY AWAY from this one, you will be frustrated and you will hate it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Examina has an extremely unique combat system, and in some ways, Examina's system is better than all other existing ones.

As I understand it, there's a few popular existing ways to model medieval combat:
-Directional Blocking: Mount & Blade Warband, Kingdom Come Deliverance (not released). You can attack and block in a number of directions. Fights between skilled players can look quite ridiculous as players spin, feint, and jump. Mount & Blade: Warband is my favorite game ever, but its combat system is not exactly realistic.
-Chivalry Medieval Warfare's system: Regardless of direction, blocking is dependent upon timing. Skilled players do unrealistic things like jumping and angle their swings in ludicrous ways that drastically affect the time that their blow lands. It's a good system, but experienced players use extremely gimmicky tactics like the aforementioned angling of swings.
-The Assassin Creed/Witcher/Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor's system: This system of combat is set up for a really strong protagonist that can take on legions of enemies. While it requires a degree of skill in the timing, it's not realistic (leaving an enemy to your back is a fatal mistake, even if you're a brilliant fighter). Nonetheless, it's a functional system for the types of game the use it; just don't make a game using this system if you want it to have good multiplayer combat or realism.
-Mindless hack and slash, Skyrim's system: Awful! Skyrim's combat does not entail any real skill. It is the least rewarding of any of the above mentioned system in my humble opinion.

Exanima, on the other hand, is extremely unique and one of the more realistic systems. Examina:
+ Takes into account forward and lateral movement into weapon damage better than any system
+ Takes into account weapon alignment/accuracy" better than any other system. To elaborate
date: if you hit someone with the shaft of your polehammer they'll shrug it off
recommended: if you nail their helmet with the head of your polehammer they'll be hurt badly. This means that if you are right in front of your enemy and they have a pole weapon they can't really hit you- which is a good thing
hoursPlayed: because it wasn't possible in reality. This advantage of Examina is perhaps entirely unique; unlike Chivalry
voteText: Assassin's Creed
helpfulPercent: or Warband
votesHelpful: if you aren't the correct distance from your enemy in Exanima and you hit them with the shaft of your poleaxe you won't do any damage.\n+ Semi-Realistic treatment of plate armor; slashing weapons do not cut
votesTotal: but only impart the damage done by the  impact of the weapon (plate armor will treat an enemy's sword as blunt)\n+ Doesn't have bull ♥♥♥♥ gimmicks in combat. Every tactic you can employ in Examina could also be employed in real life (probably). Beating your opponent in Examina relies upon timing your attacks when your opponent can't parry (because they're starting to attack)
votesFunny: feinting

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a great shame that this title hasn't received the exposure warranted by its innovative combat mechanics and ambitious environmental interactions. Unfortunately, I suspect that the game is frequently overlooked as just another Diablo clone, due to isometric camera and dungeon-bound settings, when nothing could be further from the truth. The reality is that this is an old-school style dungeon crawler that places emphasis on survival rather than running around and popping loot-balloons masquerading as enemies. Additionally, the combat is less about spamming LMB than offering an almost-Mount-and-Blade level of sword-fighting finesse.

Hopefully, as the devs approach the final build the game still start getting the recognition it deserves. It most certainly deserves it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

v. 52--------------------------------
Alright, so they've changed the game up a bit: Namely, you don't walk quite as funny anymore. What a letdown, eh? Less booze before battle.
Anyway, I've got some more time on the game now, but my previous comment still stand, with the addendum that combat is more realistic than I thought. It's not just about letting your character swing their weapon when you hold down the mouse button! You actually need to swing yourself (a.k.a the cursor) around a bit to get the most out of your swing, or less to allow for quicker recovery; made more difficult if your character is at an odd camera angle. It's a painful learning curve, but a satisfying one never the less. (Dark Souls, anyone?)
I must add, however, that the jumping" steps you take in battle are a bit wonky
date: in the least. It seems to me that you'd take a few steps before you were about to fall over
recommended: whether forwards or backwards. The side-stepping also suffers from this bizarre syndrome. It's like the character has an awkwardly high point of balance to work with; situated somewhere around the shoulders rather than the hips as would be logical. This is a hyper-realistic game
hoursPlayed:
but it takes time to reach perfection I guess.

v. 51--------------------------------
Jackie Chan made a tutorial video for this game: It's called "Drunken Master"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Negative:

The gripes about controls are not unfounded.  The controls are overly difficult.  Almost to the point of making me quit.  My recomendation to the devs would be... you have a default button that aligns the camera...why not just make the camera always align?  I think that would help somewhat.

So far I have tried the areana on novice and am about 0 and 10 and have not even come close to killing my oppenent.  My character looks like a drunken elephant in heat as he tries to connect to with his opponent.  I hate to ask for this but could the devs make an arena mode with no opponent...really just one where I can walk around and swing and get a feel for controls.  I suppose I may have that option in campaign game.

The Positive:

It looks good.  The inventory system reminds me of Ultima Online.  The lighting and shadow effects are so well done.  Even though the controls are so difficult when I do get a nice correct swing it looks glorious.  At one point I felt like I was watching a movie with real actors doing combat....taking steps forward and backward to gain position.

I have watched several videos on this game so I know mastering the controls is possible...I just can't personally figure out how to do it yet.  30 mins in and I have no idea what im doing but I think a shield and smaller weapon is more noob friendly than a two handed weapon.

Also this combat system is original.  The first of its kind I have seen.  This will lay the ground work for all kinds of possibilities to include hopefully someday...a multiplayer game with these mechanics.

TLDR:  Don't buy this if you are afraid to control an elephant in heat for hours.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best thing to happen to RPGs for years. A punishing and atmospheric WRPG that I can't stop playing, featuring the finest combat I've ever seen in a game.

Exanima runs on a scratch-built engine which simulates its realistic physics in incredible ways. This isn't a 'press the button to swing the sword' game, this is real-time, simulated melee combat based on weight, balance and stance. I don't exaggerate when I say that it's the best melee combat in any game to date. That alone would be enough to justify a purchase, but Exanima gives much more besides.

That feeling when you play an atmospheric, unforgiving and unique game like Dark Souls. That feeling that the world you're in is overwhelming and harsh and hostile, but in some way comforting, beautiful and spectacular. Exanima has that feeling, big time.

You don't have a map marker or a giant arrow on the screen showing you where to go and who to talk to next. Your character awakens in a horrible dungeon and you have to find your way out, that's all. No map markers, no friendly NPCs. Everyone you encounter has a procedural personalily, if you approach them with respect they might not attack. If you charge at them they might feel threatened and attack. If you deal a lot of damage quickly they might flee and find help, leaving you with a two-on-one fight. This is a dynamic dungeon crawler for the 21st century - Immersive is an understatement.

As an added spin-off the newly-updated Arena mode provides a simpler, quicker experience than the main game, whereby you earn money by partaking in various gladiatorial bouts such as fisticuffs pugilism, 6-man deathmatch, 1-on-1 fights and so on. You can buy more fighters for your roster and upgrade their equipment with your earnings. It's a great game in its own right.

Developer Bare Mettle have been generous and transparent throughout this project, always releasing expansive upgrades to the game for free and listening closely to their fans. This one is really special. There are 4 maps as of writing, with 10 more planned. And bear in mind that this is a prelude to Sui Generis, an open-world version of this concept.

This is the game that I dreamt of as a teenager, and slowly but surely it's coming true before my eyes. A unique masterpiece.

Early Access Review

I'll just point out here where this game really shines:
Every single battle is exciting!

- You feel you're getting better with real practice rather than just having the character stronger.

- You can really feel the effect of bashing a hammer on the enemy head or slicing his guts with a heavy sword.

- Same thing around, you feel the pain of taking a wrong step and having the blade of the axe sink in your back.

Takes a while to get the hang of the mechanics, but it's a hell of a combat when you get it.
Looking forward to what else the developers will show us.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game, it's fresh and bring an unique experience. Especially because of the physics. People says you character looks drunk during fights... stop compare this to movies... You are not holding a nice light aluminium blade and wearing a plastic chain mail....

So the physics engine play a huge part in this game. Everything goes around it. It creats a realistic unpredictable world. Every combat is unique, you can't be 100% sure what is going to happen. i have 100+ hours in this game and i still get surprise by how things goes.

The physics also makes the game really challenging. Warning ! You are going to get your ♥♥♥ kick and die over and over at the start. Don't make the mistake to give up, you are going to miss everything. The game and the fun begins once you passed the frustrating part learning how to deal with the physics. (It took me 15 hours to beat expert arena the first time.) After that, you will enjoy using it to your advantage, it feels so rewarding when you land a massive blow in the face of your enemy. You will reach a point where you almost feel your character ^^.

This is an awesome game and when you know it's just the beginning of the adventure. A small dungeon and an arena. Because yes, Exanima is just a prelude to an open world, Sui Generis. Can't wait.
