reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had this game for a couple of months now so I feel like I can give my honest opinion on this game.. Let me start with saying that this game dares to be different, it sets off on it's own path leaving convention behind and in so doing has become a rare gem. In a digital arena where too many companies are afraid to take risks BareMettle have thrown caution to the wind and forged something truly unique and wonderful.. And for that you have my utmost respect.

Now on to the game. The first thing I want to say is.. This game is difficult, it has a steep learning curve. But, persevere and it reveals itself rewarding you with an incredibly deep combat system encompassing distance, timing and a feeling of real weight.


Being a prelude to Sui Generis, Exanima is something of a test bed for the dev's to create features for Sui Generis, but it also feels like a very rounded game in its own right albeit a work in progress.

Exanima is split currently into 2 experiences, the story, a no hands holding affair that drops you into a dungeon with no apologies and leaves you to figure out how you got there and how you get out. Not knowing if the NPC's are friend or foes only adds to the tension. Most of the items lying around can be manipulated by the player as everything is based around physics, which also factor into all aspects of the combat. Searching in this game actually involves moving the items around.

The story I cannot say much about as I am still working my wy through it, I'm one of those guys that loves the Arena gameplay. Which, leads me onto the second experience the Arena.. In the arena you control a main character who manages the fights and partakes in the battles. You select the type of battle and the participants you want to enter and get down to the glorious business of smashing, cutting and thrusting your enemies to death. It costs you money to enter an event and you will get a reward if you win the match. If you are an accomplished fighter you will earn money which can be used to buy weapons and armour that will increase your chance of survival.

There are lots of other features that I haven't touch on here but I thoroughly recommend you guys give this a go and don't be disheartend if you don't win for the first few hours as your get to grips with both the movement and the fighting.

I don't have a enough praise for this game, it is good already and it keeps on getting better with regular updates.

I look forward to more updates and ultimately to Sui Generis..

Thanks for reading.

Early Access Review

Good game with a unique combat system that you will enjoy once you get the hang of it. The game is a bit short which is it's only flaw worth mentioning. Don't let that keep you from buying it because you will still play it for several hours because; if you die, you have to start over! It's supposed to be something of a prequel and a taste of the developers next game called Sui Generis which will be much larger and feature the same combat system.

Pros:
- Great combat system
- Physics are well simulated
- Scary
- Good attention to detail from the dev's (puzzles, key's you have to find, etc)
- Graphics are nice
- Setting is awesome
- Story is vague but interesting

Cons:
- Combat is difficult (this is a good thing!!)
- A bit short as of now

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely brilliant. Love the physics and combat systems. Can't wait for the open-world Sui Generis, it looks like it'll be my favourite game of all time if Exanima is anything to go by.

Have to say, the running puzzle was tedious. Don't get me wrong, the other puzzles/traps were great.  With the running one, it was either you tried trial and error running for an hour and a half or you fiddle with wood debris, to keep the levers down, for an hour and a half. I did both because I couldn't run the distance and my reward was some steel vembraces. Why were they guarding that place so fiercely? I found better armour and weapons in the barracks on level two than I did in that hellhole. I proceded to die and had to do it a second time. Probably the biggest improvement to the game would be allowing you to save your progress.

I got to the end, I was fully kitted out and I was ready baby. It was a do or die moment but I had a choice. Do I fight the beastie head on (after releasing it from the fantastical bathroom I had previously trapped it in) or lead it to that death trap? Well the prospect of it dropping loot made me fight it lest the corpse was lost down that hole. Well it knocked me to the ground and shagged me. I wish I could've saved it before my virtue was lost. I don't think no saving makes it harder, it makes it boring. I went through that entire level and practically earned the right to battle this daemon but now I have to do the whole level again just to have another crack at the beastie. Kill the dead, search every chest and cuboard, navigate with only a compass... nah, I've done it before and if I die as easily as last time, I'll have to do it all again. There better be some kickass loot on it's corpse, otherwise it can go to hell.

What would make this game a billion times cooler (and looting so much easier) is if you could draw your own map in the journal with utensils and paper you find lying about. No set mini map, just your own attemp at figuring out where to go and which friggen rooms you've already been to. Especially when you've died at the end of a level, more than once, and keep getting confused as to where you've been and where you haven't. It's a nightmare for a thorough looter like me.

The arena is epic. I can never get passed aspirant but I blame my laptop. It's just not good enough to run the game, I think, so I end up lagging about and bet butchered by an acursed sharp weapon like a cleaver. I got the technique perfected though and it's great fun when it's running smoothly. I hope there is an arena or arenas in Sui Generis. One in every major city where you play as your character. I think it's great that the arena feature is seperate to the campaign in Examina but I wouldn't like to see that seperation in Sui Generis.

Amazing game, cannot wait for more updates. Love it, love it. Thank you Bare Mettle Entertainment.

Cool name: Bare Mettle.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll start this off by saying this game probably isn't for everyone.  To me, that is a good thing, because appealing to as wide a base as possible can strip a game of what makes it unique.  That's just my own personal bias, though.

This is a game that rewards you for thinking and practicing  and offers little in the way of hand-holding.  You won't jump in and be great from the get-go, but every inch of progress feels like a worthy accomplishment.  You will die, A LOT.  At first you might blame the game (go read some of the more frustrated discussion posts on the forums) but with enough time in the Arena or crawling through the dungeon, you'll find how much each-and-every keystroke and mouse-click affects your character.  I've probably spent half of my playtime so far in each game mode, and only now am I getting decent at surviving...the first floor.  Hell, that's probably my own fault, too, because I try my darndest to kill each and every undead SOB that I come across.

Currently there are two game modes: Story and Arena.  The story takes place amidst three floors or sections of an underworld (so far).  The arena comes in two flavors: Novice and Expert, and serves as a good 'tutorial' for learning the game mechanics.  All things considered, you can easily get the $15 worth out of the arena alone and never reach the Expert level.

There's more to be said in the forums about individual mechanics, but the long and short of it is a love/hate relationship.  Every step matters.  When you click your mouse and how you move it matter.  The direction you are facing when attacking or dodging matters.  This is the first game where I've been able to trip someone over a sawhorse and smash their head in with a mace, and that's a plus in my book.

If you're looking for a challenge, want to support a dedicated development team, are tired of reskinned and repackaged Call of Assasin's Whatever, I fully recommend this game.  Whatever the reason.  There are few games in my library that I feel as happy about buying as I do with this game (I can probably count them all on one hand).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is a nice proof of concept but I would advise against purchasing it. While the momentum based movement and combat is interesting, it really lacks a lot in the user-friendliness department.

The arena mode was a reasonable challenge, novice somehow being more difficult than expert in my opinion. But the story mode is just frustrating. Numerous times I find myself stuck to walls unable to move, and the movement in combat mode is annoying as you cannot position yourself precisely due to it sidestepping or backstepping. The movement is great in the arena but in the tight confines of the story mode I find myself struggling to just go in the correct direction as turning can be inconsistent, often over or undershooting while turning. I keep finding myself spinning and facing away from the enemy in combat, often with little understand of how, though it seems it takes the long way round to face them after a wide swing. I understand it is different to other games, but the whole system is just too clunky in my opinion.

I look forward to improvements and changes, and will likely change this as it becomes more playable.

As an arena brawler you could give this a try, it was definitely fun and this wont exactly break the bank. But as an dungeon crawler, I feel in its current state it would be painful to play through as I feel my performance is dictated by luck rather than skill in the tight corridors, combined with perma-death: no thanks.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:
Atmosphere/level design are good, combat is great and is definitely the games strong point. A little like Mount and Blade but top down, and when you learn how to play it's satisfying and challenging in the same way.

Cons:
A lot of the time you're frantically trying to click narrow items in your inventory and drag them to your player or other things as fast as you can, while an enemy is lurching towards you. Hope they implement favorites or quick switching between weapon and torch at least. Items you have to pick up are also very small and clicking on them can test your mouse accuracy.

The only suggestion i'd have is probably not going to be popular and that's to allow saving. It doesn't feel like a roguelike because it's not procedurally generated and redoing the same stuff over and over is repetitive. And you will redo things a lot with how dangerous all the combat is. Maybe i just need to get better though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very well polished for an EA game, with a few saving hiccups when it comes to arena mode.  The world looks amazing, when it comes to texture and lighting.  When you accidentally kick your torch across the room, you're in for a bad time.

While this game has great physics, graphics and a highly polished world, the controls are utterly garbage and inconsistent.  With movement being camera based, it's very easy to accidentally turn yourself around and give your back to the enemy.  And seeing as how unforgiving the game is when it comes to death, it can get very frustrating to lose a well geared character to clunky controls.  On top of the bad camera angles and control scheme, the most frustrating part of the game is when you try to perform a back handed swing.  It feels impossible to perform it consistenly, especially when it's the best way to beat shielded opponents.  Maybe let us bind back handed swings to RMB?

Overall, well polished EA game.  For $15, not sure but seeing as how I got this for backing them on Sui Generis I don't mind the issues it has.  I just hope the gameplay is more intuitive and less clunkly when Sui Generis is released.  And give us a 1-click backhanded swing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've spent well over 5 hours just trying to learn how to fight, and another 10 to learn how to fight effectively.
....
And I've loved every minute of it.

*Extra info*

Pros:
- Graphics are great and the designers have done excellently for optimization to where you can get 60 fps with a 4 yr old comp.

- The fighting is simply revolutionary, and the attention to detail in this game is extremely refreshing. YOU control your character, I don't mean A+up for a high attack, your mouse input, timing, and footwork determins where you will land.

- Funny things can happen with physics. I don't mean glitchs or anything, I mean fighting someone, you trip and fall, and he/she trips and fall over you, then you trip over him.

- Developers are transparent and seemingly make good progress.

- Sound is very atmospheric and realistic.

Cons
- There can be a problem with animation speeds suddenly slowing or speeding up depending on cpu/gpu usage ratios, but its avoidable and workable.

- Combat can take a long time to learn, but its very rewarding once you do get proficient.

- For better or worse this, this game does not hold your hand ( a pro for me)

- No thrust attacks yet (at least not without highly advanced footwork and timing to turn a slash small enough to be 'thrust' like)

- I really really really wish this game was open world like torchlite 2, something like that is rumoured but I can't confirm atm.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love the way the combat feels, it's so much more alive than any other game I've played. It may seem really hard at first (it will punish you for any mistake you make) but when you get used to it you will feel like a bad***, slaughtering everything in your path.
The atmosphere is also great, it is set in an expansive underground complex that is filled with undead warriors patrolling it's corridors. The feeling of suspense is tangible as you never know when you're going to run into another baddie; I have opened many doors to promptly slam it shut when I see the undead guy with a rather large axe on the other side.
Another great feature is the armour/clothing, it's not simply about stacking equipment into slots  to get a stat boost, it matters what you wear, and it can all combine creatively; no more head/chest/hands/feet. You can stack your clothing on top of each other to get the maximum benefit of everything. For example you can wear a shirt, put some chainmail over it, put a tunic over that, then wear a plate breastplate to top it all off.
The only criticism I have is the health, and it's not even a criticism, more like I see room for improvement. Considering how ambitious the developers are for the the sequel game Sui Generis, I thought health would be a little more advanced than a health bar. For example; the game Kenshi has health for all your individual limbs and body parts, you could lose the function of your left arm for a time, or if it is damaged enough you could lose it permanently. There is also a blood count which is lowered by being slashed and bleeding (duh) and will knock you unconscious but will regenerate over time and bleeding can be stopped with bandages applied to the damaged body part, which will also heal in time. Sorry for going on about that.
Overall this is a very good game that is definitely worth buying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My biggest critique on this game will be the controls. They feel very unresponsive, especially the movement keys. There's a good half a second delay before anything happens, and as the camera angle changes throughout a fight, your controls get reversed. As a result of this, you have to be pressing space almost every 5 seconds to keep the camera angle straight, because... well, good luck trying to win a fight with reversed controls.

Definitely prepare to die 8,000 times if you're going to buy this game. This is by far one of my most frustrating gaming experiences and you would THINK that someone like me with 1900 hours in Chivalry would have a decent understanding of sword-fighting by now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is a unique game that takes traditional action combat and turns it on its head using physics! I'd say, initially, it's like trying to control a combatant that decided it'd be a great idea to flail his greatsword around while blindingly drunk. In the beginning, it was quite amusing attempting to control this character that seemed to be fighting with me at every moment, but, as I kept playing, I started to realize there was a finesse to controlling the combatant’s movements and swings.

Exanima's development background is an interesting one. Published by Bare Mettle, it is a precursor to their Kickstarter success; Sui Generis, which will be an open-world RPG. Exanima is designed to give people a taste of what their larger game will be like, and allows their fans to experience the unique combat system.

Exanima's combat relies solely on realistic physics. The direction you swing and the weight of your weapon determines your character's movement. While you use the mouse to direct your swings, you use the keyboard to direct how your character moves their feet. The initial effect feels like you're controlling the local town drunk, but, once mastered, you will be using that momentum to make your swings even more devastating. You can even knock down your opponent if you have enough momentum or hit them just right.

While this system has a steep learning curve and requires a certain amount of mental dexterity, the payoff is worth the initial frustration. When you manage to use your forward momentum to crash your greatsword into the enemy, and the physical force drives him into the ground, you can't help but exclaim in excitement! It takes some patience, but if you stay the course, you will be rewarded with a highly satisfying combat mechanic.

The combat isn't the only thing that follows the physics engine, though. The way you interact with the environment is also governed by realistic physics. For example, if you're fleeing from a nasty group of enemies and find yourself running in a dark hallway, and you run over a chair, there's a good chance your character is going to face-plant into the floor. I've encountered this scenario on many occasions, and it always makes me laugh (until my assailants catch up with me). In addition to chair-tripping and face-planting, the way you open and close doors is physics-based, as well. You click and drag the doors to open them. You can open a door slowly, or, my favorite, swing the mouse really fast so the door bangs open loudly-- that will scare those pesky undead, right?!

Exanima has two game modes--arena mode and story mode. Arena mode places you against one enemy at a time in a square room, and as you defeat each opponent, you are matched against harder (and better-equipped) opponents in subsequent battles. When you are vanquished, though, you begin again from the first combatant. However, there's a twist-- as you progress through, you get to keep any equipment you pilfered from your previously-defeated opponents, thus giving you a feeling of progression (albeit a small one). The arena is a good way to practice game mechanics before jumping into story mode

Story mode drops you in the middle of a dungeon, unarmed, except for your trusty torch. It’s a dark dungeon with no real direction, and it's up to you to piece together what's really going on by finding various hidden notes containing information, and by battling multitudes of armed undead, looting them for better equipment along the way.

The atmosphere of the story's dungeon is foreboding and moody. Most corridors are impenetrably dark without a torch. The dungeon is not without it's well-lit rooms, but those tend to be occupied by individuals that aren’t exactly concerned about your well-being. The music and sound effects add to the tension provided by the visual atmosphere. The mystery of the story, and the lack of information given, only adds to the enigma cake. “Why are there so many wood logs in here?” “Was this an underground saw mill?” “What diabolical goal existed to where something so logistically backwards was necessary!?” I must know!

It is important to keep in mind that Exanima is a 'rogue-like' game. That is to say, that when you die, you start over entirely. The developers recently added checkpoints for when you reach other floors, but each floor is a huge labyrinth, and I have yet to see the second floor. So, if that is not your cup of tea, then Exanima may not be for you. However, you can always have fun with the combat in the arena, which has a pseudo-progression system.

Written June 1st, 2015.

You can find more of my ramblings about video games at www.chatswithrad.com

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I'm playing Exanima, the tournament/Vs mode to be more specific, and my character feels as if it is a marrionette.  I am controlling a little guy using strings.  While drunk.

I'm hooked.

I end up playing for hours straight.  Hacking, slashing, bashing.  Checking out the different weapons.  How to move using the in game controls.

Then it happens.  Something just clicks.

I am no longer stumbling about.  I am moving about in a clear concise manner.  I am dodging attacks, blocking.  I even duck under a broad sweeping horizontal slash.  I rush the enemy and knock them onto the ground and finish them off with a powerful overhead slash.

Next round.  I die in a single blow.

I played for a few more hours.

I am excited about where this game is going and hope that the makers continue to fine tune the controls.  They are amazing when you get them to work.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've spent well over 5 hours just trying to learn how to fight, and another 10 to learn how to fight effectively.
....
And I've loved every minute of it.

*Extra info*

Pros:
- Graphics are great and the designers have done excellently for optimization to where you can get 60 fps with a 4 yr old comp.

- The fighting is simply revolutionary, and the attention to detail in this game is extremely refreshing. YOU control your character, I don't mean A+up for a high attack, your mouse input, timing, and footwork determins where you will land.

- Funny things can happen with physics. I don't mean glitchs or anything, I mean fighting someone, you trip and fall, and he/she trips and fall over you, then you trip over him.

- Developers are transparent and seemingly make good progress.

- Sound is very atmospheric and realistic.

Cons
- There can be a problem with animation speeds suddenly slowing or speeding up depending on cpu/gpu usage ratios, but its avoidable and workable.

- Combat can take a long time to learn, but its very rewarding once you do get proficient.

- For better or worse this, this game does not hold your hand ( a pro for me)

- No thrust attacks yet (at least not without highly advanced footwork and timing to turn a slash small enough to be 'thrust' like)

- I really really really wish this game was open world like torchlite 2, something like that is rumoured but I can't confirm atm.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a combat system like nothing I've ever seen before. At first it's really difficult, I recommend for new players to play through the arena (novice and preferably expert too, or at least until the first 4-6 fights on expert level) before attempting the main game. Otherwise there's a great risk you'll find the controls confusing and frustrating and more or less give up on the game.
That's what I did anyway, at first. I bought the game because I saw a playthrough of the first level and it seemed really fun, then when I tried it myself I failed miserably.
But now I've gone through the arena fights and just finished lvl 2 (I think there's only 3 currently, but the levels are pretty big, hard and unforgiving). I love it. No saves and permadeath means you have to constantly be on your toes (I've heard you automatically save when exiting though, I really hope that's true or else I'll have to go through levels 1-2 again..)

There are numerous game mechanics tutorials on youtube, I had some help from one of them, can't remember which and when I look now there's quite a few to choose from. I'm really glad I gave the game a second chance, once you get reasonably good at it it's very rewarding. And that's just how it is in its current state, there's lots of stuff not yet implemented, this might become a very nice (and cheap for what it is) game indeed.
Highly recommended

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima,

If you're tired of both the TES series and the Soul's series, then this will give you an extremely breath of fresh air. The game is both a combination of TES storytelling (mostly Dark souls esque storytelling to be honest) and Soul-like combat. Although it is currently in beta and the early access phase, the game FEELs like a complete game. The physics of the game are awkward at best, but the game formula does work.

The game beta presents three modes. In story mode, you're an amnesic, stumbling through dark corridors finding your destiny. The arena mode is where you, a gladiator, fight to fame and glory. The third mode which honestly isn’t another mode but it is a worthy thing to point out is arena practice. This is where you are given full skills, and access to a variety of tools to unleash death and hell upon your enemies.

The combat is astounding, the way you feel when you desperately backhand swing your sword and accidentally cut your opponent's face, catching him off guard and knocking him to the ground, finishing him with a stab to his chest is amazing. Another amazing scenario is when two-handed swords clash, and your sword slides down his, catching his face and cutting him down. This is as close to real life combat as I've seen so far.

In short, this game is a definite game worth its price. If you can devote your blood, sweat, and literal tears to train yourself, you can become a lowly scrounger to a knight in armor which is stained with the blood of your enemies. If you go into this game, blindly swinging, you won’t get very far. Training is truly what you need in this game. Imagination is half the battle. I like to imagine that I’m training myself to become an honorable knight. It gets me through all the hardships of the game.

If you do buy this game, start off with arena practice. Learn how to fight, then fight well. Remember that practice will get you through many of the challenges. Patience and virtue.

My only complaint is that the torch lighting is too advanced for my laptop to handle.

9.9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I'm playing Exanima, the tournament/Vs mode to be more specific, and my character feels as if it is a marrionette.  I am controlling a little guy using strings.  While drunk.

I'm hooked.

I end up playing for hours straight.  Hacking, slashing, bashing.  Checking out the different weapons.  How to move using the in game controls.

Then it happens.  Something just clicks.

I am no longer stumbling about.  I am moving about in a clear concise manner.  I am dodging attacks, blocking.  I even duck under a broad sweeping horizontal slash.  I rush the enemy and knock them onto the ground and finish them off with a powerful overhead slash.

Next round.  I die in a single blow.

I played for a few more hours.

I am excited about where this game is going and hope that the makers continue to fine tune the controls.  They are amazing when you get them to work.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA little gem of a game. Basically a proof of concept for its upcoming older sibling, Sui Generis. A dungeon crawler with a highly nuanced, physically simulated combat system - which at the time of this writing comes with a difficult and interesting (if unfinished) campaign and an incredibly addictive Arena mode (recently expanded upon in an update) for you to practice your fighting skills in. And practice you must: The selling point of Exanima is its frankly brilliant combat system, which is all about influencing your character's basic set of animations at key moments in order to procedurally generate the unique actions the situation calls for. It will take you, at the very least, a couple of hours to get used to how it all works (and the game's camera system), but the reward is well worth it. The developers have spent the past couple of years not only working on content (such as weapons and new floors for the campaign dungeon), but also polishing the combat system and the underlying details of its simulation. And their efforts show  - Bare Mettle has achieved something undeniably unique here. It currently has a a bit of a dearth of content (if highly replayable), but I would nonetheless suggest you pick up this game even in its current state. Mechanically speaking, what's in there is already quite impressive, and will give you a relatively clear view of the roadmap towards the full version.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very buggy at the moment, but I'm sure the devs will tackle that problem. This game has a lot of potential, and a very hard learning curve.

For everyone complaining about camera: use middle mouse to change the view, or press spacebar to set the camera behind your character.

Movement is a bit wonky, but that's just because of the unique system in place. W makes your character move forward, but only in the directin your character is facing in the game. I reccommend you use your mouse to move. Right click in the direction you want to go and press shift to run (make sure you don't trip lol).

As you've probably heard, combat is very unique too. I'd say try arena mode before story mode, just to get a hang of it. Combat is difficult so make sure you can fight well before trying story mode, because there is a lot of fighting there.

It doesn't look like I've played a lot but I've watched a few gameplays. These are just early impressions though. The game looks great and I'm excited for co-op mode.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you like darksouls? do you like getting the utter ♥♥♥♥ kicked out of you when you make a single mistake? do you miss the god awefull controls that were not simple at all? Do you like learning on your own without any tutorial or help? Are you ready to fail many times before you learn to succeed even the first few levels? Then this game is for you. Its got a great armor mechanic with a layering system and location based damage.

I especcially like the health mechanic, its an interesting, complex system. Yellow damage means stamina (temporary) but if it gains red you've permanently been physically damaged and must seek one of the very rare medical items in the game. Get knock out and you might get a second chance, but the enemy that made you unconcious to begin with can still be lurking around anywhere.

This game is entirely about cuation and patient combat, you must out smart your enemy in combat, not out hit them. Wait for their mistake, their mis-step or missed attack, and then reply to their failure with a glorious swipe.
Hitting the head is always almost fatal or a knockout, but the same rule goes for you.
The control scheme is odd, wierd, and the camera placement is awkward and doesnt help with it, but god damn is it not satisfying to beat even one area.

Again: This game is highly difficult, and skill based. You will die, and you will fail. Its a matter of time, patience, and ability to adapt while also making sure your character does get ♥♥♥♥ed by falling over from stepping on a chair in the heat of combat. Keep an eye on your surroundings and stay aware, and take everything slow. Dont go into things full speed thinking you can take on the world, you'll get your ♥♥♥ kicked long before you can say I smite thee." like some god damn hooligan. 1 enemy with a prosthetic leg as a able was almost able to kick my ♥♥♥ (albiet
date: with no permanent health damage.) all becuase he had me dead to rights in a corner
recommended: i made it with a sliver of my stamina life left. 1 enemy is difficult
hoursPlayed: 2 is extremely occupying
voteText:
and anymore might as well be suicide unless your clad in the armor of a god.

My rating:
10/10 - would be clobbered by a prosthetic leg wielding zombie again."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you like darksouls? do you like getting the utter ♥♥♥♥ kicked out of you when you make a single mistake? do you miss the god awefull controls that were not simple at all? Do you like learning on your own without any tutorial or help? Are you ready to fail many times before you learn to succeed even the first few levels? Then this game is for you. Its got a great armor mechanic with a layering system and location based damage.

I especcially like the health mechanic, its an interesting, complex system. Yellow damage means stamina (temporary) but if it gains red you've permanently been physically damaged and must seek one of the very rare medical items in the game. Get knock out and you might get a second chance, but the enemy that made you unconcious to begin with can still be lurking around anywhere.

This game is entirely about cuation and patient combat, you must out smart your enemy in combat, not out hit them. Wait for their mistake, their mis-step or missed attack, and then reply to their failure with a glorious swipe.
Hitting the head is always almost fatal or a knockout, but the same rule goes for you.
The control scheme is odd, wierd, and the camera placement is awkward and doesnt help with it, but god damn is it not satisfying to beat even one area.

Again: This game is highly difficult, and skill based. You will die, and you will fail. Its a matter of time, patience, and ability to adapt while also making sure your character does get ♥♥♥♥ed by falling over from stepping on a chair in the heat of combat. Keep an eye on your surroundings and stay aware, and take everything slow. Dont go into things full speed thinking you can take on the world, you'll get your ♥♥♥ kicked long before you can say I smite thee." like some god damn hooligan. 1 enemy with a prosthetic leg as a able was almost able to kick my ♥♥♥ (albiet
date: with no permanent health damage.) all becuase he had me dead to rights in a corner
recommended: i made it with a sliver of my stamina life left. 1 enemy is difficult
hoursPlayed: 2 is extremely occupying
voteText:
and anymore might as well be suicide unless your clad in the armor of a god.

My rating:
10/10 - would be clobbered by a prosthetic leg wielding zombie again."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really can't recommend this game. I know I've only played for 1.2 hours, but I assure you that is being generous. I am not a person that enjoys needless frustration and aggravation in a game. Two things this game does incredibly well. The Physics are great and it has the potential to be a great game, but the needlessly frustrating and aggravating combat system killed it for me, but I paid for it so i'm stuck with it. I don't understand these indie developers, and there desire to cater to only very Specific groups of gamer's. If you are a hard core gamer or enjoy needless frustration and aggravation then this game is probably something you'll like. If you play games to relax and have fun and don't enjoy being needlessly frustrated or aggravated by core game mechanics then i cant recommend this game for you. The developer needs to do some actual research on weapon use in combat as well. The two handed weapons the way they throw you around isn't accurate at all, Heavy weighted weapons doesn't mean the weapon is going to pull and throw you around with every swing, it's called controlled swings and momentum, not blind and wild swinging.

I do not recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Some comments after 10+ hours in game.
- The combat is awesome, it almost tastes like sweat and blood. It's absolutely the best combat system I've ever tried.
- But be warned, the learning curve is steep. I wish there would be an auto-follow-camera option. Learning to use the space key for realigning the cam is one of the key things, and pretty unintuitive for a regular gamer. For me it took around 3 hours to get a grip on it.
- Watching youtube tutorials can be really helpful.
- The Arena progress is a bit too slow at the moment. My main champion is Novice now, I'm always out of money and it seems that it requires even more grinding to get further.
- The Arena practice mode is complete opposite (short and generous), it's a lot of fun for an hour or two.
- I've only tried the story mode for few times, the movement mechanism is not super suitable for that honestly which makes it feel a bit frustrating. The free movement should be way snappier and especially here the auto-follow-cam would be a huge improvement. Player should enjoy trying sneaking around, but now it's mostly a struggle against imprecise movement, at least for me. So I haven't touch that part of the game much.

So all in all, the combat and the Arena mode are so awesome that it's easy to recommend this already. There is huge amount of potential here. I personally hope the devs would focus on the Arena and polish it to perfection. A multiplayer feature would be fantastic, even local.


Edit:
20 hours in and stuck at novice (3/6 in ranks) in the Arena. The grinding get's too bad at this point. Fighting tend to require quite a bit of healing time so you need pretty much a full roster of combatants thus making progression really slow. Also accidental deaths do happen which is devastating from time consuming perspective. I would not change the permadeath though, just make the progression faster and more balanced.

I've hammered through the Arena practice mode on novice and expert several times. And I'm still not interested in the story mode because of the imprecise controls. So the game is pretty much done for me for now. I'm still recommending it, but truly hoping for more balanced combat related content, since in my opinion (with these controls) this is an awesome combat game, not so much an adveture / rpg.

Edit2:
40+ hours in. Grinded to the master level on Arena mode. Everything above still stands. Also played the story for some hours, the story mode is very far from proper game and I would still introduce completely different controls for walking / running around.

Anyhow, still a strong recommendation. Best melee combat game I've ever played. The content is a bit all over the place, but lot to enjoy still.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An interesting tech demo that however serves as a reminder as to why odd-ball mechanics such as physics are for the most part relegated to the role of gimmicks. While it is to the developers credit that they managed to make it kind of sort of work, you would be hard pressed to find a single aspect of game that could not be strictly improved by drastically limiting the effect that procedural generation and physics simulation has on character movement or really any other part of the game.

Apart from that, the game in it's current state is very bare bones. With a very limited control scheme, lack of variety in environment and a short game time.

All in all, if you are not aware of or are not interested in the tech that underlines the gameplay, stay away. The game on it's face is sluggish, clunky, buggy, short, with animations that only shine as comic relive and is generally not worth the price asked.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Review subject to change)
7.7 hours and no progress due to no saves, i'm done

I am a video game veteran of 36 years and i must say that this game has left the rules of traditional dungeon exploring as i know it, some good, some bad.

The good
Graphic style, music and atmosphere are really nice as with the physics for some portions of the game like objects falling, door swing and taking a trip over the junk laying on the ground, pretty funny actually.
The lighting is some of the very best and true to life and camera angles work well setting the scene.

The bad
Now before i go into it, the idea of a physics based combat system is a nice one, it fails for the most part here,can you kill things sure but it can be very sloppy at times with some of the encounters, you bump into things trying to get into combat mode when you get a surprise attack and by that time you have 2 hits in on you, you draw your weapon then oops dead.
It feels like I'm racing on an elephant with three legs, awkward and not very graceful,
I think the combat system needs a little more finesse with a tweak here and there and it should be better.

Yeah so it would be a pretty good early access if it had a save feature, 7.7 hours of play got me pretty much nowhere.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Examina is a game I want so badly to like, but I just can't do to the multiple issues I have with the game. Before we continue, remember that this game is in early access, so any problems I mention can be fixed or improved on. Also, this is my opinion. This means some aspects of the game I list as a problem may be a positve to someone else. Anyway, let's continue.

Examina is a Isometric RPG Dungeon crawler where the objective is to explore a dungeon to get better gear so you can survive against the ruthless and deadly enemies. The games combat is entirely physics base, so the way your character is animated when moving, attacking, reacting to hits and everything else is done by the physics engine, and so are the enemies and the props (of course). Let's get the combat out of the way. I love it. It is a brilliant way of breathing new live into the genre. What it is, is that when you are up against an enemy, you go into a attack mode, which allows you to swing your weapon and block. You block by hitting the enemy's weapon with yours, making the enemy's weapon lose momentom and not hit you. This, of course, prevents you from taking damage, though even if you do block, sometimes you will still be clipped and take a small amount of damage. You attack by holding the left mouse button to hold your weapon up and you move your mouse to swing it (there are other ways to attack, but that's how I usually attacked). Base on you weapon's stats, the amount of momentom your weapon has, where you hit, and the armor the enemy is wearing will determine the amount of damage you will deal. My descripton of the combat is extremly simplified and it much more complex than how I have descripted it.

This game is also brutually difficult and is NOT begginer friendly (heck, I don't remember if there is even a tutorial). I don't find this to be a positive or a negitive. I'm fine with it being brutually difficult, but it's the fact that you aren't even told the controls is pretty annoying, and as a result, prevented me from getting into the games combat fully, as I didn't even know the basics of combat. One of my favorite games of all time, Dark Souls, is known for being extremely difficult, and yet that game told you how to attack, defend yourself, how to manage your inventory, and how some mechanics works like how resting at a bondfire may refill your estus flask (a healing item), but it revives every enemy on the map except mini bosses and bosses. I wish this game would just explain the basics and players can find out the advanced tactics and mechanics on there own.

The level design is pretty good. Nothing really special about it, so not much to talk about.

There are two modes. The first one which I believe is called adventure, and the second on called arena. Adventure is where you explore a dungeon to get better gear so you can face the enemies ahead. Arena is my favorite mode, it's where you go up a enemy 1v1 in a small arena. If you defeat the enemy, you get the chance to loot the enemy and go onto the next stage. This continues intill you die I believe. The AI and the equipment they have gets better and better the more you progress. It's brilliant, and it is fun if you enjoy the way the game controls and how the combat system works.

The AI is brilliant...     during combat, but outside of combat, they can be really dumb. The enemies are set on a predetermined path, and if they aren't, they will just stand there, and do nothing. Another problem with the AI, and this also affects the AI during combat, is the fact that they CAN'T OPEN DOORS. If the door is completly shut, they can't get through.

The game looks pretty good. The textures appear to be high res and the lighting is quite good. The dark and creepy art direction is brilliant and the atmosphere is just perfect as it set's the mood brilliantly about the dangers you will be facing. Not much else to say again, so let's move on.

Now let's get to the main problem of the game and why I don't recommend you pick it up yet is the controls. I would love to play and experiment with the games combat if it weren't for the fact that the game controls like ♥♥♥♥ and are extremely confusing. You feel like a tank. I know they're trying to focus on the fact that you are heavy, but it is not needed to the extent this game goes to. Half of the time I just walk strait into the enemy, preventing us both from swinging our weapons. I just want there to be a lock on system, since the game focuses on 1v1, where you press A and D to circle around your opponent, and W and S you move closer and futher from you opponent. But instead, it feels like I'm controlling a character from Resident Evil 1. I hope they do add a lock on system. If there is one already in the game, I can't find it. This problem breaks the game for me

Here is a short list on what I like, what I was indifferent to, and what I disliked

Pros:

+Combat

+Graphics

+atmosphere and art direction

+level design

+Enemy AI during combat

+Arena

Indifferent:

+/- The game not telling you anything, including how to play.

+/- The enemy AI outside of combat.

Dislikes:

- The Controls

- Enemy AI doesn't know how to open doors.

Overall, I want to love this game, I really do, but the awful controls in my opinion just destroy this game for me.

5/10

Sorry for any mistakes in the review. I haven't played the game for a couple of months.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't even played the actual game, this review is based solely on ARENA in the BETA testing branch.

Timing is more important than playtime. Just holding in the LMB just makes you perform like a drunken, limp-wristed nancy. You'll be hitting people with your weapon haft, forehead, or who knows what else. You need to coordinate your step, swing timing, and mouse twitch to land that beautiful, blood spraying head crack on your poorly dressed, destitute opponent.

I appreciate a game that is skill based rather than playtime grind based. Holding in a mouse button and pressing 1-9 doesn't appeal to me. Learing the coordination to manipulate WASD, click timing, and mouse movement is much more fun in my opinion.

You will be punished mid swing if you leave yourself open. You will be rewarded if you read your opponents swing and hit him as he overextends. This game has beautiful, addicting mechanics. You don't just control your character, you become one with your charcter, you are his eyes, arms, and legs. When I was a kid, I would move my arms and body while controlling my console characters on screen. Shruggin shoulders to get that extra oomph" into a jump
date: tilting sideways to push my character a little further to clear a pit. I'm an old man now
recommended: and this game is the only game to make me do that as an adult!\n\nCons in my short playtime: Inventory and equipment is not very intuitive
hoursPlayed: you can't immediately tell what is equipped/overridden/unequipped. Interface can be a little clunky at times.\n\nTL;DR: easy to learn

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome early access title, shows a lot of promise. Still getting a lot of playtime in its current unfinished state.

The combat and controls have a very real learning curve, but are immensely satisfying once mastered. For real, the combat is super addicting, and with the new chalenging arena mode, its a blast to play.

Story mode is unfinished, and ive spent far more time in the arena than in the story dungeons, but I think they will become quite exciting once fully realized.

Most importantly, as an early access title, is the progress the game is making. Updates come roughly once every couple months, but evey single update ive seen has been highly polished, introducing new concepts, in the form of attacks, armors, levels and whatnot in a way that smoothly and greatly enhances the game. These guys know what they're doing, the care and thought going into this game is apparent.

Bottom line, this is undoubtedly one of the finest EA titles currently on steam, and an absolute hidden gem. If youre willing to learn a new style of gameplay, you will definitely not regret it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Perfect game even at this stage of development! The combat feels very realistic and fun, especially when you first time learn how to make an over head swing with a two handed hammer and slam it right on the enemy's skull! Not to mention watching enemies tripping on objects they don't notice and deal a killing blow before they get up. At start it was very hard to learn the movement of your character and it felt clumsy but after tens of deaths you'll get the hang of it (when they said unforgiving" they really meant it). The exploration was also fun and interesting: throwing stuff here and there to see if anything is hidden and all the long hallways to walk and huge amount of doors to open and - of course - revealing the dark mysteries. I only encountered 1 bug which I found completely hillarious: I was just swinging around with the huge hammer when I tried to hit a box as hard as I could when suddenly my hand was stuck in it. I tried to shake it off but it only looked like I was just furiously swinging it. After a few minutes I managed to unstuck it by trying to run away from it.

I found it disappointing when I realized that it was rather short but what to expect from an Early-Access game. I still found it very satisfying and I have already 17 hours in game time. Definetly worth the money! 5/5 Have fun with the physics! xD"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love this game. In fact, I can't stop thinking about it. The combat is challenging (expect to put in a few hours before you get the hang of it), but it is incredibly satisfying when you do master it. This is hands down the most innovative game I've played in years. Exanima is a dungeon crawling prequel to the larger Sui Generis (which is still in development) - but it is a full game on its own. The developers are fantastic and more levels and features are on the way. If you are at all interested in this sort of thing, I urge you to buy this game and support these guys...they truly deserve it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

How to put this...

I've been delving for many years. I've gotten extremely used to the standardized 'kill -> loot -> upgrade' mechanic that every dungeoning game seems to try and adapt in some way. The genre has begun to feel stale, to say the least.

And oh boy is Exanima a breath of fresh air.

The combat is entirely controlled by an in-house physics engine. There are no animations
date:
only muscle contractions resulting in movement of the body. The progression of the game's visual fidelity over the past few years has impressed me, with Bare Mettle paying close attention to player critiques of both gameplay and visuals.

Most exciting to me is the fact that this game is a preamble, a proof of concept if you will, for a much larger open world game that is still in development. Even MORE exciting is the eventual inclusion of low-latency multiplayer over LAN, which has at this point been confirmed by the developer.

If you're unsure about purchasing this game, I would visit their website and watch their videos. If the reviews on steam and screengrabs don't get you, the technical demonstrations sure will.

Lastly, please spend 4-6 hours in the practice arena before you leave a bad review. The game has a learning curve! :)
hoursPlayed: true

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After watching the trailer for this game I was instantly interested.  It had something that I just had to try out for myself!

I'll admit that I can see a lot of people being turned off by the game mechanics, but for someone that doesn't mind taking the time to get to know the game, it's been a fun ride so far.  You'll notice right away that your character moves like a drunk sloth at times and the combat can be a bit clunky, BUT once you get it down, it's actually a lot of fun and takes a bit of skill to get good at.

Exploring the dungeon and taking your time searching around is where this game shines.  The game is rogue-like in a sense, and if you're lucky enough to survive a knockout"
date: you'll have a second chance to pick yourself back up and tread lightly though the dungeon again (with what is left of your health).  The game also has an arena mode where you can fight and hire other characters to fight for you and it adds a bit more content for you to sink your teeth into as well.\n\nAll and all
recommended: If the trailer has you wondering what this game is all about
hoursPlayed: and you don't  mind risking your cash on an EA title
voteText:
then give it a go!!

***UPDATE***

After doing a little more poking around
helpfulPercent: I've discovered that this game is actually a prelude to another game the devs are working on called 'Sui Generis'.  Examina takes place 20 years before the events of SG.  The only difference is this game is limited to the underworld dungeons of SG. Exanima is its own full game and should not be avoided because of SG.  SG looks even more amazing than Exanima and far more ambitious too!"

It's in alpha. That's it.

The combat system is extremely hard to master. The swings do not really come from the directions you choose and there is absolutely now way of blocking incoming hits without a shield. With the shield you have to navigate yourself with the messed up combat system and place yourself so that the enemy hits it. No way of raising or lower it. However, the AI can ofcourse do this. Parry with two-handers and block excelently with a shield. You just fumble around like a drunk even if you give it your best shot. I think the game would do much better in first person.

But it has potential. A lot of potential, so I'm not smacktalking it. Finetuning the combat system will bring it to another level. Maybe a retry"- button in the arena wouldn't hurt as well."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You wander around halls checking rooms, trunks, shelves and underthings for items. Strangers will come into sight, and they may or may not attack. Sometimes you feel good enough about your fighting ability (after some frustrated learning) to open an attack, but you also know that one false swing could go very badly, so do you risk it now, or wait for a better opportunity or weapon, or more armor to yet be found or taken.
No save feature yet, but I do believe they will add a persistent growth system. You can start a game and play in the story line, where that is going I am unsure of, you start with a perplexing parchment in you inventory, and find more, but you don't know anything at all. Also they have an arena, and it does keep some of your stuff you looted, even if you die, havent tried if it keeps after a shut off.
Although it does not have enough in it to be fully thumbed up yet, the simple fact of how much fun it is to play, where it seems to be going, and the physics use in the game makes it quite worth while as is now.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nExanima is another game with an ambitious graphic interface. Just about everything in the game operates according to basic physics. You can trip over boards, fall over after swinging your weapon too far, and so on. On the plus side, the game basically achieves its ambitious goals. On the down side, the controls lack a certain 'smoothness,' or 'finesse.' Trying this one out is not a waste of money, but make sure and read up on the control interface before attempting anything. Then you should give yourself at least an hour to get a good hang of the interface. The bottom line is that using true physics in an action game is a fantastic idea, but that this game represents a 'work in progress.'

Absolutely love the combat mechanics. The nature of the physics based system makes the game feel more like a sport; much more depth and complexity. It does seem like this it is a core system and really needs added moves, magic, etc.

That being said, I enjoyed Exanima's arena quite a bit and I really hope Suis Generis has a good single player experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

:EDIT:  I am going to recommend this game with several cautions not to be taken lightly:

- difficult combat with a bit of learning curve
- no saves.  You die, you start over.
- light on the story, no back story, just you in a dungeon.  Accept it, act accordingly.

Yeah this is a difficult one.  It's going to be tough for some people to appreciate this one, and I had a heck of a time diving into it.  I read a ton of positive reviews, watched some videos, and got really excited about this game.  Offered as something different, it is the most unique combat experience which I've ever partaken, and the learning curve is steep.

At first, the combat feels like you're driving a tank; trying to steer the camera, aim your weapon's swing direction and position your character all at the same time and it's near impossible to land any kind of powerful or accurate blow on an enemy.  I recommend diving right into the arena to get a handle on the battle mechanix.

One thing that people will enjoy is that it is visceral and much more than simply smashing the left click button to melee hordes of baddies, although I've had to suffer through not even being able to land a single blow on one guy standing right in front of me.  I grimmace at the thought of my first encounters - it was like two tired boxers just clinging to other falling over themselves in a punchdrunk haze.

You may want to hold out on this game for now if you need to jump into a game and be good at it and kill everything, this isnt' for you.  If you want to take a bit of time rummaging through rooms and using a keen eye to pick up items for survival and plot points, all while being weary of what's behind that next door, you may be in for a treat.  Be warned, and tread carefully.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nExanima is a special breed of rpg, Exanima is what happens if dark souls and diablo had a baby the combat controls a bit rough to get used to so i would do the arena mode before you start the main game. Surpisingly for an early access game the bugs are limited, the only one i found is weapons being stuck in objects and one previous location flashing on my screen then the framerate drops horribly causing me to relaunch the whole game. Exanima is almost a Rpg Horror game , but no horror as in jumpscare horror exept for a few quiet jumpscares (zombie waiting in front of a door i just opened)  it keeps you on the edge of your seat and when you hear one little thing move or a footstep it instantly puts you on guard , because a person in full armor and a halberd can be beat to death by somone using a stick. The odds are always against you in exanima.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAn absolute pleasure to play... Once you get it down, of course. My biggest grip, my BIGGEST gripe about the game? The phyics based movement. I know, I know, physics based game. But when your characters walk like they're about to spew taco bell al over the floor, and doing these goofy unrealistic wild swings.. It detracts from the experience. I was hoping for something a little more.. Realistic. But, it's still in early access and could change for all I know! Even in its current state, it's a great game! All my hours are from buying the game in one sitting, and frankly that just doesn't happen for me anymore. If you're considering buying the game, just know this. It will anger you at first if you've a low tolerance for learning curves. The physics take time to understand and grow accustomed to. Also, keep in mind.. It's early access. While it's rare, stuttering, glitches and crashes do happen. All in all, it's a unique fighting style you don't see in very many games. If they add multiplayer to the arena, fix the taco bell poop walk, and fix the overswinging barbarian movesets, this will be easily one of my top ten favorite combat systems in video games of all time.

Then it ended (sort of) it currently has not ending, so at level 4 your just sat in a empty dungon with 2 (maby 3) doors that don't open.

however, i can say i am a bit concerned with how this is sort of a side game" to another game
date: and with that being the case i wonder if this game is actually going to be supported after the other game is released
recommended: and it would be nice if you got a discount on the "main game" if you have purchased this one.\n\nbut anyhow

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAn absolute pleasure to play... Once you get it down, of course. My biggest grip, my BIGGEST gripe about the game? The phyics based movement. I know, I know, physics based game. But when your characters walk like they're about to spew taco bell al over the floor, and doing these goofy unrealistic wild swings.. It detracts from the experience. I was hoping for something a little more.. Realistic. But, it's still in early access and could change for all I know! Even in its current state, it's a great game! All my hours are from buying the game in one sitting, and frankly that just doesn't happen for me anymore. If you're considering buying the game, just know this. It will anger you at first if you've a low tolerance for learning curves. The physics take time to understand and grow accustomed to. Also, keep in mind.. It's early access. While it's rare, stuttering, glitches and crashes do happen. All in all, it's a unique fighting style you don't see in very many games. If they add multiplayer to the arena, fix the taco bell poop walk, and fix the overswinging barbarian movesets, this will be easily one of my top ten favorite combat systems in video games of all time.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSince the new update, the game has a new feel that isn't so diminising in spirit, but rather beckoning of the heart. This game is a dark adventure, and without the mind set you will find yourself lost in the underground. It took me about 22 hours to complete (search most important rooms and defeat most enemies) including completion the Arena in both modes and finishing to the (TO BE CONTINUED) at the end of the short chapter. It was fun most of these hours, some were spent in agony in the earlier times when I was impatient and could not fight :). But for the majority the chapter was fun and I enjoyed the constant feeling of death, it kept me on edge. This game was worth at this point the 14 dollars I spent, so far, so I hope to see more levels added along with more gear, random enemies of different kinds (more monsters, like maybe spiders or something scurry).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'd like to be kind to this game, it has fantastic art and atmoshere, but an awful combat system.

I'm really not sure what I'm supposed to be doing -- my character's obviously numb arms and drunken feet flail about even when I'm carefully moving the mouse. I thought I was supposed to guide the tip of the sword or something, but the character drunkenly swings at his foe when simply clicking the mouse. The game has no tutorial level, or anything of that sort, so good luck figuring out key commands, no end goal, and no back story (though I suppose that's good for RP purposes).

Now for the good part. This game really embodies that clauster-phobic, what's behind the door"
date: "I can't run fast enough" feel that I love about dungeon crawlers. Not to mention the art is really top-notch -- textures
hoursPlayed: and 3D have all obviously been passionately created by people who know their stuff. The character creation is very efficient and gets you moving into the game itself quickly.\n\nWhile it's on sale

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's early access, so I'm really looking forward to the finished product based solely on what has been published so far.

What I really like about this game:
-Physics based combat
-in-depth layered armour
-low fantasy (though it appears that there is magic in the game, it's not available to the player right now)

What I don't like about the game:
-It's not finished (just kidding, there isn't anything to dislike about this game yet... it's not finished) :p

It seems that there is much to come of this game too. Ranged combat has not been implemented, there is no magic for the players yet (I have fought skeletons and some kind of hulking beast that obliterated me), and I would like to see some kind of coop mode. It may be unkind of me to insult another game, but this is what Diablo 3 could have been...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is refreshingly new. The small development team, did really great work the last 3 years.
The outcome is a unique game with mechanics i have never seen before in an RPG game.

but be warned: the game is hard an you will be frustrated at one point (more sooner than later), but with every progress you make, you will get more and more hooked.

Everything in this game is based on the very own physics engine.

I do recommend to watch a short tutorial video before you get started, so you know how things work in this game.

It is not for everyone, but for people who like a challange and a dark fantasy world setting, where dangers lure behind every corner, it is a truly precious gem.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very interesting early access game. Has a handful of bugs such as default clothing disapearing after death and weapon-hand getting stuck on the floor after a knock out making it impossible to move too far away from it (stretchy hand syndrome).
Other than all that...love the difficulty. Love the weapon and layered cloth ratings. Love the mechanics even if the physics sometimes make it look like your character is in some very strong muscle-relaxers.
Another feature to make it even more realistic would be mandatory water and food consumption ala Fallout New Vegas.

Not sure I like the death = hard restart feature. Its one thing to be challenging (dark souls) another to be intentionally frustrating (this game). Still, I thoroghly enjoy the torment, obnoxious though it may sometimes be.
Looking forward to seeing how this game continues to be improved.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

/////-----THIS IS A VERY FUN GAME IF YOU HAVE THE PATIENCE TO LEARN FROM YOUR MISTAKES AND THE COURAGE TO START OVER WHEN FAILED-----//////
Exanima is exactly what we should be expecting from any indie video game developer, it is a top-down hack-and-slash dungeon crawler with strong role playing elements and very very unique central mechanics.
The game features a (of course incomplete) main story mode with classic claustrophobic dungeon crawling and an arena mode in which you can muster up a company of pit fighting warriors which focuses mainly on character-on-character mortal combat with many different rules and set-ups.
The game is very unique and interesting in the way it plays, the excellent physics simulation used in the melee combat system of this game is a very refreshing take on the hack and slash genre, albeit it starts off as really freaking frustrating and hard to master, the average player definitely needs to take more than a few hours to actually get used to the general control scheme of this game, what with the mouse control physics based melee combat and the godforsaken rigid control of the player character.
.
////-----MY MAJOR ISSUE WITH THIS GAME-----////
.
Yeah, the way this game offers of controlling the PC is almost unbearably bad, you see, even though the game's appearance suggests that this game should somewhat control like a Diablo style dungeon crawler, and you wouldn't be entirely wrong, but you would be partially wrong for thinking that would be okay for this particular game. Because maybe it is okay for the player to control the character entirely using the mouse during exploration/non-combat sessions, but it's definitely not an option during combat, where you would need to sidestep, backpedal your way around and away from your foe, which would absolute requires the use of your keyboard directional keys(WSAD), and the movement control is relative to the character instead of the camera, which means, if your chracter is facing south and your camera is facing north, while your foe is swinging his poleaxe at you from your south and you need to get away from him, your instinct would tell you to press the UP(w) button for the camera is facing the direction your character should go, but guess what, because the directional control is character relative, he/she will walk foward and straight into you enemy's killzone and probably get their skull split open like a watermelon.
.
Besides the obvious problem with the chracter-relative movement control and the absence of camera-relative movement controls, which would very likely put off a lot of players, the game's combat system also lacks an active block button, which would most likely put off a whole other bunch of potential players.
Also the movement animation itself is somewhat clunky and makes every ingame human character look like they are either drunk or shambling corpses, speaking of which the actually zombies in this game are vividly (re-)animated using the exact same technology I assume.
...
I'm not saying the game's control scheme is completely unbearable, as many other players and myself have already adapted and gotten used to it, but I would be lying if I say it isn't frustraing as hell and would not benefit from the addition of an alternative option with more traditional and user-friendly design.
.
/////-----Graphics, Sound and Music-----/////
.
This game's 3D rendering is surprisingly realistic and detailed with the chracter models with details being on par or even better than what could be seen in some recent AAA titles like Fallout 4,  the environment however, being nothing more than an actual dungeon, is regretably stark and lacking in interesting features, albeit sporting some decent looking textures as well. The lighting and dynamic shadows in this game however, are quite impressive, with many different light sources casting real-time soft shadows in different parts of the game, contributing a lot to the dark and claustrophobic atmosphere of the game. (p.s. Could use some better physics based female breats simulation though, this game has the potential to trump Metro Last Light in that category.)
.
The sound effects in the game is also pleasantly realistic, with the clanking of clashing metal, sound of sharp blade scratching over a cold stone wall, and of course the violent crushing or tearing sounds of devastated body and bones, very often making the hair on my spine stand up during the extremely intense melee fights between my characters and their opponents. They are simplistic, but very effective in representing exactly what you see while you are playing the game.
.
As for the music, this game has some pretty nicely composed battle BGM which will make you feel even more tense than you already are, which could potentially be a bad thing in a game that requires high level of concentration and alertness like this, but you can always simply turn it off.
//
//
Early Access Verdict as of 8th of April 2016:
+Fresh and unique physics based combat mechanics, with very visceral combat visual and sound presentation
+Impressive graphics and sound designs
+Appropriately presented atmosphere
+Great amount of available equipment including different layers of separate armor pieces (wasn't mentioned above)
-Frustrating and difficult control scheme
+/-Generally steep learning curve
.
RECOMMENDED: purchase to support development. current recommendation level 7/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend this game as it offers something new and exciting to the gaming world, i like how this game has been giving great detail on just about every little thing and the combat system is quite fun, this would be my possitive look on this game.

My dislikes about this game are that there is not a respawn effect in the game and that is all well and grand being that fact that this game was intended to feel more real however just going through the game is pretty tough without having to die once and skills features are lost quite easly, i have found some bugs in the game that can be fixed of corse but i would love a respawn effect and like a hardcore mode of that game were you can only die once as it currently stands.

Thank you for all your hard work making this increable game.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game has a very steep learning curve.  Just as difficult as the first time I picked up Demon's Souls.  The graphics, physics, and atmosphere are very, very well done.  This game is in my personal Top Fives of atmosphere.  The controls feel a little wonky because they are fixed and do not change with your character.  W always goes up even if you're facing down, S always goes down even if you're facing up etc etc.  That is my only complaint of the game.  I have not progressed far since it is difficult and you really need to learn it.  I can breeze through arena mode, but I don't make it very far in the story mode.  Every hit is never the same.  If you hit an enemy in the head and make them stumble, but you move a little too close to them to hit them again you might not have enough power to finish them off.  Every encounter feels like a mini-strategy game; different than the Soulsborne world but similar as well.  If you get easily frustrated than this game isn't for you.  You will fail, you will die, and you'll do it hundred times.  Very fun game.

Early Access Review

I think, that this game will someday be one of my favoured games. It has a detailed enviroment tons of different weapons, many layers of armor and an interesting philosophy concerning combats.

But at this stage the game is not fun.It is more or less unplayable. After 5 hours in the same room of the so called practice mode I hardly manage to come to opponent 5. It is that hard, that I concider it more as work than as a game. The story is not really existent yet.

There will have to be an tutorial soon and a real practice mode, in which one can really practice without getting back to the main menu screen all the time.

Indeed one improves after a while (10 hours !!) and the game turns to be a little more fun.

I wouldn't really recommend this game unless you want to spend many hours in learning the game and getting frustrated. But I also think a bad review wouldn't be fair to the developers

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: You may like this game a lot, any issues with it come down to personal tastes, but Steam doesn't have a possibly recommend" option.

I personally dislike the combat system. If the combat system is important to you
date: then I'd advise you to consider the purchase of this game very carefully and watch a few combat videos. The other big issue I have is the lack of save options in the dungeon exploring mode. At the moment (checkpoint system apparently coming later) if you die you've got to start everything from the beginning again. The art style is excellent in my opinion though
recommended: and if you can find enjoyment in the combat system this would probably be the best isometric dungeon crawler you could buy.\n\nYou may or may not find the controls difficult to grasp
hoursPlayed: a few in the forums have complained about the controls. I personally figured them out in about 5 minutes and don't have an issue with them myself. Everything revolves around the mouse cursor:  in combat W moves you towards the mouse cursor
voteText: D away from it
helpfulPercent: and A/D rotate clockwise/counterclockwise around it. In explore mode you can right-click and hold to move towards the character. In combat mode a double left-click and hold will perform an overhead attack
votesHelpful: a single click and hold on left/right side of your character will perform a left or right swing. Not pressing any mouse buttons and aiming your cursor roughly in the direction of an opponent's attack will make your character try to block it.\n\nI don't like the combat for a few reasons. Overall
votesTotal: everything is somewhat slow and there is a sense that your character is drunk. Movement follows a "step
votesFunny: slight pause
commentsCount: step" pattern and I feel it could be much more fluid. Swings have big windups and are also a little slow. The blocking feels too automatic - all you have to do is release your attack keys and aim in the general direction of the opponents incoming swing. If the pace of combat were faster this might be an okay system
column16: but incoming attacks are very easy to react to so there doesn't seem to be much skill involved in blocking.\n\nPhysics is calculated on the way you move and your swings and this does result in some neat features. You can use your movement to add force to your swings. The part of the weapon that hits you also matters
column17: so you could step into the swing of a pole weapon (like a halberd) to avoid getting hit with the bladed part of the weapon and instead get hit by the pole
column18: taking reduced damage. If you step into your opponent's swing right as he's winding up you can prevent him from being able to complete the swing. It's also possible for you (or opponents) to actually trip and fall over objects on the dungeon floor. However
column19: if having these physics means keeping the drunken like movements and slow combat
column20: then I think the game could've done without the physics. If you don't mind slower paced combat (and possibly difficult controls) and like what the physics adds then I think this game is potentially worth purchasing.\n\n"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGraphics? Great. Concept? Intriguing. Challenge? Difficult but not in a good way. The camera set up is not a good one and having the direction input constantly changing because the camera can't stay still and constantly needs to be reset with the space bar is not a good thing. Challenging game play is one thing, i can accept the increased difficulty from the physics and hit detection, but the ai, which was programmed very nicely, will decimate you not because you didn't swing at the right time but rather cause your character constantly needs the camera re-positioned. Perhaps have the camera always facing behind the character unless we toggle it off otherwise,  or maybe add a lock on system and dodge so that the constant slow hobble that is the player's combat movement doesn't hinder us. The ai can sprint, turn and ignore the need for a camera while in battle. The player cannot. Improvements in this vital area would more than change my current opinion of this game.
