Not everyone wants to sink several hours into adapting to clunky, unintuitive controls.

I'm an alpha backer. I keep coming back to this game and giving it chance after chance after chance. It STILL feels awful to play. Even after you get the hang of it, you're still fighting your own drunken movements more than the opponent. The physics based combat makes everything feel ragdolley, sluggish. Everything has that lag as if you're playing with motion controls.

It's hard, but not in a fun way. I don't feel any joy from landing blows and defeating opponents. Combat feels like a chore. Don't listen to the rabid fanboys, give this a pass.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Exanima is a game with a lot of promise. From a distance, it looks like the first game in a new generation of roguelikes, with actual graphics and an exciting physics-based combat system that makes beating someone to death with a hammer feel like beating someone to death with a hammer rather than clicking on a 3D model until its health bar disappears. However, it has a fatal flaw: the combat system is broken.

Trying to control your character in combat is like trying to use keyboard to drive an actual dump truck. To swing your weapon, your choices are a slow right-to-left swing, a slow backhand left-to-right swing that doesn't register 70% of the time, and a very slow overhand haymaker that is impossible to aim and is useless if you want to stay alive for long. I suspect that there's no option to thrust your weapon because, like real life, that would be by far the most effective choice. Characters move with an unrealistic lack of urgency, making it impossible to quickly step out of an attack or into a blow. Worst of all, there's no player input for defending, which is the most important part of real fighting. Your character simply does it passively whenever you're not attacking. Often you will be perfectly positioned to stop a slow overhead strike, and still end up watching your oppenent's hammer slide off your shield and right into your head, killing you instantly. All of this clumsy design muddles fighting into something more like a roulette wheel you can tilt in your favor rather than a system you can master.

As it currently exists, Exanima is less like a game and more like a toy. You will die many frustrating deaths, sometimes because of a mistake you made that you can learn from, but mostly for reasons outside of your control. This is bad design. If you buy Exanima, buy it because you want to hit a zombie in the face with a machete and are OK with dying a lot for arbitrary reasons. If you don't think you'd like that, I can't recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just be warned that the combat system this game focuses around is extremely different, and you may never get used to it. The largest hurdle (for me) was the fact that pressing the key to move right can move the character left on the screen, depending on where your character is facing, and the character constantly changes directions to where you move your cursor. If you can wrap your brain around that, then you will be fine, but if not, you are screwed because there are no alternative control options and the developers (at least for now) do not want to implement them either!

I'll update this review if anything changes during Early Access, but I'll leave this as a warning for those in doubt.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keeping with the updates, a few things have changed:

Pros:

1.)  Combat is a bit tighter.  Not in any revolutionary way, but there's somewhat less delay between player input and your character actually doing something on the screen.

2.)  The camera is much friendlier in the Arena.

3.)  Damage now seems more consistent with what you're seeing on the screen.  (Meaning: really nasty-looking cuts or blows now appear to actually cause nasty levels of damage.)


Cons:

1.)  Blocking is still woefully broken.  Sometimes, blocking works as intended, sometimes the enemy's weapon just passes right through your own.  Blocking should work 100% of the time, like it does for the AI.

2.)  Occasionally, you get spun around or knocked down for ridiculous reasons, like having your swing blocked.  Then, 99% of the time, you turn the wrong way to face the cursor, exposing your back, and there is nothing the player can do to prevent this.  This really needs to be fixed.

3.)  Enemy bosses" now get instant reaction times and swing their weapons twice as fast as you can while taking triple the damage!  How exciting
recommended: and balanced...\n\n4.)  Probably as a side effect of the physics being tightened up
hoursPlayed: weapons and ragdolls have much more "dead" weight.  You used to kill an enemy and send them sprawling.  Now
voteText: they all basically sink to the ground in slow-motion and take forever to come to a rest.  It was more satisfying before."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Total overhaul of my review, played around with the game some more.

As mentioned in the last one, i had high hopes for this game, I still do.

And I still want to recommend it. Not only because the developers are very creative with their puzzles, but also because combat is... well, combat.
It's hard, you're not some elegant fencer, heck no. You're a jack of all trades, master of none.

Sure, you can use any weapon you want. It's not a guarantee that you'll be good at it. Players actually need to find the weapon combination that fits them specifically.
The map is like a maze as well, and instructions are still somewhat unclear. when it comes to the world itself, and the enemies will sometimes block the doors so you can't get back out, especially if they are hunting you.

But all that aside. Once you finally learn to fight in this game, it's actually pretty fun, but rest assured. the road to learning combat in this game, is a rather rough one... You'll get frustrated and angry multiple times.

Also, It seems that this game will have some pretty deep rpg elements, like levels. I'm looking forward to it.

Though I have one thing to add;

HP.
In this game, hp is probably the most treasured thing. You can take permanent damage... And it's really hard to regen it in the story mode. (as far as I know, it's only through one specific item)

Hoping we will see other means of regenerating permanent damage, not that such a method should come easily. I'm thinking through meditation (seems to be a skill tree that the devs are working on)
Maybe the higher tiers would allow you to slowly regenerate permanent damage when out of combat, and not running.

For now, i'm recommending this game, even at full price, and it's a must play for gamers looking for a unique and hard combat system.

But don't tell me I didn't warn you. This game. is TOUGH!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finished early-access version of Exanima. After the first play session I've got a mostly negative impression: physics and graphics are good, but camera is inconvenient, controls are difficult, you don't know what to do and where to go. But after I've got the hang of controls and started defeating opponents in melee combat, I've come to appreciate the exploration component of this game. I liked going through dungeons seeking the way out. Right now the game has no saves, only checkpoints between levels. And knowing that after death you need to start from the checkpoint adds adrenalin to the fights.

Waiting for the final version!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

how to win:

-stack those shirts
-roll blade, trust
-keep the cursor between you and your enemy
***-alternate holding and tapping the SPACE BAR to control your camera***
-stop attacking to block/parry
-C-C-C-CROUCH ATTACK (with C)

how to lose:

-trip on anything
-get chased into tripping on something
-spam attack
-assume something is friendly

--

This is a seriously interesting game, but I want to be clear that if I wasn't fond of soul crushing ragdoll combat I would be a little frustrated with this purchase in it's current state. If you're expecting a polished combat system right now I wouldn't come here.

That being said, I am so excited to see what this will be like down the road and I expect to put plenty more hours in. Once you get a feel for the controls and actually start landing some heliocopter headclockers it feels good. Just bring a little extra heaping of good humor and patience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great Physics Driven Combat System with Great Artwork, Lighting and Sounds.

Game only flawed in 2 main areas for me. Firstly, a hardcore anorak developer who does not want players to be able to 'save early, save often' choosing instead for rage quitting perma-death (console style checkpoint system has been implented apparently, though I never got that far).

Secondly, the combat is not really conducive to narrow passage ways, and if the game is worth buying, it's only worth it for the practice arenas, where you get to perfect the aforementioned excellent Combat Physics - this isn't animated combat, it's physics! Stumble, fall, swing wildly and collide with your opponent for victory. A victory which never felt this good before in any sword wielding game I've ever played.

Keep an eye out for Sui Generis, by the same developer, which will provide more open area for fighting and alleviate at least one of my concerns. Either way, two thumbs up and yes, it's worth a buy, if only for the Practice Arena.

9/10 (minus 1 point for the anorak)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bought this game, played for about 20 minutes and promptly returned it.  I really wanted to like this game.  However, after figuring out how the combat system works, all I can say is that I am very underwhelmed.

My main gripes are as follows.

Your character swings every weapon like a drunk, blocking is NOT manual, and there is no way to attack other than swing wildly.  I'm not sure how having a character that automatically swings all his weapons into chairs and tables  or one that doesn't even attempt to block most attacks is realistic...

Enemies stare at you for a few seconds, then attack you.  There is no chance for interaction.  When I read the description for the game this is one of the features I was excited about, yet not one I saw any evidence of.

I might come back and try this game after it is more complete, however as it is right now, the combat is simply far to clunky, boring, and unrealistic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to love this game, I really do.

I backed the Sui Generis Kickstarter and I think the engine is amazing. It has a ton of potential. The graphics and audio are sublime and once there's more content and the whole thing is little more fleshed out, this is going to be the benchmark for RPGs.

That said, I find this game impossible to enjoy. Yes, the controls are clunky but I could live with that if it weren't for the permadeath combined with hard to control combat. I rarely make it any distance at all. Then I restart, a couple of times, get fed up of hunting for the barrel lid to use as a shield, and give up for a another few months.

This is my 4th time coming back to this game and, frankly, I doubt there will be a 5th unless there's a significant update.

It's possible I'm just exceptionally bad at this title, but I have no similar problems with any other games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't know how this is a 'very positive' game. Controls are frustrating to say the least. Camera control makes it worse. Combat is near impossible especially with no tutorial to help explain how in the world to do anything, especially when you have to keep adjusting the camera mid-fight to face the right direction and you constantly sidestep in the wrong direction because that's just how the controls are setup. I get that it's 'physics based' combat and this game has props from me for trying something new, but for now, I think it's being executed poorly. Got frustrated at it and quit in less than an hour. I believe I said the words 'This is a terrible game' while playing. If you're looking for a new RPG/Dungeon Crawler/Hack n Slash: look elsewhere. At least until more work is done on this game and it gets improved. Overall it does look good and the devs are trying something new with physics based combat, but I think they need to work on the combat more to make it enjoyable. As for now, I cannot reccommend this game. If the controls get improved so you can actually see where youre going and defend yourself successfuly, then I might reccommend it. For now though, wait on buying this until it's out of EA.

Played it some more after writing this review. I got further and enjoyed it a bit more, but the character controls and camera controls are still really annoying and wonky. It is a good game. The graphics look good, the lighting and shadows are really good, but I think the controls suffer and the physics system needs more work. This makes the game retain the 'not recommended' vote at least until the controls get updated.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I thought the high difficulty in this game was going to be from well made A.I, deep combat system and a world similar to Dark Souls. Instead I got 'drunk wheelchair simulator' with a camera system so bad that if you were to design the worst camera system on purpose, it would still end up being better than what's in this game. You're not buying this game to fight well programmed AI or other players, but to fight the horrible controls and camera and ''realistic physics''.  Just make sure to enjoy those precious hours of fighting bad development choices, because the actual game itself isn't even worth suffering through to begin with.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You cannot control blocking, your character randomly blocks some attacks and not others.

Attacking controls are extremely vague and unresponsive.

Movement is awkward and is relavant to the direction your character is facing, not the direction YOU the player is facing.

Movement is also very 'floaty' and feels like people are drunk or fighting under water.

Maybe later in development the controls will be more intuitive but just now they are unique but at the detriment of playability.

Hopefully I get a refund and I might buy it later when on sale and the game is finished...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First things first, I like the game. Would I recommend it to someone else short answer no.

The combat is interesting and different and the Arena mode is good fun, the AI is also very good and does a fine job of being challenging but not unfair.

The problems start in the single player campaign game. The lack of save points is a real issue, I have had a look around and I understand the arguments against them, however adding in different difficulty modes would change nothing for hard core players and would lower the barrier for entry for other people with less time.

The loot system is random so some times I get nice armour others nothing of much use, this can be irritating in a game where you are expected to replay levels over and over. I feel like the loot should be fixed. This is how every other element of the game work so why chests are random makes no sense.

Due the the amount you will have to replay sections of the game while learning much of the immersion and atmosphere are lost, while permanent death dose make the game tense a lot of that tension is lost when you know the exact layout of the levels and the enemies in them. In many ways this seems a strange choice as the initial play troughs are great fun but quickly turn frustrating or just boring.

At the moment this is only a game for the hard core player, I don’t think its a bad game but I do think it has an extremely limited audience in its current form. I would say to anyone think very carefully about how much time you have lean to play. Also think about how much repetition in a game you are comfortable with. You will have to replay the first levels a lot even with the save points at the end of each level.

So in short:

- Interesting Combat
- Nice concept
- Lots of repetition (Destroys the sense of immersion)
- Will take a large time investment to get good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can see what they're trying to do with the combat, and as everyone says it has great potential. But for a complex system it's too simple. Let me expand on that. In order to block you move the mouse in a way that will move your weapon to stop the force of the opponents blow, but in combat mode you always face the direction your mouse is, so you end up spinning around, unable to strike on your open opponent. You also have to manually track the target to keep facing towards them, again based on where your mouse is pointing.

Movement with the WASD isn't so bad to get used to but it feels so unresponsive and your character will randomly stop moving then start again. Walking around with the torch in the dar kdungeons and exploring and using the physics engine is great. But the combat (which most of this game is) is just not fun. It's not fun to learn and it's not fun to do.

Hopefully it will be improved upon to make it more user friendly because if they don't, no-one except the hardcore fans are gonna want to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Reinventing the wheel...

If you want a challenge, buy the game just to beat the Arena modes.  Should take anywhere from a hour to a couple for almost anyone to complete the Arenas.

It is not that the combat or game is really hard, its simply different.  They reinvented the wheel for combat so its a learning process and not just learning what to do... but learning how to actually be competent with the controls.  Ever play Surgeon Simulator? Its like that, in that it has its own semi unique control scheme which forces players to learn something they have never done.  It also while fun for a bit is far from perfect...(explain more farther down)

Why did I buy the game? I was on the fence for a while and recently watched a stream play through the campaign (Its not really much of a campaign... its like a modern version of a reallly old dungeon game... none of the standard fair is there... No MAP, no inventory management, no dialogue, honestly not much of anything...) Its a giant maze that you just wonder around in fighting.  Hoping you dont trip over something, if your not paying attention you will forget there is even a sort of back story going on.  So with having previewed the campaign I just wanted to test my mettle against the combat system" and see the hype and hate about it first hand and see if I could master it or not.

Back to the Combat... For a game that hypes the combat so much

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI understand games trying to be difficult, I even enjoy it; at least when that difficulty leads to excitement or a sense of achievement. Exanima is difficult and tedious, and even when you play well, it feels unrewarding. The combat system was promising, but unreliable - for example, even when blocking in the direction of an incoming attack, you sometimes take huge damage. The level design is repetitive and unintuitive; its very difficult to find your way around because everything looks the same. I'd give a 2/5 - has some promise and interesting ideas, but not enough to make me want to keep playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Weeell..... I think it is good in its way. I like the setting and that developers decided to use general ideas of gameplay from Dark Souls (i guess), which is not that easy. But i don't like battle mechanincs so far, not in this way. I had to spend time and get killed like a hundred times to finally understand it. In general it is simple, you hold your sword by doing nothing and the player parries himself as long as you keep distance and in forward of the enemy. Once you've parried you hit him back. On at a time, or he will hit most likely hit you on your second click. And you do this until the enemy is dead. If you come across 2 enemies or more - you run away and try to kill them one by one. This is game's batle mechanics. Takes a lot of time to undestand and makes you feel stupid and bored once you did that.
The game has nice picture, but level design is too complicated. You can wander around for 2 hours to come across closed door, and than look for a little key for another 2 hours. I could make it futher than second level because i couldn't find one of those keys. Loot is boring as well, at least for now. You have to undress every item you have to compare it to the one you've found.

Pluses:
- Nice graphics
- Entourage Interaction
- Interesting world design
- Optimization

Minuses:
- Blank looking levels. I know that this is a setting, but orienting in these corridors is damn hard.
- Very complicated level design
- Every fight looks like a fight of drunk people
- abolutely not intuative battle mechanics...

... And the most important:
- awfull awfull awfull controls!!! I hate them! Why can't you simply walk on wasd the direction you press? The importance of comfortable controls is undoubtedly very high! How can you expect this game to gain popularity among mass players with such awfull controls? Even Dark Souls knows that despite making gameplay hardcore you must give a player comfortable control scheme. The receipt of good game is not in making gameplay hard through difficult controls, but making the challenges hard with good controls!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An RPG with isometric 3D graphics and strange character controls . I wouldn't recommend this to children who don't know how to play it. You have to learn it, it's not that hard.

Pros:
+Atmosphere
+Graphics

Cons:
-A guy with heavy armour and a two-handed sword attacks quicker than naked me with a wooden stick.
-Your character is wiggling from side to side like he/she's drunk, which makes the overall gameplay very difficult.
-Strangely enough, your character doesn't block a lot of attacks while your enemies do block most of them.
-Sometimes enemies can hit you in a very weird manner.
-The Arena isn't very sophisticated (early acces tho).
-When it's all against you in the Fray mode, ♥♥♥♥ gets very annoying.
-A wooden stick is sometimes more effective than a warhammer.
-There is no map.
-All items are a bit overpriced in the Arena.
So far, the early access isn't quite good but the full release might be awesome.
The soundtrack isn't exactly right up to my alley.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

May 2015
God damn it I want to like this game, a lot. I really do. The physics engine, the realistic duels, the setting, graphics, tone. EVERYTHING! I want to like this game! The game reminds me of part Diablo, part Chivalry, and part Resident Evil. The fight engine, OMG I love the realistic physics based fight engine. It feels like a top down version of Chivalry realistic melee engine, constantly trying to block and parry to land a crippling blow BUT with the current controls and camera it is so hard to simply walk down a hallway without tripping much less have a coherent fight. It reminds me of controlling a string puppet the way it moves but the AI doesn't seem to have this handicap as it easily pursues you and counter attacks your character on every one of your uncoordinated swings. The controls are Resident Evil style Tank controls along with a rotating camera (If it was just a fixed camera or locked behind you it would be fine), W moves forward regardless the direction the camera is facing. As the camera rotates you feel as if you are fighting the camera as well as the enemy and it becomes so frustrating because when you die you feel like the game unjustly killed you, mixed with the lack of no saves or checkpoints it gets harder and harder to want to restart every time you die. I feel like they were trying to reinvent the wheel by replacing it with 4 concrete blocks.

In the end this is alpha, the controls flat suck and you only have two attacks swing and chop, no thrust yet even though its listed in stats. The game can still be great just not yet, maybe in the Beta.

Update May 2016
-----------------------
I tried this game again so here are a few bullet points.
*They added thrust, which is GREAT but always seems to miss to their left under their arm pit.
*You still feel like your character is drunk as he stumbles into the enemy and sluggishly swings.
*I feel no real umph" when I land a blow
date: everything feels like a glancing blow.\n*According to the Devs the bad controls arn't a mistake
recommended: they are the point so get used to it or get out.\n\nThey say a sign of good game design is "easy to play hard to master"
hoursPlayed: get ready to master just walking down hallways...\n\nI guess I'll see what happens in May 2017."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My first four hours with this game were horrible, absolutely miserable, but boy am I glad I stuck it out!

At first the combat will doubtlessly seem, clunky, jankballs, and unresponsive; in the wrong hands it is. But given a few hours practice the games combat is what makes it truly ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. I have never encountered a combat system that produces such organic and realistic looking melee duels. The duels between a plate armor-clad AI and I look like they are straight out of a fully coreographed medieval blockbuster.

Be warned that Exanima is really a glorified and fleshed out tech demo for Bare Mettle Entertainment's upcoming Sui Generis. Sui Generis is to be an open-world, fantasy, RPG, cluster♥♥♥♥ of awesomeness, and Exanima is really just testing out and stabilizing the game mechanics.

In order to get the most of your gameplay experience, stick to the Arena, this is where the game really displays its most valuable assets.

Great game mechanics right here, its worth the money just for the Arena gamemode. Keep an eyeout for Sui Generis, its shaping up to be a real gem!

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

It's awesome game that's unfortunately a little difficult to get the hang of. Notably it reminds me of the old Die by the Sword, but more deliberate than what DbtS was.

Personally I found the controls to be extremely clunky, but it's side effect of the goals. And I can understand some people just Loving that nonsense (I love that this is one of the few games you can actually stumble in). But as an actual game? I just can not bring myself to recommending this to anyone but those who love crazy awkward physics games in general currently.

And as disclosure, I received this for free for being Kickstarter backer for Sui Generis.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Seem to be on a roll with early access purchase failures of late.

FIrstly, love the concept of what's involved with this game. It's what made me purchase it.

Secondly, there is nothing intuitive about this game. Looks like an experiment in poorly grafted physics port to mouse controls. Keep thinking i need a Street fighter controller just to get combo moves right.

If you're looking for a dungeon crawler that you want to have a bit of fun in. Avoid this.
If you want to have a great frustrating time watching an incredibly small variety of ways of your character getting perma killed. BUY THIS! It rocks!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI certainly do not recommend playing this game at this point. maybe it will get better further in development but for the moment it is not playable in my opinion. i love the idea but the execution is not there. the way the player moves is clunky and that is before you talk about combat. i have played reality based combat games, the warband series does this quite well. exanima fails. the controls are simply not there to do anything other than get lucky with a wild swing. everything is slow or just does not respond. movement is not how people move. they have a lofty goal but so far their not even on the right field.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm writing this as I go.

+ First look, it's impressive, the graphics are surprisingly good.

- Lack of tutorial, but there is a lengthy quick guide. It just wasn't helpful in helping me learn the mechanics of combat or how to interact with objects. That came mostly from trial and error, mostly error and death.

- NO ADJUSTABLE DIFFICULTY: This is a huge negative right now. I suppose they can always add it later because I'm not one to enjoy learning a quirky combat system the hard way, just to play an indy game with quirky combat no one really understands except for the dev team, and maybe people who've been following the game development.

I'm not gonna lie, my patience went from full to zero fast. Instead of destroying my keyboard I downloaded a trainer from a trusted source and proceeded to explore. :/ I wish there was an easier difficulty for n00bs. So take note of that before buying. This game is hard and combat isn't easily mastered. Think of Dark Souls, but with you constantly tripping over crap in the environment and falling on your face while a zombie rapes your butt with a handsaw, true story.

+ Very immersive and dark environment. I want the lead level designer to be my interior decorator, it's like being inside one of my nightmares, confusing, dank, dark, and all around creepy.

+ Surprisingly large amount of layerable armor. Right now I have on Leather boots, leather pants, shirt, leather jerkin, leather cap, leather gloves, and leather vambraces. Bassically I'm ready to go to a BDSM convention. I'm just walking around carrying a barrel lid as a makeshift shield and a bloody wood axe as my weapon of choice. Considering I started with pants, shoes, and a shirt, this feels like a huge improvement.

- Despite supposedly being a way to make friends and gain trust among the shambling corpse like beings I've encountered, I haven't seemed to manage it. Perhaps I'm just too tasty looking? I don't know, everything seems to walk up to me, stare, then take a swing at me. A tutorial would seriously help.

- While the concept for the combat is great, I'm really struggling with the controls. They just aren't very intuitive. It's like trying to learn to ride a bike with the steering reversed. Yeah, it's pretty bad, and they don't seem to be contextually sensitive so the response isn't always what you'd expect, but rather in relation to either the pointer, or which way the character is facing. The controls get a 1 out 10 from me. Seriously, cool idea, terrible experience. Another reason why it is not n00b friendly, aside from lacking in adjustable difficulty.

- No save file system. Why? I don't know, probably some lame tripe about it being more hardcore" or some crap. If that's seriously the dev team idea of fun
date: then they need a reality check. If you want iron man mode you can add it as an option. The rest of us have crap to do. Like feed our 9 foot python our neighbor’s annoying yuppie chihuahua. Then wait behind the bushes on Monday morning to chase the mailman with a machete
